name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on combating child sexual abuse on the Internet (2015/2564(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the sexual abuse of children is a monstrous crime. The European Union has already taken a series of steps to tackle it, both online and offline. The Child Sexual Abuse Directive includes a substantial number of tools to improve the effectiveness of Member States’ responses to these crimes and to facilitate international cooperation. So the Commission does not intend to propose any amendment in the near future but to focus on its implementation.  A study is ongoing to look into Member States’ transposition of the Directive. The results will be available by April, after which decisions on pursuing or opening new infringement  proceedings – 11 are already open – can be taken. In the meantime, the Commission is in bilateral contact with various Member States to facilitate transposition and notification. There are specific issues regarding the need for law enforcement and judicial authorities to access evidence of child sexual abuse online held by private companies located under different jurisdictions. This is a major obstacle to the effective investigation and prosecution of these crimes, which Member States must ensure in order to respect their obligations to protect the fundamental rights of victims. These issues are common to other forms of cybercrime and other crimes facilitated by the internet. Given the global reach of the internet, a European Union response to them must take account of the need for cooperation with the EU’s strategic partners worldwide. A comprehensive approach is essential to ensure consistency, including in the fight against crime, in cybersecurity, consumer protection, fundamental rights and data protection, and e-commerce. These challenges will be considered as part of the reflections for the upcoming digital single market package.  I will now turn to the Global Alliance against child sexual abuse online. The Global Alliance is a set of political commitments by Ministers from 54 countries to take action to improve victim identification and assistance, improve investigation and prosecution, raise awareness, and reduce the amount of child sexual abuse material available online. The Global Alliance has succeeded in a number of points. Commitments have become part of national policy.  But the Global Alliance still needs to address a number of issues. First, ensure that all countries continue to pursue the policy targets, by mutual inspiration and pooling resources. Second, it should reach out to more countries. Third, the Alliance should react to the trends and threats that we see in the real world, and adapt the response to them. We must also work more closely with the internet industry that is ready to play a role within the Global Alliance.  Under the Internal Security Fund, the Commission will support the establishment of public-private partnerships between key players from the private sector and law enforcement agencies. Under the Connecting Europe Facility the Commission will continue to co-fund the long-standing European network of Safer Internet Centres which have a key role in raising awareness about internet safety matters for children throughout the European Union.  Safer Internet Centres currently operate in 27 Member States and cover three functions. Firstly, an awareness centre for empowering children, parents and teachers to make the best use of the internet, building on enhanced digital resource centres, from which specific awareness toolkits and services will be adapted and deployed, in cooperation with schools and industry.  Secondly, an online helpline service for children allowing them to seek advice and to report harmful contact, conduct and content. Thirdly, a hotline to receive information from the public relating to child pornography.  The hotlines make a preliminary assessment of the legality of the content reported, trace its origin, and forward the report to law enforcement. They notify the hosting ISP and monitor systematically the take-down of child sexual abuse content by the ISP. Hotlines are networked through the Inhope association, co-funded by the Commission, on a global level. Finally, the Commission will continue to support law enforcement in more efficient identification of victims and perpetrators by co-funding the development of shared databases, currently hosted in Interpol, giving law enforcement better access to data and evidence available worldwide.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, a heartfelt thank you for this debate, which I consider to be very important. My final point is that, on the subject of encryption, we must ensure that it is important on the one hand to prevent espionage in order to guarantee security, privacy. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, the subject is extremely important and, I think we all are aware of, the sexual abuse and all the terrible things that happen to children make us think about what can be done. If you believe that this association financed by the Commission also has security and the guarantee of personal data?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – When companies examine data on the Internet, it is not done by personal inspection, because the data is far too many, but it takes place using technical algorithms. Only when specific characteristics, such as the rape of a child, are discovered by algorithm, a personal insight takes place. Against this background, I consider this form of inspection to be important.

text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Hohlmeier, every citizen is obliged to intervene appropriately if he accidentally discovers a crime. However, in the discussion on this directive, we have noticed very well that, in addition to the clear abuse of children, there are also many cases of doubt that are not clear. It is therefore important that there should be consultation with public authorities on such issues.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the measure of any society is how we protect those who cannot protect themselves. There are very few situations where there is an absolute right and an absolute wrong, but where the exploitation and abuse of children is concerned there is no confusion. It is the worst kind of crime. We must do all we can at every level, national, European and global, to eradicate it and punish those that seek to do children harm. Arguments on freedom of expression and the right to privacy cease to be relevant in this context, and when we ask ourselves what needs to be done to stop the abuse it is quite simple: everything humanly possible. We need to work with internet companies and providers, social media, schools, parents, communities and police authorities. We need to block search results that lead to child abuse. We need to identify illegal images and take them down. We need to capture and prosecute perpetrators and provide justice for victims, and to give ourselves the tools to do so. Then we need to offer victims the necessary help and assistance to feel safe again. There are too many dark corners in the internet, and the most heinous of crimes are committed there. Children need a united voice committed to protecting them and their childhood.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a few weeks ago, in the Committee on Freedoms, in an important debate on the fight against cybercrime and cyber-predators, we have seen horrific data and statistics, inspiring disgust and abjectness towards children: 4 million child pornography materials are currently circulating on the internet. The victims are younger and younger - 10% of children are under two years of age - the images are becoming more violent, the network has an increasingly sophisticated encryption system, etc. A few weeks ago, I began to try to understand how things worked on the dark web and became more aware - if needed - of its sordid and dangerous facets. Some networks, including Tor and Freenet, are totally hijacked by cyber-paedophiles and, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot stand idly by in the face of this indignity. On reading the AFA report, we see that, in 2014, there was a 100% increase in reports of child pornography. That is to say, we have found, once again, that this child pornography on the Internet is increasing more than ever. In the face of this horror, this abjection in our democracies, what answers? Firstly, can we get a real report to assess the implementation of the European directive, the deadline for transposition - I remind the Commission - was 13 December 2013? Can we get information on that? Can the Commission exercise its role as guardian of the treaties in this regard? Second, what about the role and potential increase in the skills and powers of Europol's Joint Cybercrime Action Taskforce and the Cybercrime Centre? Thirdly - you have not really mentioned this, Commissioner, and I regret this - we must act to remove the sites and block them in order to remove these horrors and child pornography. Thank you for giving me some answers.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I am pleased to see that this issue has been given some attention. The best way to advance this discussion is on the basis of a detailed proposal coming from the Committee on Civil Liberties, which we await. Obviously this is a big issue but it is an area that needs to be looked at from a grassroots perspective: that is the only way to ensure children are protected. Children are carrying around smartphones in their pockets, and very few are aware of the risks associated with them. We need to explore the use and danger of new media so that children take precautions, and we need to ensure that parents and educators have the skills to inform. We should look at solutions which, while protecting children, also protect a free internet, and we should open up the discussion and raise awareness. Recently in my own constituency in the North of Ireland, relatively innocent photographs of schoolgirls were obtained and used online: 732 photographs of schoolchildren from 19 post-primary schools were on a pornographic website used by paedophiles. This is shocking stuff, but it should be used as an example to show others in this age group just how careful they need to be. Many believe that the people uploading these photographs should have been arrested, and this leads to the question of necessary measures to address this issue of ownership of photographs on social network sites, and how they are legally or illegally prepared.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think all of us will welcome the review of the directive when it comes later this year. It is very disturbing for us to hear just how many Member States have still, apparently, not fully transposed its provisions. Obviously, as people have said, the removal of existing content on websites is an important issue, and the directive makes it very clear that action to take down sites is compulsory and that, even if Member States choose to block, we need to be clear in the law about where responsibility lies. I think this partly answers the question that was raised earlier about service providers or whoever else it is: the law needs to be clear about what their action should be, and I think the directive is clear on people’s responsibility. I would also welcome it if the Commission could say a little more about the difficulties it is having in getting agreement with third countries where sites are hosted and how that can be followed up, because we are all aware that child abuse images should not be acceptable in any country in the world. Indeed, child abuse itself should not be acceptable. I think we also we need to link together some of the actions that we are taking on vulnerable children, for example the measures in place to report missing children rapidly. We need to close the gap in our asylum system, where at present there is no duty for anyone to follow up on children who go missing. Others have spoken –  and my colleague just now – about the issues of the prevention and empowerment of children and young people so that they do recognise the risks. Certainly the Safer Internet Centres play an important role in also being a point of contact for children who cannot, or will not, report things to parents or teachers. I also think that there are issues here about good sex and personal relationship education, so that children understand what is really happening. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Mrs Representative mentioned that many Member State governments are hesitant, slow or even idle in transposition of the relevant directives. He also mentioned that cooperation with third countries is also experiencing certain difficulties. We speak unanimously here in this Chamber, but what do you think is the reason why governments are reluctant? I was thinking of national governments in the first place.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I am sure that the report that we get from the Commission will help clarify why some Member States are taking so long to actually implement the Directive.  I think that for some it is a question of whether it matches with their own particular laws, in particular where they are having to increase penalties, but like you, I find it amazing that Member States have really not got their act together on this. This is absolutely a crucial thing about protection of young people and, whatever the reasons, we should be asking our colleagues in national parliaments to be raising the questions there, as well, about why this is not transposed.

name: Diane DODDS
text: Mr President, while the internet has been one of Europe’s most transformative assets in terms of expanding opportunities for businesses and consumers, we must accept that it has also aided the faceless criminals who prey on children online. It is therefore an area where we are right to work together to seek solutions and fight against such abuse. November 2014 saw the publication in my own constituency of Northern Ireland of an independent report into child sexual exploitation, compiled by Kathleen Marshall. This found that, in one instance, a school reported it had identified six cases of online grooming in the last four years. The most recent Young Life and Times Survey in Northern Ireland reported that a staggering one in nine 16-year-olds had experienced grooming. We really must ensure that our children are equipped to deal with the internet. But, more than that, we must ensure that the global giants who run the internet ... name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: With the advent of these new technologies, we are growing up with a generation of young people and children who control technological innovations much better than their parents and educators. Therefore, it is much more difficult for parents, who have primary responsibility for raising their children, to protect them from inappropriate and harmful content on the Internet. Children are naturally more trusting, often unaware of the dangers they face when they visit such inappropriate sites or communicate with inappropriate people. I think that this is our responsibility to establish and apply legal action against producers of such inverted cases. As a Member of the Slovak National Council, I have openly raised the problem of displaying inappropriate, often pornographic content in the daily press, and my Nahota for Sale campaign was intended to legally anchor the protection of children from inappropriate content. To date, almost 70000 signatures have been collected to support this idea, and I believe that this threat to the moral education of young people begins with such surveillance also in the daily press and access to open pornography.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The sexual abuse and exploitation of children on the internet is getting rougher and coarser and the victims are getting younger, and the images are spreading across the world at lightning speed. In 2011, we adopted the directive on combating child sexual abuse on the internet. Now the Commission really needs to come up with this report and set out targeted tools that are effective – not just another report, but effective means so that we can get to grips with this. The suffering is repeated again and again when the images are displayed. We need to equip children for the future, because the future is tough for all of us and children are our future. Here, the Commission, together with us in the European Parliament, must now take action against this heinous crime.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: No country can deal with this terrible phenomenon alone, because the online space has no borders. I think it is clear that public authorities do not always have sufficient resources to trace crimes committed, all the more so to prevent them. Change therefore requires not only increased responsibility for child abuse, but also greater funding for responsible authorities, joint training and information between workers in the European Union and other countries. Cooperation between supervisory authorities in different Member States must also be improved. It is necessary for information to reach different institutions quickly, to provide for and to keep up-to-date joint rapid response plans. On the last speech, I would like to ask my fellow Member whether it would not be appropriate to provide as European legislation for facilitating access to complaints, that is to say, to impose an alarm on the homepage of search engines precisely in order to reject and begin directly to denounce what are perhaps child pornography content on the Internet.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you to my colleague for your question. Indeed, I believe that various measures are possible, but they need to be interpreted and we need to consult with specialists on how to do this, how much it will cost and whether it will have an effect. A proper study should then be carried out.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr. President! The sexual abuse of children on the Internet is a heinous crime. Pictures and videos of abused children are uploaded every day. We currently have a stock of four million images and videos. This stock increases by 80,000 images and videos per year. 70% of the children on it are under ten years of age, and the worst thing is that the pictures and videos are not deleted. In other words, dramatic situations are preserved for children for a lifetime. Britain is a best practice example of tackling child abuse online. There is a criminal offence that constitutes sexual chats between adults and children on the Internet. A special unit has been set up from the National Crime Agency and the Secret Service to be more active on the darknet. A database has been set up, budget lines have been set up to provide sufficient staff for this task force. A further 50 million pounds have also been allocated to the Global Child Protection Fund. EU countries wanted to implement this. Unfortunately, the directive has not yet been implemented in all countries. That's bad. Paedophiles on the Net are like digital terrorists, and they must be persecuted, just like the terrorists, with coordinated use of police and intelligence services, nationally, European and internationally. Task forces must also be set up and equipped.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, more than a million pornographic images of children are circulating on the internet, 200 new ones appear every day. Between 50,000 and 100,000 paedophiles are coordinated in organized networks. These and other data reflect the seriousness of this matter. The Directive, updating it, or the creation of the global alliance are important measures to address this growing threat. That is why it is necessary to adopt a common approach, covering police and judicial action against criminals, the protection of victims and the prevention of the phenomenon. That is why special guarantees should also be given in the prevention and prosecution of these crimes, and even more in the processing of data obtained in criminal proceedings, in order to avoid further stigmatization of children. We must use technology to eliminate its mistakes, because in a technological problem, part of the solution is technological. It is necessary to remove URLs loaded with criminal content, combat the financing of pages with child pornography, the fight against the distribution and possession of material, especially through peer-to-peer download networks, or the creation of codes of conduct of security on the Internet, among others. And all this with international coordination of the authorities involved, the forces and law enies of the State, the private sector and civil society, especially promoting the role of Europol and its EC3, Eurojust and the European financial coalition against the online commercial sexual exploitation of children. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Dear colleague, you mentioned judicial protection and mentioned police protection. But by the time we come up with the laws that the courts will enforce, a lot of victims may already fall. So I ask you, do you think that introducing sex education as a compulsory subject in education in the European Union is necessary?

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Borzan, no doubt that sex education would be an instrument, but not the only instrument. Of course, what is needed is to leave the scruples and prejudices parked, which have more to do with the protection of crime than with the protection of the victim. Therefore, in my view, all police and judicial legislative initiatives must be aimed at protecting the victim. This victim is a special victim, he is a child victim, he is a victim who deserves the greatest protection.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, we have wasted a lot of time over the last ten years on our first report. If we don't mobilize all our forces, we're going to lose this battle, because today everything is going faster and faster, you know, with the dark web or the deep web.  We have a vital need for a country-by-country state of affairs, as we have already told you, and the answers we know. We need to raise awareness among parents and children, train educators and, why not, set up a European green number on this issue. We also need to be able to block and filter sites. Obviously, Europol's means are paltry, so we really need to strengthen them so that we can better search for and find predators, identify victims and facilitate data sharing. Basically, to protect our children, we need this unwavering mobilization, not only from our politicians, but also from society as a whole.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, I am pleased, in this week of Safer Internet Day and as an official champion of the Internet Watch Foundation in the UK, to welcome this debate and to call for intensified efforts by the hotlines that already exist to take the imagery of child sex abuse down more quickly and to foster cooperation to ensure that the perpetrators are identified and prosecuted wherever they are in the world. Last year the IWF removed 13 300 such images from the internet: a 100% increase on the previous year. At present in Britain there are a series of high profile prosecutions taking place on historic cases of child sex abuse from the 1970s. This debate is a reminder that the digital age has provided new opportunities for paedophiles and abusers for abuse and grooming. What Safer Internet Day has taught us this year is that 3 in 4 young people themselves believe they have the power to create a kinder online community. We have to give them the tools to do so.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Commissioner, thank you for your report. I think that the European Commission, the European Parliament and also the Member States must join forces on this issue, because the Internet has no borders. You have listed a number of interventions here, Commissioner, including the implementation of the 2011 directive, but what I am missing is a really detailed assessment of how the directive is implemented. We are not proposing any new regulation or directive here, but we want to ask how the directive works, how its measures are effective. And given the increase in casualties, it turns out that all these legislative and technical measures do not seem to be effective. All these measures are simply delayed for those who want to abuse children. And I would like to ask you what is your opinion on truly effective support and greater awareness in this matter with regard to parents, children and schools.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ

Perpetrators of sexual violence today no longer lurk in the bushes, but behind carefully thought-out usernames and fake social media profiles.  I therefore believe that we need to focus on raising awareness among children and parents about the dangers lurking online. So not wait for something to happen and then react, but to prevent. A child who is informed in a timely and quality manner about the dangers of internet communication with strangers means one less victim. I also believe that we need to develop and disseminate online child sexual abuse reporting systems, such as Red Button implemented in Croatia, and the logistics behind them.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Stylianides, you have already given the data, the NGO data, the Europol data on what is really a difficult problem to solve, not least because it is as if it were the downside of the positive aspects of the Internet. While we have a tool that allows us to join forces, to be able to do things that are unimaginable until a few years ago, on the other hand there is the Deep Web, the Dark Web, something that is beyond our control and which then involves very serious crimes that can have children of two years or less of all kinds as victims. So we have to try to find a way to be able to run as fast as the development of the Internet. It is not easy, the instruments we have available today are not enough and we must try to find solutions together.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: I would like to thank Monica Hohlmeier for highlighting the need to monitor the application and, where appropriate, to update the directive on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children and child pornography. I also join the call for the Commission to set up an awareness-raising campaign that would enable children to understand the risks of the Internet and support parents' efforts to protect children online. In Slovakia, a similar campaign, which I initiated under the title 'Do you know what your child is doing now?', provided parents with basic information on the risks of alcohol and drugs, sexual abuse and human trafficking. It is precisely this that the Commission could now follow up on. Combating child abuse on the Internet must be one of the European Union's priorities in order to find the means to finance such important projects.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for giving me the chance to discuss with you today this challenging and extremely important issue. As you can appreciate, the European Union has already taken a series of steps to tackle sexual abuse of children on the internet, but unfortunately the fight to eradicate this hideous crime is far from complete. Unfortunately.  We need, therefore, to reflect on a policy that balances the right to privacy and protection of personal data with citizens’ security. Ensuring effective investigations and prosecution of child sexual abuse online is a positive duty of Member States to ensure protection of children’s fundamental rights.  Just one point. Indeed, as many others of you have already mentioned, we need more people to work in the focal point, in EC3. This is why the Commission supports the strengthening of Europol. It is very critical. All of us recognise these needs, these demands, already. But I would like to repeat that this is far from complete, this very painful issue, and I am sure that we will continue our cooperation to maintain awareness at an optimum level.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the March I part-session. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. - Reports of child sexual abuse online show alarming trends. There is a growing demand for online content depicting child sexual abuse, there is more violence in such content and the age of victims is getting lower. According to Europol, 10% of victims are under two years old.  It is very difficult for the police to trace the perpetrators, and the content at issue remains online presenting lasting trauma for the victims. It is estimated that about 50,000 disputed photos are uploaded each year. I have written to the Commission earlier about the rapid downloading of unchated content from the internet, referring in particular to the worrying trend when minors victimise each other.  At EU level, children start using the internet on average from the age of 7 and children from 9 to 16 spend around an hour and a half a day on it. The development and availability of technology creates a great space for manipulation. I believe that joint action at the supranational level is a necessary precondition for the successful suppression of these trends.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that modern technology has brought many benefits. The cost of a free and open internet can, however, have hideous consequences, namely facilitating the occurrences of exploitation of and crimes against children. It is vital for us to vigorously peruse from every possible angle all means to protect innocent children from such cruel and deplorable crimes. We cannot afford to waste any time. With every year that passes, the amount of child pornography material and number of websites continue to grow exponentially and contaminate the web. In my country, the Czech Republic, the amount of child pornography content discovered by police soared from 136 in 2007 to 1047 reported cases in 2011. The nature of the internet, however, means that we cannot tackle this problem on a national level. Criminals on the other side of the world can be uploading images that may easily be accessed across borders and jurisdictions. These images do not disappear and continue to re-victimise the children long after the original crime has happened. Locally, nationally, and globally, we must protect our children.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Child sexual abuse online is a crime that is ubiquitous and knows no borders. The fight to eradicate the online exploitation of children is far from complete. Child pornography offenders are increasingly operating in international online groups that use high standard technology and security protocols to frustrate the efforts of law enforcement to investigate their crimes. In addition to the further actions that should be taken to investigate cases of child sexual abuse online and to identify and prosecute offenders, we need to focus on prevention and need effective campaigns to support parents and educators on how to identify the online risks. We need an effective mechanism for reporting suspected sexual behaviour which on the surface can appear innocent. This initiative requires a global approach. While many efforts to improve child online protection are already under way, their reach has been more national than global. We need further EU action with the commitment of online platforms, internet providers and other stakeholders outside of the EU as well to fight against online child exploitation and to build powerful reporting tools and educational resources.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Estimates by the Internet Center for Missing and Exploited Children quantify the volume of child pornography circulating online in 25 million files: in just over 10 years, since the last analysis in 2002, there has been a dramatic surge of about 500%. Adolescents, pre-adolescents, but also children and infants, victims of the darkest navigation, the one that often lurks and hides in the dark web but also among the meshes of social networks. We must do more and use every measure and strategy to stem this infamous phenomenon and exploit the capabilities of the network without endangering our safety, even more so that of our children. Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children must be the starting point for coordinated and tough action, preventive and punitive for crimes of this kind: international task force, promotion of "hashes" to identify the most dangerous images circulating online, initiate a serious reflection in support of the ethics and responsibilities of network giants, information campaigns for the youngest on the dangers of the network and for families for greater control action.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – According to estimates, 4 million images and videos containing child pornography circulate online. More than 70% with children under ten years of age and 10% with children under two years old! This is just a slice of this pathological reality. It is still very difficult to determine the exact number of children used by adults online. Anonymity, which is one of the great advantages of the internet, in this context is its curse. The arguments on freedom of expression and the right to privacy no longer apply here.  Today's debate is a reminder that the digital age is also creating new opportunities for paedophiles. Given the global reach of the internet, the EU's response to their crimes must be to establish greater cooperation with its strategic partners around the world. It is therefore right to create a global alliance to combat the sexual exploitation of children online. Joint action will certainly improve the effectiveness of identifying and assisting victims.  Improving the investigation and prosecution of cybercriminals and raising awareness of threats among parents and children, as well as removing illegal content, will also be crucial. We must do everything we can to protect the youngest participants in virtual reality. Children need our united voice to commit to protecting their childhood.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The Internet has undoubtedly revolutionised our daily lives. For most of us, it has become a primary source of information, education, employment or entertainment. But like any tool can be used in the wrong way. There is no doubt that child sexual exploitation is the most abhorrent form of violence. Today's unrestricted access to electronic media means that more and more minors using these technologies are exposed to content harmful to them. We must not forget that technologies do not stand still and change extremely quickly. Finding a balance between a free internet and combating illegal content online is not easy. However, for the sake of the best interests of the youngest EU citizens, it is our duty to create an effective law that responds to the challenges of the digital age.  The European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to amend the AvMSD. Unfortunately, this has not yet happened. The Commission should prepare such an amendment as well as ensure that Member States implement the 2011 Child Sexual Exploitation Directive as soon as possible. Additional funding should also be found for the education of both children and adults in this area.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: in writing. – At almost every plenary sitting we discuss problems connected to the use of internet and to the violence that persists on the web. It was, once the case regarding war propaganda, but this time it is about the worst case scenario: the sexual abuse of children using the Internet. Personally, I think that all abusers should be strongly punished and that we have to use the logic of zero tolerance in such cases of cybercrimes. I want to highlight the need for the Commission to propose, with the so-called Global Alliance, an overall approach for the prevention of violence on the internet, and to oppose to everything that threatens our freedom and values. The new digital era should comply with new regulations. I feel that our legal system is still not fully ready to tackle new technologies and internet possibilities that go more quickly than our political and legal responses to the new digital era.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. – The fight against the sexual abuse of children on the internet must be immediate, decisive and continuous. We cannot leave our children at the mercy of the various circuits and criminals. This requires strict and effective legislation. Coordination of the action of the Member States of the European Union is needed, and the European Commission is also called upon to play an important role here. However, effective implementation of the relevant EU directive on sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography is required. At the same time, the prosecuting and judicial authorities of the EU Member States must become even more effective in hitting cybercrimes that know no borders. So zero tolerance for child sexual abuse on the internet. That is the message that the European Parliament must send today.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – The abuse of children and the depiction of child pornography material on the Internet is a worldwide scandal. Through the worldwide network, the perpetrators can address children and trade with pictures and films. Children must be protected from this in the best possible way. This includes education in families, daycare centres and schools to deal properly with the new media. Above all, however, this includes a determined fight by the Member States. The Member States must finally transpose into national law the directive adopted in 2011. Furthermore, Member States must not hand over responsibility to private providers in the fight against heinous crimes. Providers must cooperate with government authorities to fight crime at all times. There must be no private systems of monitoring Internet activity that are outside the responsibility of public authorities. This goes against the understanding of the rule of law. I call on the Commission and the Member States to finally ensure that the directive is implemented quickly in the Member States and not to place state responsibility for combating crime in private hands.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – It is a frightening fact that one in five children using the internet received an unsolicited suggestion or request of a sexual nature and that in Europe 10 to 20 percent were sexually abused. Unfortunately, this number is steadily growing and follows alarming trends when it comes to online child abuse. It is known that in developing countries the internet is not represented as in some Western countries, so we must strongly condemn the sexual abuse and exploitation of children including child pornography, prostitution and all other cruel crimes in time, as they constitute a serious violation of fundamental human rights. We must insist on establishing an accurate list of offences, setting minimum sentences, educating competent persons and ensuring the flow of information and criminal records of perpetrators to raise awareness of the seriousness of the problem. Our task is to create a safe environment for children online to protect and enable them at the same time. Furthermore, it is necessary to ensure protection for victims and to develop a reliable legislative framework for finding, identifying and punishing perpetrators, as children are vulnerable and often find their problems very difficult. This is a situation where we must act preventively because fundamental children's and human rights are at stake, the rights of our children - our future.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Obviously, the rapid and free dissemination of information through the Internet accelerates economic and social development, stimulates research and innovation and facilitates access to education in less developed areas. But at the same time, several gates have been opened for crimes, including the very serious problem of sexual abuse of minors and child pornography on the Internet. Important steps have been taken in recent years to combat these abuses, including from the European Commission. I welcome, in this way, the Global Alliance against the Sexual Abuse of Children online. In this context, we need preventive and sanctioning measures to keep up. I therefore call for a more substantial allocation of funds from the European Union to combat this crime. An allocation is required in accordance with the seriousness of this type of offence, on two dimensions: (1) implementation and support of the new measures; (2) public information on them. Organisations facilitating anonymous reporting of these offences need to be more strongly supported through the active participation of all EU states and institutions, and new prevention and sanctioning mechanisms can be introduced. Internet users need to be clearly informed that, by involving them, they can stop the phenomenon and that ignoring abuse supports criminals.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Burundi: the case of Bob Rugurika (2015/2561(RSP)).

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. - Bob Rugurika is a journalist from Burundi, director of Radio Afrique, who was imprisoned on 20 September for allegedly having information about the murder of three Italian nuns, information he passed on to the public, which is his duty as a journalist. The accusation is that he should have given that information to the government. Now he's stuck because – let's face it – it's actually a good time to jail a journalist who makes the government 'uncomfortable'. In its resolution, the European Parliament calls for the swift release of Bob Rugurika, because we see this as imprisonment for not making his voice heard, to stifle his voice. And we must also see this in the light of the forthcoming elections in Burundi. This sets the mood.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. - (C) Mr President, I would like to begin by thank I myself have been a journalist for years, that is, in the framework of professional solidarity, but also of such an elementary sense of justice, because it is indeed our duty to defend people in situations that are like a white and black film, because indeed, a situation in which power persecutes someone who fulfils his mission, a journalistic mission, a professional mission, is a scandalous situation, and three sisters have been murdered. This journalist fulfilled his duty, refused to give the source of his information, and thus behaved a bit like a priest at confession, who also refuses to tell anyone what he was saying to him during the confession. I think it is good that the European Parliament is taking a firm say on this.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. - Mr President, let us talk about the concrete. The European Union has given Burundi EUR 432 million to improve its governance and civil society. Second, Burundi is ranked 142nd in 180th in freedom of the press, according to Reporters Without Borders. Third, there are no free elections without free press. Consequently, what is happening with Mr Rugurika is absolutely intolerable and contradictory to the help that the European Union — 432 million! – is giving to the Republic of Burundi. Therefore, beyond metaphysical, philosophical, empty and useless responses, what is raised in point 12 is essential: either Burundi is taught to the basic rules of conduct in free elections, including the freedom of the journalist, Mr Rugurika, or consultations will be made regarding Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement to suspend Burundi.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Bob Rugurika, president of African public radio, has never believed the official version of the Burundian authorities on the murder of these three Italian nuns, who were probably also raped, while the Government of Burundi says that a man with mental disorders acted alone. Here, as Mr Nart also rightly said, what is at stake is the freedom of the press and the aid that the European Union gives to Burundi, where, moreover, elections are being held shortly. So let's be consistent in our approach to countries where things like this happen, where those who are deemed uncomfortable in government for the activity they do are being held. We are questioning our aid and our relations with these countries. With this resolution we are also paying attention to this, as well as calling for the immediate release of Bob Rugurika.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Author. - Mr President, today we want to draw attention to the violation of human rights in Burundi. We call for freedom of association and expression and, in this context, demand the freedom of Bob Rugurika and all detainees for expressing themselves freely. But we also want to draw attention to the fact that Burundi is one of the ten poorest countries in the world, and we cannot forget that the interests of Western powers have much to do with situations of extreme poverty in Africa. But now, it must also be said that Burundi has coffee, has cotton, has cobalt, has copper, has coltan and has water, as it also borders Lake Tanganygany. We would also like to ask the European Commission and the states that provide funds for special support to combat chronic malnutrition, strongly betting on the development of family and local agriculture, which, while providing basic food for the population, generates wealth and work in the country.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has Burundi has undergone tragic developments in recent decades. It is very positive to note that in this hard-to-examine country, an ever-increasing number of people are betting that a positive future can only be made possible by strengthening democracy and the rule of law and safeguarding human rights. The elections scheduled for this year could be an important step in this direction. However, this requires the unrestricted possibility of freedom of expression. The closer the elections get, the less room for manoeuvre will be, and Bob Rugurika is an important voice for democracy and human rights. We call on the government to release him immediately and without conditions. I believe that we should also increase the pressure on the government.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second time since the beginning of this new Parliament that our Parliament has called on the Government of Burundi to respect its human rights obligations. Today, it is Mr Rugurika's situation that is of great concern to us. He has been held in prison since 20 January, following the broadcast of a report that questioned the official version of the triple murder of the Italian nuns. In this report, a man claimed to have participated in the murder of three nuns on behalf of Burundian intelligence services. After several requests from the prosecutor to reveal the identity of the interviewee and the refusal of Mr. Rugurika, Mr. Rugurika faces 20 years in prison for complicity in murder, violation of the secrecy of the investigation, receiving a criminal and breach of public solidarity. We therefore call for his immediate and unconditional release. Burundi must respect its international commitments on human rights and press freedom, especially as the presidential and legislative elections will be held next May and June. The credibility and smooth running of these elections is at stake.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the authors of this proposal for discussing it in plenary today. Bob Rugurika's case is extremely important. It is another example of a journalist who has been unlawfully accused of his investigative activities. It needs to be clearly named here and to say, the situation is all the worse because he was even accused of a crime that he tried to publish and expose. It is therefore clear here that there is an abuse of judicial power in Burundi and we must draw attention to this in this way. The situation is made all the worse by burundi being a partner of the European Union. The European Union strongly supports this state, and we should not only ask for the release of Mr Bob Rugurika and for an investigation into the heinous murders of three EU citizens, but we should also make it clear that if Burundi does not do this, sanctions must come from the EU and Burundi should be penalised for doing so.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just a few weeks before the elections in Burundi, tensions over the election result and the resulting political implications are evident. Burundi is one of the poorest countries in the world, plagued by a high rate of corruption, in 157th place according to data from Transparency International.  In this context of political and social instability, the unjustified arrest on 20 January of Bob Rugurika, journalist and director of African public radio, is a cause for alarm and concern. Rugurika has been arrested by the Burundian authorities, as is feared, for investigating the motives and motives for the murder of the three Italian missionaries Olga, Lucia and Bernadetta. According to the complaints of some human rights associations, he runs the risk of suffering physical and psychological torture. A number of international organisations have already mobilised calling for the journalist to be released. The court, meanwhile, has already refused release and confirmed the charges. Europe must make firm and decisive representations to the Burundian authorities calling for the immediate release of the journalist and the restoration of conditions of democratic viability in the country.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how much does it cost a man in Burundi to find the truth? How much can you pay for seeing too much? The three Italian nuns, Bernadetta, Olga and Lucia, paid with their lives. Our activist, Mr Rugurika, is in danger of paying twenty years in prison for his desire to sow doubts and not comfortable truths, such as those advocated so far by the Government of Burundi. The latest transfer to Muramvya, a prison known to be a very convenient place to cover up very uncomfortable people, is just the final act of this shameful action by the Burundian authorities. We immediately call for his release and, above all, for him to be allowed to do the work that must be carried out by every journalist and every activist who is truly committed to the issue of human rights. It is not possible for a country to go to the polls by stifling any voice other than that of the mainstream. We in the European Union cannot allow this.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Mr President, I will be brief because it is true that we have already spoken about Burundi on several occasions. The arrest on 20 January of Mr Bob Rugurika, director of Radio Publique Africaine, following reports, as has been said, of an investigation into the September 2014 murder of three Italian nuns offering health care and support to the local community, is undoubtedly disturbing. It is disturbing by its motivation and very worrying about the accusations made about Mr Rugurika, who is in detention and will in all likelihood face various accusations which can lead to sentences of up to twenty years in prison. From this institution we have a duty to demand from the Burundian authorities the immediate release of Mr Rugurika, since his detention constitutes a disproportionate restriction of the right to freedom of expression, and to take advantage of the agreements signed with Burundi by our institutions to force Burundi to choose: development and human rights, or autarchy and our condemnation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Mr President, regardless of the state and the continent on which it lies, freedom of the press and freedom of expression are one of the basic pillars of democracy. What is happening in Burundi in the context of the approaching elections in May poses a danger not only locally, but also regionally, with the Great Lakes area being extremely volatile. The European Union must act to protect the people of Burundi, respect human rights, freedom of expression and the preservation of a stable climate in the region. Burundi must also continue its path to democracy, and Europe must ensure that no backward steps are taken from this road during this tense period. In this respect, the S&D Group strongly calls on the Government of Burundi to respect the commitments made so far, to ensure fair elections and respect for human rights, and for the European Commission to take all measures permitted by the agreements and treaties in force, and last but not least, I call for the immediate release of journalist Bob Rugurika.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Bob Rugurika, director of public radio in Burundi, was arrested when he published a series of investigative reports on the murder of three Italian nuns. Burundi's authorities have once again harassed and harassed journalists and social activists in an order to stop the media from reporting and publishing confidential information on government abuses. In the same room, we have already discussed the case of Dr Pierre Claver Mbonimpa. The Burundian Government has committed itself to complying with the Coton Agreement on Human Rights, including Freedom of Expression, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which explicitly states that pre-trial detention should be based on credible, legitimate charges. I therefore strongly condemn the unlawful detention of Bob Rugurika and call for his immediate unconditional release. Respect for rights in Burundi is an essential condition for transparent and fair elections in 2015 in burundi.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again an arrest, another violation of freedom of expression, which affects not only journalists but also activists and members of political parties. We are here again, after the mbonimpa case that we have denounced, and the situation is unfortunately going to get worse in the run-up to the next presidential elections. Bob Rugurika is guilty of wanting to shed light on the deaths of the three missionary nuns, Bernadetta, Olga and Lucia. Burundi has an obligation to respect universal human rights, including freedom of expression. It is the constraint of the human rights clause provided for in the Cotonou Agreement, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter of Human and Peoples' Rights. The European Union has a responsibility to monitor compliance with this clause and to penalise all violations of human rights. We must monitor the pre-election situation in order to prevent the repeated violations of fundamental freedom from greater effect not only on the democratisation process but also on peace and security in Burundi and throughout the Lake Region.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, human rights violations have been intensifying in Burundi lately. As the presidential and general elections approach in 2015, the regime is stepping up measures to control press freedom. At the same time, it limits the conditions for the election activity of opposition parties. Recently, a flagrant violation of human rights in Burundi has been the unlawful arrest and detention of the well-known activist and director of a radio station, Bob Rugurika, for daring, with documented reporting, to deal with and reveal the murders of three Italian well-beings in September 2014. We therefore support the resolution condemning the violation of human rights in Burundi and call for the immediate release of activist Bob Rugurika.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Mr President, what do Bob Rugurika, Raif Badawi, Nadiya Savchenko or Leopoldo López have in common? Not only that these are illegally detained persons, wrongfully imprisoned for no reason, but we are facing a violation of human rights. I am pleased to be here today in this House where we deal with cases of ruptures, human rights breaches around the world, because we have no double standards, because we have no problem dealing with any case that occurs anywhere in the world, even if it is one person. Today, 12 February, I would particularly like to remind you that one year marks the demonstrations that were violently suppressed in Venezuela, which resulted in dozens of deaths and which are still imprisoned by hundreds of people, including Leopoldo López, whose release we have asked for several times from here. I would like to remind you that our main role from Europe is to defend human rights and defend democracy.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Mr President, unfortunately in Burundi, as we have heard, there is no respect for human rights, there is no respect for freedom of expression, and there is also no respect for freedom of the press, as is happening in other countries of the world that we have also denounced here, from this House, and as my colleague reminded, that is also happening , for example, closely, in Venezuela. The arrests of journalists in that African country are getting worse every day, as some colleagues have also recalled, on the eve of the elections in that country. That is why we call for the release of journalists who are illegally held there in Burundi, to be played in accordance with democratic rules in that African country, and I also take the opportunity to remind those people who are detained elsewhere on the planet unfairly, to be released immediately, as is the case of Leopoldo López in Venezuela.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, this time we're discussing it again in a classic way. We have a horrific murder, first and foremost. We have interests that are related to the great lakes in Africa and we have a partner with the European Union. In the end, we have a reporter. We always discuss this Parliament in some way in similar situations. Either we have a European Union partner who makes trouble or we have horrific murders or when we discussed Congo, we had again that topic that exists as an economic interest around the great lakes in Africa.  In this case, when I talk about the press, here about the journalist, I'm talking about fundamental freedoms. I think we really need to set a common policy and send a clear message to all European Union partners that minimum respect for human rights cannot be compromised with the partners of the European Union. I think that has to be our final position.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President, defender of freedom of expression and the separation of state and church, Raïf Badawi has been sentenced by the authorities of Risde to the inhuman and degrading sentence of 10 years in prison and 1,000 years in prison. The late King Abdullah sent a request for a review of this conviction to the Supreme Court, which in turn referred the case back to the criminal court. The decision on his case was adjourned to 4 March, while he was denied a request to leave Saudi Arabia for Bahrain.  Respect for human rights is one of the key objectives of the European Union's common foreign and security policy, and i therefore reiterate here today the question I asked on 4 February, together with some of my MEPs, to the Vice-President and High Representative of the European Union for Foreign and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini. And the question was this... (I didn't get an answer yet.) What steps do you intend to take to pressure Saudi Arabia to humanise its penal code?

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am very grateful to the honourable Members for having highlighted this subject. I would remind you that the European Parliament resolution on Burundi in September significantly helped in securing the release on bail of human rights activist Pierre Claver Mbonimpa. It also encouraged a more intensive and focused political dialogue with Bujumbura. Despite this, significant issues remain to be addressed with a greater sense of urgency as parliamentary, presidential and local elections come into view. Let me stress my concern, and that of High Representative Mogherini, at the arrest of Bob Rugurika. This took place after his radio station broadcast reports on the murder of three Italian nuns, reports which incidentally deserve to be followed up by appropriate independent inquiries. His arrest raises great concern, in particular given the current pre-electoral climate. The charges against him seem disproportionate, and we see no legal basis for his detention. The issue could have been addressed within the framework of the country’s media law or though the National Communication Council. Colleagues, including our Head of Delegation in Bujumbura, regularly visit Mr Rugurika in detention to check that his conditions are satisfactory. We will do all we can to follow his case and to argue for full respect for the principle of freedom of the media. Shortly after Mr Rugurika’s arrest his case was raised under the intensified political dialogue that EU Heads of Mission are currently having with Burundi. The Heads of Mission insisted on strict respect for legality, the law on the press and the principles of freedom of expression and freedom of opinion, and they called for Mr Rugurika’s immediate release. These messages were made public in a communiqué issued following the dialogue. The Heads of Mission also expressed concern at the possible political impact of this affair, given its timing – and this includes the risk of a negative effect on the political climate, the credibility of the authorities and the ongoing electoral process. With this in mind, I reaffirm how important it is that the upcoming elections are inclusive transparent, peaceful and credible. Keeping Bob Rugurika in detention sends a worrying message to journalists in Burundi. We will continue to call for his immediate release. I welcome the fact that we communicate regularly with Burundian counterparts in our now intensive political dialogue, leading to mutual contractual engagements. We must sustain the intensity of the dialogue and use it to underline that our support for the elections is linked to the fulfilment by Burundi of all the relevant commitments it has made, including those in the electoral law and the roadmap. And of course we will take advantage of every opportunity to pursue the case of Mr Rugurika.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place after today's debates.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Saudi Arabia: the case of Raif Badawi (2015/2550(RSP))

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank The fact that the public torture of Raif Badawi has been postponed several times for health reasons shows one thing above all: the cruel consequences of the first 50 stick blows. It is hard to imagine what the 950 more blows would do. Global solidarity with Raif Badawi must not be allowed to slacken. That is another reason why our resolution today, which calls for Badawi to be released, without conditions, is important. It is not an isolated case. Many bloggers and human rights activists are imprisoned in Saudi Arabia, and the right to freedom of expression is systematically curtailed. Last year I met Badawi's lawyer, Waleed Abu al-Khair in Saudi Arabia. He, too, was sentenced to 15 years in prison. I would recommend that the EU draw up a list of all non-violent political prisoners that it systematically addresses in its talks with the Saudi Government.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. - Saudi Arabia, ladies and gentlemen, is a country that is trying to prove itself diplomatically. It will be on the UN Human Rights Council until 2016 and prides itself on making an important contribution to the global fight against terrorism. Saudi Arabia can gain by explicitly turning away from the practices of Islamic State. Many Muslims do not find themselves in the extremist elements that are getting more and more attention in the media. A first step towards renewal in the 'land of the two holy mosques' could give the Debate on Islam a new dynamic. Because today, beneath the surface of oil dollars, there is still a cruel system under the surface of oil dollars. This ranges from corporal punishment for the least offence, such as being open to discussion with other religions, to publicly beheading people. In this game, Raïf Badawi is the innocent victim of a country that is internationally modern, but is internally in a dark, medieval transition period. I hope that Europe can be united and make it clear to Saudi Arabia that it cannot possibly be part of the UN Human Rights Council without also being committed at home. Raïf Badawi does not belong in prison, but in a discussion panel!

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. - Mr President, Saudi Arabian liberal blogger Raïf Badawi was deemed medically incapable of enduring the remaining punishment of 1 000 lashes after receiving 50, and we needed no doctors’ reports or doctors’ assessments to confirm the barbaric nature of such corporal punishment which goes against UN Conventions that the Saudi Arabian authorities have themselves signed up to. In light of the broader human rights violations in Saudi Arabia that impact all citizens, but especially women and critics of the political system, its membership of the UN Human Rights Council frankly, and we can say it right here, is a farce.  Sadly, also in this House it is difficult to speak out jointly on the violations of human rights in Saudi Arabia and I urge all Members of the European People’s Party Group to support the joint motion for a resolution that the other political groups have put forward. These blatant violations of Raïf Badawi’s rights must be jointly condemned and I think it is high time to rethink the sense of our relationship to Saudi Arabia.  It is not a credible actor and ally in fighting Islamic State when it has not only exported for decades the fundamentalist Islamist views that this ideology is also based on, but also applies the same brutal violence, as an ordinary everyday punishment, that we condemn so strongly when the so-called Islamic State terrorist group applies the same.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Raïf Badawi, blogger and founder of Free Saudi Liberals, cannot stand any more lashes. We all agree on this, and so the point of this resolution, first and then, is to call on the Saudi authorities to stop this condemnation and to release Raïf Badawi. But this must give rise to a somewhat broader reflection of our love for petrodollars and our relations with Saudi Arabia. We are faced with constant and perpetrated violations of international law and human rights, which mean that a hypocritical situation is created when it comes to the fight against terrorism, even with regard to a country that is an ally of the West. How can we combat ISIS practices when we consider a friend a country that imposes corporal punishment on those who do freedom of information or those who oppose or criticise religion? That is the reflection.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Author. - Mr President, I would like to express our absolute condemnation of raif Badawi's treatment: ten years in prison and to receive a thousand lashes just for pointing to the clergy through satire; We also condemn Saudi Arabia's death penalty and oppression of women. That is why I cannot help but be dismayed by the position of Western leaders in the face of the recent death of the satrapa. According to Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose moral standards go for a walk every time we have to talk about Greek debt, King Abdullah "gave himself and his country respect and recognition" with "wisdom, height of sight and great dedication"; David Cameron showed his excitement and deep sadness at "the death of the guardian of sacred mosques"; Barack Obama, leader of the free world, expressed his personal condolences and sympathy. I must condemn the double standards of this European Union, so strong with the weak and submissive and hypocritical with the powerful. Like this satrapy, which, in addition to boosting Islam's worst rigorism, supports fundamentalist terrorist groups.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank The judges who sentenced blogger Raif Badawi to ten years in prison, a fine and a thousand lashes in Jeddah in May last year probably had no idea what they would trigger. It was one of many verdicts against critical Saudi citizens who do nothing but express their opinions freely. But this case has attracted global public opinion, and since then the whole world has known that saudi arabia is using cruel corporal punishments such as beheadings as a deterrent and floggings. All things that, when carried out by a terrorist organisation, are rightly condemned as a despicable crime. We must not apply double standards. Even a state with which we cooperate intensively on economic issues and with which we also associate certain security interests must not in any way use methods that are in stark contrast to human rights. Stability in the region is not assured by looking the other way. We can achieve real stability only through democratic conditions and a judicial system that complies with human rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: question raised by raising the blue card. – Honourable colleague, in your implementation, you mentioned the difficulties that we have in the European Parliament and in the european Union's entire approach to the issue of respect for human rights and our attitude towards countries where human rights are being violated. This is not only happening in Saudi Arabia, it is also happening in Israel, it is happening in Morocco, it is happening in some countries that we have for friendly countries and we even have different agreements with them. Do you not think it is time to speak seriously in this House, too, about how much we care about human rights, and how do we intend to show this in our attitudes towards these countries that are violating them?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. - (DE) Mr President, I can only agree with you on this. I believe that human rights in themselves are a topos of their own and that you must not link them to other things. It is not acceptable for political considerations to make the problem particularly clear in one case and not in the other. Human rights are above political interests and must be discussed in this way.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. - Mr President, the EPP calls on the authorities of Saudi Arabia to annul the flogging of Raïf Badawi and the application of the other sanctions. Freedom of expression cannot be punished. Our group has not signed the resolution agreed by the other colleagues, the key reason is that the joint resolution puts Saudi Arabia and The Islamic State on an equal footing in one paragraph. It's an error. All the more so since a delegation of the European Parliament leaves for Riad tomorrow. I wonder, are our colleagues going to Islamic State? I conclude by saying that we regret the fact that two of the proposals made by the PPE Group to discuss here in the emergency, namely, the case of Nadia Savchenko and, respectively, the case of the Crimean Tatars who are currently condemned by Moscow, have not been taken into account and have been considered irrelevant.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the case of Raïf Badawi deserves serious attention. Everybody must be alarmed by the heavy prison sentence he was given for his activities while monitoring human rights in his country. However, the decision to administer 1 000 lashes to him is barbaric and equals a death sentence. Saudi Arabia has ratified the UN Convention against Torture, under which corporal punishments are prohibited. I very much hope that this debate will convey a convincing message to the Saudi authorities that they should cancel the lashing verdict, review the accusations against Mr Badawi and provide conditions of humane treatment for him. We welcome, at the same time, the judicial reforms that have started already in Saudi Arabia, and I encourage the new King to do his utmost to guarantee the protection of individual citizens’ rights and safety.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, flogging is torture. Torture is human rights abuse. Blogging is free expression. Freedom of expression curtailed is human rights abuse. Each of the one thousand lashes against Raif Badawi is human rights abuse: abuse in which we must all feel the pain, and we must all act. Raif’s wife, Ensaf Haider, told us personally that his suffering is so great that he cannot speak about it and the only words that he can utter are distress at the impact on his children. She asked us to ask for a pardon but at the same time, Commissioner, for him to leave the country and to join their family. Today we do so. When the European Union announced, on Monday, cooperation with Saudi Arabia on countering terrorism, we have to remember that the Saudis have called Raif a terrorist. If Europe’s cooperation with Saudi Arabia is to mean anything, we have to use it to free Raif. Free Raif. Free Raif.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It has been pointed out that the Badawi case is typical of Saudi Arabia. However, as a long-standing member of Amnesty International, I would also like to point out that this case is typical of Islam. Islam is always distinguished from Islamism. This is as if one were to distinguish the socialists from socialism or capital from capitalism. I can tell you today that of the 57 Islamic countries in at least 55 countries, human rights are being trampled underfoot; for example, women and girls are treated much worse than boys and men. Most of the victims are Muslims. That is why it is right that we should also deal with human rights violations in all Islamic countries here in Parliament. Mr Weidenholzer is absolutely right: we should not apply double standards here.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is tragic and unbearable about the cruel treatment of Mr Badaoui is that this is not an isolated case or a smear that is attributable to overzealous repressive services. What is tragic and unbearable is that it is a system. Worse still, this system is a legal system, developed, built and implemented by the institutions of a country that we consider an allied country. What is tragic and unbearable about the punishment inflicted on Mr. Badaoui is not only the brutality of the beatings inflicted on him, but that these blows are given to him for apostasy, that is, for insulting Islam, even though he was simply using the internet to fuel a democratic debate. What is tragic and unbearable about the brutality of the punishment inflicted on Mr. Badaoui is that there is, in essence, no difference in nature between certain savage practices of the "Islamic State" group, which we are bombing, and certain wild but legal practices of Saudi Arabia, which we are sparing. That is why I support this resolution and I ask all colleagues to support it.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think it is useful to remember in this House that our duty is to the people of a region, a country, a state, and not necessarily the present regime in charge of it. We have seen how quickly that can change. I count myself as a friend of Saudi Arabia – I grew up in Riyadh, I have many happy memories of my time within the country. And it is precisely that friendship and our values that oblige us to be true to our values and to be vocal about the systematic deliberate and widespread human rights abuses going on within that country. Raïf Badawi – and I thank Amnesty Scotland for their work on his behalf – is emblematic, and that is precisely the point. He is important because the Saudi authorities chose to make him important: they chose to make an example of him. It is right that we should react to his plight. But there are thousands of others, and this resolution is for all of them. I would end with a plea to our Member States. As Mr Howitt rightly said, if our cooperation is to mean anything, we must be true to our values. My plea to the Member States – not least my own, the United Kingdom – is that if we think a little bit less about arms sales and a little bit more about our values, we might be taken more seriously.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ten years in prison and a thousand lashes for a political, social and religious debate, fifteen years for a lawyer for playing his role as a defender of human rights. What criminal system is the one in which fifty lashes are inflicted and cared for for another nine hundred and fifty? This is a slow and painful death sentence.  There is no justification or political calculation that would allow us to ignore this barbarity. Saudi Arabia, if it is a partner, must respect and listen to us and must absolutely release all those who are unjustly detained for their opinions, democracy and dialogue, it must reform its criminal justice system and turn it into a re-education system.
