Ladies and gentlemen, the conscience of this Parliament cannot be chameleon-like with Arabia and with so many other countries, as so many of you have said before, because human rights are a categorical imperative for us. We cannot sell our principles as much per barrel of oil, because every lash inflicted on Badawi is a lash inflicted on our consciences as parliamentarians and as representatives of the whole of Europe. We owe it to Raïf and all the other Raïfs held in Saudi Arabia. We must use every instrument in our power and all groups must be united in this respect. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – In fact, Mr Castaldo, you know, after what happened in Paris – I mean the terrorist attacks in Paris against Charlie Hebdo – the Saudi Ambassador in France attended the rally, with all the personalities, in support of Charlie Hebdo and to send a strong anti-terrorism message. At the same time, if all those things were to happen in Saudi Arabia, with a newspaper like Charlie Hebdo in Saudi Arabia, there would of course be a punishment for apostasy, maybe the death penalty, a thousand lashes and so on and so forth.  Not far away, a new movement has been started: ‘Je suis Raif’. Do you not think that we should promote ‘Je suis Raif’ within this Parliament, like ‘Je suis Charlie’?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. My dear colleague, I fully agree with you: we must not accept hypocritical endorsements. If terrorism is to be combated, it must also be demonstrated by applying principles and completely detaching itself from the barbarity of these practices. Just as our allies and partners must not have double standards, we must not have them either and, yes, from my point of view 'Je suis absolument Raïf tous les jours'.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, gan dabht ar bith is cás truamhéalach é seo mar ar láimh amháin tá gaol maith againn le Ríocht na hAraibe Sádaí. Tá a lán dul chun cinn déanta ag an ríocht sin agus, mar shampla, tá níos mó daoine a úsáideann Twitter san Araib Shádach ná in aon áit eile sa Mheánoirthear. Ach ar an láimh eile, tarlaíonn a leithéid seo: buillí uafásacha ar dhroim duine sa lá atá inniu ann mar thaispeántas poiblí. Ní féidir cur suas leis seo. I ndáiríre, tá sé ag déanamh saghas spóirt de, spórt reiligiúin mar tá sé ag tarlú os comhair mosc agus dá bhrí sin ba chóir dúinn gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun brú a chur ar údarás Ríocht na hAraibe Sádaí deireadh a chur leis an nós aineolach, barbarach, meánaoiseach seo agus Raif Badawi a ligean saor.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, Saudi Arabia, partner country; Raif Badawi, blogger: ten years in prison, a thousand lashes, torture and death. International organizations mobilized for their freedom. And this Parliament is going to be unable to send a common message because the People's Party did not want to vote with us, to sign this resolution with us. That's salt for Badawi's wounds. We hope that they will reconsider, as we hope that heads of state and government, ministers, ambassadors, diplomats and businessmen traveling to Saudi Arabia will have some time to discuss Badawi's case. We hope that in these large portfolios, full of geostrategic and economic interests, they will have a small space to talk about human rights, to ask for Badawi's freedom, for leniency, Mr President. If we don't have that, the European Union will have been silent.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this debate on Saudi Arabia is a good opportunity to ask real questions. First of all, do we find it normal that this country is almost never mentioned in our urgent files, when it would have deserved to be mentioned on many occasions? First, there is the blogger journalist Raïf Badaoui, who is mobilizing our attention today, sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1000 lashes for simply doing his job as a journalist. Secondly, I would like to underline the words of the President of the IMF, Mrs Lagarde, who mourns the death of the king by referring, and I quote, "the death of a man who has done a lot for women". It's not humor. We can be sure that Saudi women, in general, will appreciate, just like this Burmese decapitated in the street in front of officers who remained almost passive, or these two women in prison for several years for daring to drive a car. You can hear a car! For Raif Badaoui, but also for all those men and women who have no other wrong but to claim their rights, we owe it to ourselves to denounce these injustices. One cannot be Charlie for the time of an interview or a media moment, and then opt for "I am petrodollar", in defiance of freedom of expression or human rights, in an absolute cynicism.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his I am very pleased that we have found here a large majority of six groups calling for the unconditional and immediate release of Raif Badawi. Because flogging is execution on instalments! Ten years in prison for freedom of expression is also a barbaric punishment that we cannot simply accept. I am very surprised why the European People's Party is not taking part in this broad consensus, in this solidarity with Raif Badawi. Why do you think so? Are economic relations and oil really more important to you than the fight against barbaric human rights violations? I think that must be the case. I criticise this massive lack of solidarity here and Am really glad that we have managed together – without the European People's Party, which is not standing by our side here – to condemn these floggings and also to call clearly for immediate release. Let me say a sentence with an Austrian connection: we are still waiting for the Abdullah Centre in Vienna to finally demand unconditional release and to condemn this barbaric punishment clearly and clearly. Free Raif Badawi! Now!

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for the attention devoted by this House to supporting the universality of human rights throughout the world. Saudi Arabia is an important partner for the European Union and an influential political, economic, cultural and religious actor in the Middle East and in the Islamic world. Like many in Europe, we have been concerned by the punishment imposed on Mr Badawi by a Saudi court of appeal in September last year, and by the public flogging to which he was subjected on 9 January this year. We have been closely following developments related to his case as well as the overall human rights situation in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. There is no doubt that the basis and conditions of Mr Badawi’s sentence, as well as the nature of the punishment handed down to him, are matters of strong concern for the European Union. In addition, the sentence appears overtly disproportionate. The statement issued by the spokesperson for the Vice-President of the Commission and  January, recalling our principled position on this case, is one of many initiatives that we are taking at EU level. The European External Action Service has been constantly monitoring this case, including via the EU delegation in Riyadh. In close coordination with EU Member States, several formal and informal outreach initiatives towards the Saudi authorities have been undertaken, both in capitals and locally. Since the first set of 50 lashes on 9 January, further lashing has been suspended on health grounds. This is certainly a positive development and it is to be hoped that further execution of the sentence will be definitely suspended. Obviously we will continue to call on our Saudi partners to suspend this sentence and to review the court ruling, as we understand the case may soon be referred again to an appeal court. More broadly, we look forward to strengthening an open and frank dialogue on human rights with our Saudi partners, seizing, in particular, the opportunity offered by the ongoing judicial reform process. The abolition of corporal and degrading punishment and the broader issue of freedom of expression will continue to constitute essential elements in our dialogue. Let me once again assure you that we will continue to follow closely the case of Mr Badawi and to voice the European Union’s concerns through appropriate channels.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place after the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – I strongly support the principle of this resolution. No-one should be punished for exercising their freedom of speech. Furthermore, a sentence of 10 years’ imprisonment and 1000 lashes is particularly cruel and disproportionate. I note that Raif Badawi has various health conditions which lead to specific concerns. I have seen the text of the joint motion for a resolution. The choice of words is not ideal in some places, but the sentiment is absolutely correct. I believe that pressure must be brought to bear upon the Saudi authorities.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Freedom of speech is a pillar of democracy, and the extent to which a citizen is free to express his or her opinion helps us identify to what extent our governments respect their citizens. Societies which advocate better freedom of speech have proven to be more engaged, vibrant and exuberant about being active citizens. In 1927 Justice Louis Brandeis put it perfectly when he said that the ‘freedom to think as you will and to speak as you think are means indispensable to the discovery and spread of political truth’. To censor our citizens from their democratic and fundamental right to speak their minds is nothing more than an injustice to democracy. But the case of Raif Badawi goes beyond this. The flogging of Raif Badawi is intolerable and any form of corporal punishment must be gravely condemned by the international community. Today the Parliament stands with Mr Badawi. We shall not remain passive in the face of your fight for freedom.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. – I and my fellow MEPs have strongly condemned the flogging of blogger Raif Badawi by the Saudi Arabian authorities. This is a shocking act and an assault by the Saudi authorities against the freedom of expression. I am calling on the Saudi Government to release Mr Badawi immediately and to quash his conviction and sentence.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. In Saudi Arabia, Raif Badaoui, a Saudi blogger, was sentenced to ten years in prison in November 2014, fined 1,000 riyals (22,5000 euros) and lashes 1,000 for allegedly "insulting Islam". He is said to have committed apostasy by claiming that "Muslims, Christians, Jews and atheists are all equal". He escaped an assassination attempt and his wife and children were forced into exile in Canada as political refugees.  His judgment was unanimously challenged by some organizations, including Amnesty International, as "disgracefully inhumane," and many called for his cancellation, such as the United States and the European Union. Flogging is prohibited by international law and can be considered a practice of another age. Although attached to the principle of non-interference, I cannot remain insensitive to this event. The principle of non-interference should not make us forget that Saudi Arabia has privileged relations with many European Union countries, including France, and that it is suspected of having troubled relations with terrorist organisations.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. – I am fundamentally opposed to the imprisonment and torture of people for expressing their views. I abstained because this is not a clean declaration of the release of jailed blogger Badawi, but practically a call for a deterioration in relations with the state of Saudi Arabia. The resolution likens Saudi Arabia to the Islamic State, which I consider an unnecessary provocation. It also calls on EU states to reconsider their relations with Saudi Arabia, while being cautious as they depend on it for energy. That seems like completely opposite thoughts to me.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. – The case of Raif Badawi in Saudi Arabia is an eloquent example of non-compliance with fundamental human rights. I can't comment on his sentence any other way. The European Union and the Member States are founded on universal values and in alienating human rights. In our relations with the rest of the world, we affirm and promote these values, seeking to achieve the protection of human rights and strict adherence to international law. I agree that the European Parliament must exert all the political pressure it is capable of reviewing the verdict in this one, as in other similar cases. However, I cannot agree with the references to the so-called " Islamic State and al-Qaeda in the joint declaration adopted today in plenary. The setting of a sign of equality between Saudi Arabia and the so-called Islamic State "Islamic State" is a gross mistake that I will not participate in. I support my colleagues in the EPP group who voted against. Saudi Arabia is an important partner of the EU in the Middle East and an influential political, economic and cultural leader in the Islamic world. Dialogue between the EU and Saudi Arabia must be conducted in a constructive manner. Only in this way would we achieve good results for respect for human rights and for reforms in the Kingdom.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Let me make a few written comments on the final passages of the present motion for a resolution. First of all, I would like to stress that Saudi Arabia, with its official standing religion, subscribes to a radical, one might say fundamentalist religious group. Meanwhile, fundamentalists of any faith – whether Christians, Muslims, Jews, or Hindus – are an intolerant component in a society that has always and everywhere had major problems with democratic rules. Saudi-born fundamentalism, known as Wahhabism or, correctly, Salafiya, is a Sunni sect that fights against all nonbelievers – including other branches of Islam, not just Shiites. I remind you that there are a number of links to Al Qaeda from the Wahhabi, and abu bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of the self-called Islamic State, also subscribes to this seed. In this way, Wahhabism becomes one of the biggest problems of our time. Both in the Muslim world and in liberal democracies. Discussing respect for human rights in a country where fundamentalist sectarianism is the official religion is almost a waste of time. Clear demands must be made both towards our Saudi arabian partners and against the leadership of the European Parliament and the European Commission. Cooperation cannot be expanded on any level until there is greater understanding of other views in this country, for women's equality, for opposition to the upbringing and training of fundamentalist fighters.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Mass Graves of Missing Persons in Ashia, located in The Village of Ornithi in the occupied part of Cyprus (2015/2551(RSP)). As we are late I will ask your permission not to allow blue cards and also to skip the catch the eye procedure so that we can vote in light of today's special requirements.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank The issue of persons missing in 2001, both of Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot origin, is an open wound for the families who want certainty at last, but also for the peace process in Cyprus. The Committee for the Missing Persons makes an invaluable contribution here by interviewing witnesses, finding mass graves and returning the identity of the dead. There is an urgent need for access to all areas of Cyprus in order to be able to continue its work. The Committee also needs the constant support of the European Union, both financially and politically. In this context, I do not understand why only nine Member States have signed the UN Convention on the Protection against Forced Disappearances. The Member States should finally send out a strong signal against this serious violation of human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Author. - Mr President, the tragedy of the families of the missing persons of Cyprus has literally shocked us all from our youth. Thousands of Greek Cypriots have been missing for 41 years, when in July 1974 Turkish troops illegally invaded Cyprus and occupied 37% of the island. All these missing persons were murdered by Turkish occupation troops and buried in mass graves in areas described as "military", in order to disappear their tracks. But also when mass graves are found by the efforts of the Committee of Missing Persons, as is the case of the mass grave of the missing assia, discovered in the village of Ornithi, and then the Turkish troops try again to wipe out the traces. The UN resolutions on Cypriot missing persons are dozens. Turkey is also the conviction of the European Court of Human Rights. We therefore call for the resolution on the missing persons of Cyprus and Asia to be accepted, calling on the Turkish army and Turkey ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Author. - (C) In the Greek tragedy Antigone,which was written by Sophocles already 442 f. Kr, described how a girl does everything to bury her brother. The theme is eternal, as old as human life on earth. Those we love, we want to do everything for, including bringing them to the last rest.  Today's tragedy takes place today in Cyprus where mothers and fathers, brothers and sisters, like Antigone, are doing everything they can to bury their loved ones whose fate has been unknown since 1974. It is now time for the Turkish authorities to allow mass graves in military territory to be opened so that they can be examined, so that identification can take place and people can finally mourn their loved ones, bring them to the last rest and finally come to rest.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the families of the approximately 2 000 people who disappeared in Cyprus from 1964 to 1974 have every right to know what happened to their loved ones, especially since many of them are elderly people and are in danger of dying without even knowing what happened. Putting a point and closing this story is necessary to continue, to put a stone on this issue and to be able to continue the process of reconciliation on the island of Cyprus. The Committee on Missing Persons in Cyprus is doing an excellent job but needs full cooperation from the authorities. The European Union is certainly working together, funding the Committee, but the part that Turkey, which is financed by the European Union with the pre-accession agreements, is missing. So let's go back to a broader discourse. Let us put pressure on the Turkish Government to help clarify this.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Author. - Mr President, for some years now, dozens of Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot scientists, as well as ordinary citizens, have been working to find the bones of the dead of the Cypriot tragedy, and I think this is an act that highlights the human race: that is, working to find the types of history and to trace its steps and the suffering of people and their relatives. That being the case, at the same time it is an act of shame to move and disappear bones from mass graves, an act equivalent, I once thought, to the very act of murder. I therefore think it is right to call on Turkey to put an end to this shameful action, to show us where the burial sites of the missing, the murdered, are and to open its archives, so that the investigative committee can know where it needs to look. Finally, we call on the Council to increase its financial support to the exploratory committee in order to carry out this work as easily as possible. The struggle is a struggle to find the bones of all the dead of the Cypriot tragedy – Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. That is why I have expressed my honour and appreciation to the people, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, who are working in this direction.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank It is an unspoken human right that what is left of a human being after death is treated with respect by the descendants. Antigone, the great heroine of the ancient Greeks, has left us this legacy. It is also a human right for descendants to know where their loved ones have found the last rest and to have free access to this place. They have the right to know what death they have found. That is what this resolution is about. There is an urgent suspicion that these fundamental rights are being violated in Ornithi. This is unacceptable. That is why this resolution is necessary. Only in this way is memory work possible, without which there is no future. Incidentally, a sentence from Antigone's legacy should apply to the work of remembrance: we have become too not to hate, to love!

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Draftsman. - Mr President, Commissioner, a war crime committed in 1974 by the Turkish invading army in Cyprus, with mass executions of undeclared prisoners and civilians, who were buried in mass graves unknown for years in the occupied territories, is coming to light again on the occasion of the tragic case of mass graves found in the village of Ornithi and other areas. In these cases the Turkish army moved the bones of civilians killed from the village of Assia to an unknown place. And only a few remains were found. Bone movements are made to prevent the cause of death of the victims from being determined. That is why we are asking the European Parliament to call on Turkey to stop behaving disrespectfully towards the dead; stop the insult to humanity; stop the movement of the dead from mass graves and open its military archives and so-called "military zones" to investigate and return the dead to their families.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, for forty years Turkey, in violation of every principle of European and international law, has been part of our country, resulting in tragic consequences for both our people and Cyprus and the European Union itself. But the most tragic aspect of this Cypriot drama is the missing persons aspect. The fact that there have been Cypriot missing persons for 40 years is because Turkey, and for this very humanitarian issue, is showing an inhuman and cruel face. He refuses to open the turkish army's archives to investigate their fate. There and where mass graves of missing persons are found, it describes them as a "closed military area". And most importantly, and most importantly, and the most obscene, is that he moves the bones of missing persons, as happened in Assia, to wipe out the tracks. Unfortunately, this is Turkey. This is Turkey that does not respect the dead. This is Turkey, which basically wants to become a Member State of the European Union. This is Turkey, which is receiving pre-accession aid. We call for sanctions to be imposed against Turkey on this issue.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: On behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, human drama does not distinguish between races and ethnic origins. What is happening now in the occupied part of Cyprus is a second crime against all mankind, since, 40 years later, turkey's occupying regime is moving the bones of the missing trying to wipe out elements that would lead to their detection. Think of the relatives of the missing wondering what happened to their own people. Consider burying a piece of the finger or a piece of their foot. Europe cannot close its eyes and we must immediately call on Turkey to cooperate in fully investigating the fate of the missing, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. There's no political game here. The honor of the dead is the holiest in Europe. Europe cannot pretend to serve political purposes.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in 2011 I co-authored a successful written declaration concerning the work of the EU-funded Committee on Missing Persons (CMP) in Cyprus. Today our resolution seeks to make a further specific plea related to the issue of the four mass graves in Ashia / Ornithi village, where it is believed that the graves of 106 individuals brutally murdered in 1974 during the invasion by Turkey have been tampered with and some of the human remains exhumed and destroyed or relocated in a probable criminal attempt to conceal evidence.  Turkey, under numerous judgments of the ECHR, as the occupying power in the north of Cyprus, is obliged to assist the CMP to identify all the  remaining skeletal parts in order to establish clearly the cause of death. This would allow the families, after 41 years, to have closure regarding the painful loss of their loved ones. Turkey must also open access to the military-controlled areas in the north of the island to locate all the burial sites, and once identity is … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, there are many similarities between Cyprus and Ireland: both are island nations that suffer from the legacy of partition, foreign occupation and conflict. Therefore, truth and reconciliation is as important to Cyprus as it is in Ireland. The European Court of Human Rights, in its judgment with regard to missing persons in Cyprus, held that the Turkish authorities failed to conduct an effective investigation, in violation of Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights. Similarly, the British Government also continues to violate Article 2 in relation to state killings in the north of Ireland, for example with regard to its involvement in the murder of the brilliant 39-year-old lawyer Pat Finucane, the 26th anniversary of whose death occurs today. For reconciliation to take place in Cyprus, Turkey must reveal the truth about the missing people and in relation to the further crime of the relocation of victims’ remains by the Turkish authorities. An effective investigation into this by ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many bodies can be buried in a mass grave, but how deep does a pit have to be to bury the history of the victims and the responsibilities of a terrifying conflict that is not yet over? Too deep! For each of Ashia's victims, for each of the more than 2,000 missing from the war in Cyprus, there are still families desperate for a sentence that has become an integral part of their lives. A penalty that may perhaps be partially soothed by an answer, however belated, and by the remains of the relatives finally returned. That is why Turkey must immediately implement the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights and all the parties involved must contribute to the work of the Committee by opening their archives and giving their testimonies. A candidate state must demand maximum cooperation and maximum commitment, not prolonged and shameful silence. It's never too late to make up for a mistake.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, the dramatic case of the Mass graves of Ornithi is the tree that hides the forest, it is the macabre face of a larger operation: the occupation of Cyprus for 41 years by Turkey.  The Turkish state is guilty, but it also has accomplices - those who have chosen to start accession negotiations for almost a decade now. I'm thinking of Mr.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I, also in this tourism, would like to point out that, according to the ruling of the European Court of Human Rights, Turkey has harmed the rights of relatives and the missing. Nor has it yet paid any compensation that turkey has been ordered to pay by the European Court of Human Rights. Indeed, I consider Turkey's actions to be scandalous. It is not possible to voluntarily sign the European Convention on Human Rights and submit to the Strasbourg judgment, while refusing to accept the existence of Cyprus to pay compensation granted to the victims of this injustice. And I think that the European Union is paying Turkey enough aid to pay any compensation directly to these victims if Turkey does not respect the European Court of Human Rights in this way. I'm really upset.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking As a result of internal fighting in the 1960s and the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, some two thousand people of Greek and Turkish origin were reported missing. Their fate is still being tried by the Missing Persons Committee in Cyprus. In 1974, the Turkish military murdered nearly 100 civilians near the village of Ashia. The European Court of Human Rights has held Turkey responsible for these murders. Greek Cypriots loudly demand that Turkey be held accountable. Turkey refuses to cooperate and prevents access to places where the remains of the missing may be hidden.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab We must openly call for more action to be taken against those who can help the Cypriots to resolve this tragedy, this tragic dispute. There are still relatives of the missing and murdered who are waiting to burie the remains of their loved ones. Let us leave the guilty to the courts and tribunals of war. Let us demand that both sides of this conflict be granted the right to find (...). (The President has taken the vote of the Member)

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: The Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 and the continued occupation of 40% of the island are in themselves major violations of international law, for which Turkey has been repeatedly condemned by the European Court of Human Rights. This major violation was accompanied by heinous war crimes, such as the mass execution of some 1,600 Greek and Greek Cypriot prisoners, who have been reported missing for 40 years. Not only have these crimes not been recognised and punished, but the Turkish side is engaged in an ongoing effort to cover them up.  One individual incident is the recent transfer of bones from the area of Assia to another unknown area in the occupied territories. It is a disgrace to European political and legal culture that such behaviour is tolerated by a state ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, there can be few greater personal traumas than not knowing the fate of a loved one. The Committee on Missing Persons established 34 years ago has to date identified 568 victims from both communities. In an attempt to bring some degree of closure to relatives, friends and the communities of the 1 433 missing Cypriots from both sides of the island, might I respectfully suggest that the time has come for a fresh approach to this tragic issue.  I believe that Cyprus needs to follow the brave South African example at the end of the apartheid regime by setting up a truly independent truth and reconciliation commission. As time goes by, the important question surrounding the fates and final resting places of so many victims must be addressed. Might this be an option worth investigating through the usual diplomatic channels whilst those witnesses are still able to give answers ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, these may be Greek letters printed simply on paper. But in reality these names correspond to men who were fathers, grandparents, sons and grandsons. Most of them come from Asia. Assia and its inhabitants were caught in the eye of the cyclone and the barbarity of the Turkish troops. Innocent civilians are executed in cold blood in the early hours. After completing the prisoner exchange in the following months, 84 people never returned. All war crimes committed by Turkish occupying troops and their Turkish Cypriot partners – and in particular that committed in occupied Assia – remain unpunished to this day. The Turks, in order to cover up their crimes, did not even respect the dead Assians. They moved the bones from the mass graves and threw them into wells and garbage dumps so they could never be found. As is already known, the exhumations carried out in 2009 by the IA in Ornithi confirmed the information. The problems that arise ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, Vice-President/High Representative Federica Mogherini has asked me to deliver the following message on her behalf. The Commission is conscious of the human dimension of the consequences of the tragic events of 1963-1964 and 1974 for the population throughout the island of Cyprus. Unanswered questions, especially those about missing persons, prevent many Cypriots from both communities from leaving their painful past behind. For the families concerned it is thus crucial to determine the fate of their loved ones. For this reason, the Commission is fully committed to supporting the work of the UN-facilitated bi-communal Committee on Missing Persons (CMP). The Committee on Missing Persons’ humanitarian mandate contributes to providing relief to the families of missing persons. It has proved to be a successful confidence-building measure between both Cypriot communities, and thus also strongly contributes to reconciliation in Cyprus. The European Union is currently its main source of funding, with an overall contribution since 2006 of EUR 14.7 million, managed under the authority of my colleague, Corina Crețu. The European Union is committed to continuing to support the work of the CMP and will provide an additional EUR 2.5 million in 2015. We also wanted to thank this Parliament, which in the past years provided extra funding for the CMP. In this respect I would like to pay my personal homage to former Members Panayiotis Demetriou, Ioannis Kasoulides, Klamt and Busuttil, as well as to current Members Böge, Theocharous and Hadjigeorgiou. The Commission agrees that more can and should be done by all relevant stakeholders to clarify the fate of all missing persons. At the same time, the fieldwork becomes more difficult, as new information sources are now scarce, and remaining potential graves are less accessible. This is why it is important that the CMP is granted full access to all relevant archives and, of course, military areas. The EU regularly calls on Turkey to comply with this. Missing persons is a humanitarian issue. This, like many other issues, shows the need for a fair, comprehensive and viable settlement between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities. The EU has given its strong support to the resumption of Cyprus talks under the auspices of the United Nations. We have made clear our readiness to help. We support the efforts of the UN envoy Espen Barth Eide. It is time to find an adequate answer and to give support to both communities.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place immediately after the debates today.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as has also been mentioned in this House and in yesterday's debate, 300 people died yesterday off Lampedusa. It is yet another massacre in the Mediterranean. I call on this Parliament not only to have a minute's silence, but for this Parliament finally to take responsibility for changing policies on the subject of immigration, such as Triton and Frontex, which are described as totally inadequate even by the High Commissioner for Human Rights. I would ask that, in order to remember these people who were looking for a better life, a minute's silence should be observed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: In light of yesterday's statement, I propose that we hold a moment of silence. (The assembly stood up and held a moment of silence) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The Turkish army has occupied the northern part of Cyprus since 1974. Many abuses have been committed. We must defend the memory of these massacred people and the honour of a people who are members of the European Union. You have only a meagre resolution in the face of these machine guns at the checkpoint separating the island? How can we envisage a constructive discussion with Turkey when, on the one hand, it does not recognise one of the members of the European Union, Cyprus, and, on the other hand, it occupies a part of turkey's territory militarily? Once again, the European Union wallows in legal and political inconsistencies, and shamefully despises some of the citizens who are part of it. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – I voted on this motion for a resolution with concern for the families of missing people in Cyprus. I commend the work of the Committee of Missing Persons of Cyprus. Following their effort, 568 remains have been identified and returned to their families. This effort continues today: 1078 Greek Cypriots and 355 Turkish Cypriots are still missing. In Ashia, evidence of a mass grave previously exhumed by the Turkish Government raises concern. I fear that these acts will prevent thorough examinations of remains. Identifying the missing people of Cyprus must be a priority. We, the European Parliament, call on Turkey’s government to stop the removal of remains and focus all efforts aiding the CMP. We must stand for the humanitarian cause in Cyprus. The work of the CMP will require the cooperation of all parties to bring closure to families of lost people.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: , in writing. In particular, action must be taken to conduct an independent investigation into the fate of all missing persons in Cyprus and to ensure due respect not only for missing persons but also for their family members. Each country must respect human rights standards without reservation and prevent any violations of human rights. The rules of international law and the decisions of the ECtHR must be implemented without delay. In view of the role of the Missing Persons Search Committee, its activities need to be further promoted by facilitating the achievement of the objectives set. In addition, it is essential that Turkey cooperates more closely with stakeholders to address this issue and facilitates the search for undiscovered burial sites, as well as properly fulfilling its international obligations to compensate the families of missing persons without knowledge.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. – Four decades after the invasion and illegal occupation of 30% of Cyprus, Turkey continues to provoke by ignoring all notions of international law. Thousands of our fellow Cypriots do not know where, when and how members of their families were slaughtered. Cypriot fighters, sacrificed to defend their homeland, have remained missing for four decades. Today in Assia, the families of the victims are experiencing utter humiliation, as Turkey moves the remains of their relatives from mass graves to secret areas it describes as military, in order to avoid investigations. Until when, Mr President, will we remain uninvolved in Turkey's provocative attitude, which humiliates the memory of the victims but also the dignity and suffering of their families? At a time when Europe is now called upon to promote democratic ideals throughout the world, it cannot tolerate human rights and international law being violated, openly, on its territory. At a time when Turkey, in its pre-accession process, is receiving so many economic benefits from the European Union, the least it has to do is put an end to this unacceptable practice.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Despite five years of gruesome discovery by the Missing Persons Committee in Cyprus near the village of Ashai, where 70 people were missing in unclear circumstances 30 years ago, too many questions remain unanswered. The traces found, indicating the exhumation and transfer of parts of the bodies, provide clear evidence that Turkey not only does not fulfil its obligation to conduct a thorough investigation in this case, but also seeks to avoid responsibility for the murders committed against the population in 1974.  The values we profess command us to take decisive action to compel the Turkish side to settle with the past. It is our duty to make every effort to ensure that this empty card in the history of the Cypriot-Turkish conflict is finally written down. There can be no permission for actions to conceal the truth. In these difficult times, in the face of many armed conflicts, let this resolution send a signal not only to Turkey, but to the whole world, that the European Union opposes all practices aimed at covering up crimes against civilians. Let us give a clear signal that we do not agree that those responsible for the deaths of innocents should avoid responsibility. Let us show that life, dignity and truth are our highest values.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is voting. (For results and other details of votes: see Minutes)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I would have liked to explain, before the vote on Saudi Arabia, why the EPP Group did not sign the joint resolution. We did not do so simply because, in one paragraph, the authors of this joint resolution reconcile Saudi Arabia with the Islamic State group. Otherwise, as was stated in the debate, we have of course stated in our resolution our clear opposition to the sanctions ed to Raif Badaoui. The only reason for our negative vote on this resolution is therefore that our colleagues have made the connection between Saudi Arabia and the Islamic State group.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, on behalf of the 191 signatories of the proposal for a commission of inquiry on the issue of tax rulings, I would like to draw the attention of the assembly to a point of order.  The President of this Assembly has decided - by his own authority - not to put to a vote the proposal made by 191 signatories of this Assembly, whereas in our opinion the regulation obliges the Conference of Presidents to submit to the votes of this Assembly, with a positive or negative recommendation, the choice belongs to him, the original proposal. I note that this has not been done and we believe that it is a violation of European law, that we reserve the right to sue before the European Court of Justice.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, I attempted to put in an oral explanation of vote with regard to the case of Raïf Badawi. This is a very important matter to us, and normally in this delegation we would not be voting in favour of such motions. But on this occasion we did vote in favour, because the humanitarian issue was so pressing. The difficulty is that, if we are being told we are not allowed to put in an oral explanation of vote, then we are denied the right to tell the people back in the UK why we have done what we have done.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The vote is over.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure that the tax dumping of multinationals is investigated. However, I report the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, not to allow the establishment of an investigative committee to be voted on, when the mandate that would have allowed it is the basis of the special committee. Only one committee of inquiry would have allowed access to classified documentation from the Member States, which would have made it possible to find out the role of some European political figures, such as Commission President Juncker, in relation to tax evasion and avoidance costing European citizens one billion euros per year. The formation of a committee of inquiry was legally justified because the European Commission had not complied with its own directives, which require Member States to transparency in their tax rulings.  The investigation of tax rulings cannot be limited to State aid either, since they are compatible with competition policy if they do not discriminate between companies.  I therefore undertake to consider how to legally require the establishment of an investigative commission.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the establishment of a special committee to investigate extensive allegations of tax fraud and tax evasion by a number of multinational corporations across the European Union and the alleged role of key EU political figures in relation to same. The investigation of such serious practices is unequivocally one of the most critical inquiries of our time. In this regard, I am dissatisfied that the European Parliament did not see fit to proceed with the proposed inquiry committee. An inquiry committee would have possessed the necessary legal powers to ensure that an objective, equitable and unprejudiced decision was reached. It is yet to be explored in full detail as to whether the Special Committee will have the requisite powers to investigate the legal loopholes which it has been maintained were deployed on a mass scale by multinationals across the European Union and aided by senior EU political figures. It was with these reservations in mind, that I provided support to the creation of the Special Committee and both my party and my group will be monitoring this matter very closely.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. — In view of current events (LuxLeaks, SuisseLeaks and the news about Belgian rulings), it seems fair to take up the fight against tax evasion and unfair tax advantages for multinationals. Exchange of data can be useful. If the special committee wishes to limit itself to possible exchange of information and to make recommendations, this can have added value. Certainly also for harmonisation of the internal market. I look forward to the conclusions of the special committee, which has a clear mandate for six months. However, there is a chance, as is characteristic of the ever-expanding powers of the European Union, that we want to have much more flexibility, that we will see a further harmonisation of European tax systems on the table and that any differences between Member States in tax rates or their own national policies to attract companies will be equalised. That has little or nothing to do with the smooth functioning of a single market, but everything with a new EU competence is a path I do not want to go down. I therefore vote in favour of setting up the special committee with the reservations expressed.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — On the occasion of a series of investigations into alleged tax arrangements in favour of multinationals in Luxembourg, Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands, initiated by the European Commission, Parliament voted by a large majority in favour of setting up a special committee. The Committee will examine practices in the field of binding tax information and will examine rules that determine how transparent the practice of tax decisions in EU countries can be. I welcome the establishment of this special committee, because tax justice and tax transparency are essential. The Committee will look at tax regimes in all Member States and put pressure on them to put an end to unfair tax practices and to tackle tax avoidance. This is a fundamental question of justice.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — This tax-based procedure allows private actors to avail themselves of a position of the tax administration on existing standards, following a question raised by them. However, it appears that tax rulings have been widely used in some countries by non-European companies to reduce their tax contribution. This special committee seems to be more focused on monitoring the compliance of states' actions with EU law than on assessing the abuses and excesses of this system. It is therefore an incomplete and unsatisfactory text in terms of the stakes, but it is a first step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I oppose this measure; it is not possible in six months to undertake a detailed study in all 28 Member States. This spends taxpayersʼ money and will serve to distract from the issues surrounding Mr Juncker. I suspect this also to be a precursor to an attempt to harmonise corporation tax.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. —I, of course, voted in favour of the establishment of this special committee to shed light on the tax rulings, in the aftermath of the so-called "Luxleaks" affair, which Jean-Claude Juncker mistakenly believes to have stifled.  In this committee, I will be able to count on several colleagues whose probity and competence give us hope for real results.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. " Following the revelations of the Luxleaks affair and then Swissleaks, it was essential that the European Parliament reacted. Indeed, Europeans rightly expect fairer taxation. This special commission on tax rulings will establish full transparency in this area. Having been appointed by my group as an effective member, I will fully commit myself to making the practices as clear as they can ongoing practices. I hope that, thanks to this committee and the work undertaken by the European Parliament, we will be able to achieve at European level a tax harmonisation for corporate taxes with, for example, the definition of a common taxable base and a minimum rate to be defined, ensuring that it is not a floor rate. Moreover, recent events show that it is time to combat money laundering, which is a global source of terrorist financing. My priorities in this area are the fight against tax evasion and evasion and the introduction of a capital tax.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures, since, although it is not a commission of inquiry, the establishment of such a commission is already a step forward for tax transparency in the Union. In the wake of the "LuxLeaks" scandal involving Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and the arrangements offered by Luxembourg allowing 340 multinationals to evade a large part of their taxes, particularly in France and Europe, I also regret that this decision does not make explicit reference to Luxembourg.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this text, which I consider to be balanced and well structured. I consider it of the utmost importance to set up a special committee whose task is to shed light on the scandal of tax preferences granted by the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg to certain multinationals and large companies.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted to set up a special committee. This is despite the fact that the proposal is far from what I would have liked to see. Instead of a special parliamentary inquiry into LuxLeaks with a far-reaching mandate, we now have something much toothless; a special committee, which does not have the same powers, nor a mandate that is sufficiently thorough. This is the result of an agreement between the large Groups S&D and EPP. They clearly want to avoid any political consequences following the revelations of the massive tax evasion policy for which Juncker, as Prime Minister of Luxembourg, was responsible, and still defends.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, created following the LuxLeaks case and which, within a maximum period of one year, must submit its proposals to build a true tax union and end tax havens, tax evasion, privileges and fraudulent tax competition in the EU. The commitment of the Spanish Socialists is to end banking secrecy, get companies to pay the taxes where they generate their profits and create a common corporation tax for the EU.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution by which Parliament sets up a special committee to work for the next six months to examine the way in which the Union's state aid rules have been applied since 1991 and the decisions taken by the Member States in the field of taxation. The so-called 'Luxleaks' has turned the spotlight on aggressively facilitated fiscal policies implemented by several Member States, including Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Ireland and Belgium. It is necessary to analyse carefully what has happened and, above all, to make proposals so that these events do not happen again. It is clear that fiscal policies are an area on which, by applying highly facilitated planning that is considerably removed from the parameters of the rest of the European Union, not only is unfair competition with the other Member States exercised, but there are highly distorting effects on the Union's public finances, and I would add that the Union's own sense of cohesion is being put into practice. The committee that is being set up today will enable Parliament to make its contribution to the work that the European Commission has put in place in recent months. Transparency on fiscal policies is a prerequisite for a stronger and more authoritative Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — I support the establishment of a special committee on tax rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect. Respect for tax practice is an important prerequisite for a healthy economy.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. A few weeks ago, Mr Juncker was standing before this House as a herald of the fight against tax evasion. The man who transformed the economy of a country focused on declining industries into a hub of optimization/tax evasion is now a champion in the fight against tax evasion. The forces of less-so-called harmonization carefully refrain from touching taxation, a rare un harmonised area. Yesterday the "Luxleaks", today the former Belgian socialist administration would have granted surreal advantages to multinationals, by tax oppressing the small ones. Their liberal successors continued recently, in Davos, to extol the charms of the flat country to the powerful of the planet. We are far from the "healthy" competition the Commission wants. In fact, is tax competition between countries using the same currency appropriate? It is high time to look at these practices. But the people are scolding and you only have a ridiculous commission like "brioche". She won't save you. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the establishment of a Special Committee to investigate extensive allegations of tax fraud and tax evasion by a number of multinational corporations across the European Union and the alleged role of key EU political figures in relation to same. The investigation of such serious practices is unequivocally one of the most critical inquiries of our time.  In this regard, I am dissatisfied that the European Parliament did not see fit to proceed with the proposed inquiry committee. An inquiry committee would have possessed the necessary legal powers to ensure that an objective, equitable and unprejudiced decision was reached. It is yet to be explored in full detail as to whether the Special Committee will have the requisite powers to investigate the legal loopholes which it has been maintained were deployed on a mass scale by multinationals across the European Union and aided by senior EU political figures.  It was with these reservations in mind, that I provided support to the creation of the Special Committee and both my party and my group will be monitoring this matter very closely.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I consider that this committee could be very important for the decisions on fiscal policies.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. We need to shed light on the tax preferences granted by Luxembourg to the large industrial and banking groups and on the role played in this operation by the current President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted in favour of a special committee on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect. I have been appointed to this committee. I believe that the differences between the European Union states in terms of taxation maintain unfair internal competition within the Union which is bad for the European economy. A single currency and a single market cannot co-exist with 28 national tax policies that go in different directions. This committee will be chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure. I will propose a roadmap to end tax dumping in Europe. In the context of globalisation, European countries must understand that their interest is not in ever more competition with each other, but in more cohesion. This is a major political issue for the European Union. I voted in favour of setting up this special committee.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the establishment of a Special Committee to investigate extensive allegations of tax fraud and tax evasion by a number of multinational corporations across the European Union and the alleged role of key EU political figures in relation to same. The investigation of such serious practices is unequivocally one of the most critical inquiries of our time.  In this regard, I am dissatisfied that the European Parliament did not see fit to proceed with the proposed inquiry committee. An inquiry committee would have possessed the necessary legal powers to ensure that an objective, equitable and unprejudiced decision was reached. It is yet to be explored in full detail as to whether the Special Committee will have the requisite powers to investigate the legal loopholes which it has been maintained were deployed on a mass scale by multinationals across the European Union and aided by senior EU political figures.  It was with these reservations in mind, that I provided support to the creation of the Special Committee and both my party and my group will be monitoring this matter very closely.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) We are in favour of setting up a special committee on tax agreements within the Territory of the Union. The extension of the scope of inquiry over a period of twenty-four years prior to the creation of the committee will be crucial in establishing good tax practices between Member States, with the hope that the problem of tax evasion can be addressed. Scandals such as the one involving HSBC bank lately must not be repeated, revealing a total of $100 billion stolen from tax agencies.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. — A good initiative to ensure the legal security of the taxpayer. The patriotic Members, members of the ECON committee, are also part of this committee and will try to defend the interests of the French taxpayer.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of setting up this special committee because I believe that we need to clarify those behaviours which have potentially damaged the public finances of european states and have therefore given less value to the taxes we all pay. I am, of course, a guarantor and I believe that, until proven otherwise, no one was wrong. I think that tax competition is, like any competition, healthy inso far as the starting conditions are comparable. I await this committee's report with curiosity in order to get a better idea of what happened and to be able to assess it on the basis of as objective information as possible.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — We want to shed light on all Member States’ tax rulings and put pressure on them to end unfair tax practices, as well as combat tax evasion. This has to be done on a pan-European basis and must not simply isolate and concentrate on smaller states. For us this is a crucial question of fairness. This is why we decided to start work in a special committee with a broad mandate immediately.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of setting up this special committee because I believe that it will carry out useful monitoring and monitoring of the management and use of European funding and State aid, not only by the European Commission but also by all Member States. It is important that all tax arrangements are transparent and that any tax planning does not affect public finances and, consequently, the lives of all of us citizens. I therefore wish my colleagues and the new special committee a good job.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The issue related to the misuse of tax rulings by Member States ought to be considered and exposed. Yet one must not confuse the misuse of tax rulings with the Member Statesʼ discretion in establishing the tax system which is best adapted to their economy. We must realise that each of our Member Statesʼ economies has its own different challenges, advantages, resources and potential. Turning the outcry against the misuse of tax rulings towards a call for harmonised taxation is not a way of bringing social justice within our Member States.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: in writing. - I am delighted with the establishment of this special committee. It has a remit going well beyond that which a committee of inquiry would have had as the latter is limited to looking at a violation of existing law whereas what is needed is to look at the insufficiencies of current law. A study by the S&D Group concluded that the total amount lost to national exchequers from tax avoiders and tax evasion across Europe is greater than the sum of all government deficits added together. If this committee can contribute in any way to addressing this problem it will have done European citizens a great service.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I support the setting up of a ʽspecial committeeʼ to examine the Lux Leaks case. No one can agree with tax fraud and tax avoidance.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This decision proposes the creation of an ad hoc commission whose mission, for six months, will be to uncover the tax practices of the Member States of the European Union as well as to make concrete proposals to put an end to abuses in this area and to propose a homogenisation of corporate taxation in Europe. In view of the fact that the absence of tax harmonisation at European level can create a situation where the tax decisions of one Member State lead to tax shortfalls or a reduction in tax or tax in another Member State, it is necessary for the European Parliament to address this issue. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the creation of this special committee which will be chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure, President of the French delegation within the European People's Party.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this resolution, we have endorsed the establishment of a special commission on tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or by their effect. I supported this desire to shed light on unfair tax practices that would be at work in several Member States of the European Union.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure investigation of tax dumping of multinational corporations. However, I denounce the decision by the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, to not put a revised mandate for an inquiry committee to the vote, even though that mandate is now the basis for the special committee. Only an inquiry committee would have granted the right to examine classified documents by EU Member States and hence reflect also on the role of some key EU political figures such as the President of the EU Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, in aiding tax evasion and tax avoidance, which deprives EU citizens yearly of nearly 1 trillion euros. Such a mandate would have met all the requirements for an inquiry committee, as the EU Commission did not act in accordance with EU directives, which request EU Member States to inform each other about tax rulings. However, the scope of any investigation must go beyond state aid rules, since tax rulings are perfectly compatible with competition law if they do not discriminate against single companies. I will evaluate all means to challenge the decision of Mr Schulz legally.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — In the wake of the recent tax evasion and evasion scandals in Europe, the European Parliament has decided to set up a special committee on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect. This comprehensive overview is necessary and will inform the Council of Heads of State on future tax directions. This issue concerns not only Luxembourg, but many other European countries which have granted, at the card, extraordinary tax advantages to a particular entity, or even to states, leading to unwelcome distortions of tax competition. There is only one possible answer and it is urgent: tax harmonisation within the euro area.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. " Tax rulings are an important subject and one that deserved the European Union to address them. Indeed, this procedure allows private actors to avail themselves of a position of the tax administration on existing standards, following a question raised by them. However, it appears that tax rulings have been widely used in some EU countries by non-European companies in order to reduce their tax contribution. It is proposed only a simple draft investigation which, on the other hand, seems to focus more on monitoring the compliance of States' actions with European Union law than on assessing the abuses and excesses of this system. It is therefore an incomplete and unsatisfactory text in terms of the stakes, which is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I fully support the establishment of the Special Committee on Tax Regimes. The aim of the new parliamentary committee is to investigate the scandal that has shaken the reputation of Juncker and the European Union as a whole. The other essential task before the new committee is to examine the tax regimes of all member states in order to detect and prevent the misuse of tax benefits. The Juncker scandal has subsided, but speculation has neither been exposed nor confirmed. We must not forget the essence of this scandal, namely that tax benefits and abuse threaten the full functioning of the single internal market, as it is one of the foundations of the European Union. The registration of companies in a tax haven for tax avoidance purposes in another Member State must be deterred, prohibited and sanctioned. This is not European solidarity, it is not a free market, it is siphoning money and revenue from the state and plundering the people. That is why I believe that, as an institution directly chosen by European citizens, it is our duty to impose parliamentary scrutiny and to investigate such cases until they are fully clarified. This is not about the reputation of one person or one government, this is about the reputation of the European Union itself.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — Although such action is necessary, since it will examine cases where EU countries use loopholes in EU legislation and regulations to unfairly benefit from economic figures, this proposal for a decision nevertheless enables the special committee set up for six months to investigate other measures of a similar nature or effect. , thus directly interfering with the tax mechanisms of the Member States without restriction.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The establishment of this Special Committee on Early Tax Rulings and Other Measures of A Similar Nature or Effect, which will be composed of 45 members, seeks, in addition to examining the application by a Member State or the Commission of State aid law and Union tax law in relation to advance tax rulings, to propose appropriate measures for the healthy functioning of the internal market and to verify whether aid granted by a State or from State resources is compatible internal market and are not misused. This committee will also analyse and assess the repercussions of aggressive tax planning undertaken by companies established or established in the Member States, as well as the exchange of information in this area.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The Luxleaks scandal has scandalised public opinion and further undermined the credibility of the EU institutions, calling into question the legitimacy of the President of the European Commission and his political capacity to promote more tax justice. As more information was released, it was soon understood that this issue covers the vast majority of EU countries, committing the two large political families of this Parliament, popular and socialist, to their national governments, who actively participated in this promiscuous relationship between political power and large multinational companies. That is why they made it impossible to set up a committee of inquiry – which we have been advocating from the outset – by replacing it with a special committee with far fewer powers. The establishment of this Special Committee, with this mandate, despite falling short of what would be necessary and not explicitly pointing out the central role of multinational companies and their relationship with national governments, despite the weight allocated to State aid, which we disagree with, represents an instrument that can contribute to the clarification of this Parliament and public opinion on the tax practices that , systematically burden workers and their families and relieve large enterprises.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of setting up the special committee which, among its tasks, also has the task of shedding light on the so-called Luxleak case.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Although such an action must be implemented in so far as it will examine cases where EU countries use loopholes in EU legislation and regulations to unfairly benefit economic operators, this proposal for a decision enables the special committee set up for 6 months to investigate other measures of a similar nature or effect, thus directly interfering with the tax mechanisms of the Member States without restriction. For this reason, my vote is against the establishment of a special committee on tax arrangements and other measures of a similar nature or impact.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — The establishment of a committee within the European Parliament to analyse and examine the practice in the application of Article 107(1) TFEU with regard to tax resolutions and other measures of a similar nature or effects adopted by the Member States since 1 January 1991, is a positive step towards achieving the proper functioning of the internal market and ensuring the principle of loyalty between the Member States of EU. The problem does not underlie the tax practices of a single State, so, in my opinion, this parliamentary committee can shed light on practices that are contrary to Community law and what mechanisms we must adopt to continue the process of European convergence in areas as important as fiscal policy.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution establishing a special committee on tax rulings. It is essential to clarify the application of European state aid rules and thus accompany the work of the European Commission. I wish the 45 members who will be part of it every success. Their work will be invaluable in contributing to greater fairness and legal certainty in the Member States.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. — I support the establishment of the Special Committee. Unlike a committee of inquiry, this form offers a real opportunity to actually work in a solution-oriented way towards greater transparency and more tax justice. The fact that international corporations are exercising tax avoidance at the expense of citizens and medium-sized enterprises must come to an end. However, a committee of inquiry would have been a very bad means of doing so. Such a committee only leads to controversy and not to solutions. And if in doubt, it is directed against individuals. However, this is not a question of individual cases, but of a structural problem. There must be a simple principle: where the profits are generated, taxes must also be paid. The new committee should therefore not only ensure transparency. My concern is that we are drawing up concrete proposals for greater tax justice.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. — Following the "Luxleaks" case, the umpteenth tax evasion scandal, I voted to set up a special commission to examine tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect. This committee will be composed of 45 full members, including our esteemed colleague Bernard Monot, economic strategist of the National Front.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the proposal which aims to set up a committee dedicated to investigating, from a general point of view, the different types of problems related to European taxation. We understand, however, that the proposal for the establishment of this committee comes after an investigation has become impossible that questions the tax regimes with which members who are now personalities of the European institutions have been able to facilitate tax engineering manoeuvres to different companies or private entities of various kinds.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to look into tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. Particularly following scandals such as LuxLeaks it is important that we understand exactly what has been happening across Europe when it comes to companies, their advisers and even whole countries seemingly working hand in hand to reduce corporate tax rates to little more than 0%.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. — On a proposal from the Conference of Presidents, the vote to form a special committee of inquiry took place in plenary on Thursday. The aim is to conduct an in-depth study of tax systems through the EU as a whole, and to make proposals so that cases such as Luxleaks do not happen again. The SD Group and the Socialist Delegation supported with their vote the constitution, for 6 months (extendable to another six months), of the special committee which, precisely, will have the participation of Ramón Jáuregui in the fight against evasion, fraud and tax competition. The committee will also have a member of the alternate delegation. The committee has 45 full members, 12 of them Socialists, belonging to the committees on Economic Affairs, Legal Affairs, Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and Budgets.   It is hoped that the work of the special committee to be initiated in the coming weeks will enable proposals to end tax avoidance, privileges, tax havens and the construction of a true tax union.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I was very happy to support the proposal to set up a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures. This Special Committee will allow investigation and discussion of issues such as the third-country dimension of aggressive tax planning, administrative cooperation in the field of taxation, the application of EU state-aid and taxation law in relation to tax rulings. EU citizens are genuinely concerned about the prospect of large multinationals using systems to evade paying the required levels of corporation tax and hopefully this Committee will work towards an equitable system while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — The newly set up SPECIAL COMMITTEE of the EP will be responsible for identifying and proposing specific tax avoidance practices. These methods mainly play out the tax rules of the Member States by multinationals. Last fall, a case known as the "Luxleaks" case drew attention to the fact that many large companies had evaded tax by various tax tricks or paid unrealisticly low taxes. The aim of the Fidesz-KDNP Group is to ensure that multinational companies, like small and medium-sized enterprises and individuals, play their fair and proportionate share of the burden.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the proposal which aims to set up a committee dedicated to investigating, from a general point of view, the different types of problems related to European taxation. We understand, however, that the proposal for the establishment of this committee comes after an investigation has become impossible that questions the tax regimes with which members who are now personalities of the European institutions have been able to facilitate tax engineering manoeuvres to different companies or private entities of various kinds.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted to establish a special Committee on Tax Rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect. The reason for my VOTE for the ZA is that I consider it necessary to establish a special Committee on Tax Rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect, as this will establish better coordination and monitoring of tax rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. " Tax rulings are an important subject and one that deserved the European Union to address them. Indeed, this procedure allows private actors to avail themselves of a position of the tax administration on existing standards, following a question raised by them. However, it appears that tax rulings have been widely used in some countries by non-European companies to reduce their tax contribution. It is proposed only a simple draft investigation which, on the other hand, seems to focus more on monitoring the compliance of States' actions with European Union law than on assessing the abuses and excesses of this system. It is therefore an incomplete and unsatisfactory text in terms of the stakes, which is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — MEPs voted in favour of the creation of a special parliamentary committee to examine tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect of the Member States of the Union. The committee's mission will be to uncover the tax practices of all Member States and to present concrete proposals in favour of greater European tax fairness. I welcome this vote.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Setting-up of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect’ because we agree in principle.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure investigation of tax dumping of multinational corporations. However, I denounce the decision by the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, to not put a revised mandate for an inquiry committee to the vote, even though that mandate is now the basis for the special committee.
