Only an inquiry committee would have granted the right to examine classified documents by EU Member States and hence reflect also on the role of some key EU political figures such as the President of the EU Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, in aiding tax evasion and tax avoidance, which deprives EU citizens yearly of nearly 1 trillion euros. Such a mandate would have met all the requirements for an inquiry committee as the EU Commission did not act in accordance with EU directives which request EU Member States to inform each other about tax rulings. However, the scope of any investigation must go beyond state aid rules since tax rulings are perfectly compatible with competition law if they do not discriminate against single companies. I will evaluate all means to challenge the decision of Mr Schulz legally.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the establishment of a special committee on tax arrangements and other measures of a similar nature or effect, because I believe that the establishment of a special body responsible for examining tax decisions implemented by all EU Member States is correct. Specifically, the Committee will examine the tax arrangements concluded as from 1 January 1991 and will endeavour to ascertain the negative impact of aggressive tax planning on public finances.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. — I supported the creation of a special commission on tax evasion encouraged by states, because it is vital to put an end to interstate tax competition practices. These processes subtract billions of euros from national budgets at a time when they need them most to offset the devastating effects of the crisis on populations, and thus reduce the possibilities for action by the public authorities. I note, however, that the main groups in Parliament, the right and the Socialists, have not taken up our request for a commission of inquiry which would have allowed for much more investigation than a special committee. I also regret that this manoeuvre was hidden behind a bespoke decision on the legality of a commission of inquiry. However, with the mandate remaining the same as the one we proposed with the Greens, I welcome the creation of this commission. The special committee, through its existence and its follow-up work on tax cooperation between states and the Commission's diligence on the fight against tax evasion practices, will increase the pressure against tax evasion, which costs European states almost EUR 1 trillion each year.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Writing. — Tax fraud and tax avoidance cause EUR 1 trillion in financial damage in the EU every year. Ultimately, this is theft from society and honest taxpayers, who cannot benefit from special tax arrangements and cross-border tax avoidance schemes. A fair distribution of the tax burden is a matter of social justice and essential for social cohesion. I have agreed to the convening of a special committee on tax arrangements in the EU so that the European Parliament, representing European citizens, can detect and end unfair tax practices in all EU Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure that the tax dumping of multinationals is investigated. However, I report the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, not to allow the establishment of an investigative committee to be voted on, when the mandate that would have allowed it is the basis of the special committee. Only one committee of inquiry would have allowed access to classified documentation from the Member States, which would have made it possible to find out the role of some European political figures, such as Commission President Juncker, in relation to tax evasion and avoidance costing European citizens one billion euros per year. The formation of a committee of inquiry was legally justified because the European Commission had not complied with its own directives, which require Member States to transparency in their tax rulings.  The investigation of tax rulings cannot be limited to State aid either, since they are compatible with competition policy if they do not discriminate between companies.  I therefore undertake to consider how to legally require the establishment of an investigative commission.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — As an economist, I am in for the greatest possible tax competition and the ability of individual states to determine the amount of taxes. This is the only way to compete fairly for companies that come to the country to do business. Unfortunately, the European Union's efforts are going in the opposite direction and, instead of tax competition, it is strengthening the system of selective investment incentives and the charging of a minimum tax level. I am against any attempt to centralise tax rulings at EU level.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the establishment of a special Committee on Tax Rules and other measures of a similar nature or impact whose tasks are: to investigate and analyse the tax rules and similar measures of all Member States since January 1991, to investigate and analyse the State aid system in the Member States, to foster cooperation between Member States in data sharing and to prevent aggressive tax planning and to avoid double taxation. The Committee aims to prevent aggressive tax planning and unfair tax measures that undermine competitiveness and the single market, thus hampering economic growth and development.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. I was among the members who signed a letter at the time to open the investigation into the LUXLEAKS case. Because it is important to know the truth and prevent such situations from happening again in the future. Taxes are payable by everyone without exception. Otherwise, how can we, for example, require Latvian farmers to pay everything up to the last cent and at the same time allow them not to pay taxes to large corporations, where tax evasion saves millions. I also voted today in favour of setting up the committee, even though fellow MEMBERS of the GREENS group promise to go to the Luxembourg court because they, when they initiated the investigation, asked for a different mandate for this committee than what was actually appointed at the Conference of Presidents.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the proposal for a decision establishing, defining competences, the numerical composition and the duration of the mandate of the Special Committee on Tax Ruling Agreements and other measures of a similar nature and effect, because this Committee will examine in depth the well-known 'Lux Leaks' case and other similar cases concerning tax havens within EU States and thus pose a challenge to millions of poor EU citizens , who pay their taxes normally, at a time when many businesses and wealthy individuals are fleeing by taking advantage of the above tax havens.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of setting up a Special Committee of the European Parliament on tax systems, which will have the task of examining all cases of tax avoidance and evasion, since I believe it is a necessary instrument for monitoring all tax decisions and other similar measures of the Member States in the European Union.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of setting up a special committee on tax arrangements and other measures of a similar nature or effect, as I considered it desirable to set up a special body to examine the tax decisions implemented by the Member States of the European Union. The Committee will examine the tax arrangements concluded since 1 January 1991 and will also endeavour to ascertain the negative impact of aggressive tax planning on public finances.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Committee of Inquiry to ensure that tax dumping of large multinationals is investigated. However, the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, should be denounced for not having submitted the revised mandate for the vote, as long as that mandate is the basis for the Special Committee. Only a Committee of Inquiry would have the right and access to classified documents from the Member States. Access to these documents is not included in the Special Committee, documents that could prove that political figures such as European Commission President Jean Claude Juncker would be facilitating tax evasion by large multinationals, which harm European citizens by almost €1 trillion. We will continue to challenge the decision of The President of Parliament, Martin Schulz.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Following the revelations about tax evasion in Luxembourg, my group had tried to file a motion of censure against Jean-Claude Juncker, Prime Minister of Luxembourg at the time of the events. In the absence of support, we were unable to put it to a vote. I have therefore supported the creation of a commission of inquiry into this case, and here it too is denied to us by Martin Schulz. We are offered to console ourselves with the creation of a "special" commission, with limited powers. We would have liked to bury this case that we would not have dealt with it differently. Nevertheless, for the sake of consistency in the fight against tax evasion, I vote for this committee, under no illusions as to its effects.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of setting up this committee because it is in line with the objectives to be set.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I support this proposal to establish a special committee on tax rulings as it is important that we protect competition within the internal market. I believe that this directive will help Member States curb financial crime through greater transparency. The aim is to seek to improve administrative cooperation between Member States. I reiterate that national sovereignty over taxation issues must be preserved.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure investigation of tax dumping by multinational corporations. I now protest against the decision by the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, to refuse to put a revised mandate for an inquiry committee to the vote, even though that mandate is now the basis for the special committee.  Only an inquiry committee would have granted the right to examine classified documents by EU Member States and hence reflect also on the possible role of some key EU political figures – such as the President of the EU Commission, Jean Claude Juncker – in aiding tax evasion and tax avoidance, which annually deprives EU citizens of an estimated EUR 1 trillion. Such a mandate would have met all the requirements for an inquiry committee as the EU Commission did not act in accordance with EU directives which request EU Member States to inform each other about tax rulings. However, the scope of any investigation must go beyond state aid rules since tax rulings are perfectly compatible with competition law if they do not discriminate against single companies. I will evaluate all means to challenge in law the decision of Mr Schulz.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — Following a number of investigations initiated by the European Commission which have uncovered agreements on a non-standard tax regime for multinationals in Luxembourg, Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands, there is a need to introduce more transparency into tax rulings that may affect other Member States or the union as a whole. I therefore voted in favour of the establishment of a special committee of the European Parliament to monitor tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature taken by The Member States and overall transparency in the adoption of tax rulings. On the basis of the facts examined, the Committee shall make appropriate recommendations for the future.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. — Luxembourg's tax practices cast a heavy shadow over the newly formed European Commission. It is therefore in our fundamental interest for the European Parliament to conduct a rapid and effective investigation into this matter in order to restore credibility and citizens' trust. The guarantee of this is now a special committee. At the end of the investigation, we need a European tax bill that will make tax evasion and increasingly meaty government corruption impossible. European tax avoidance legislation would be particularly important for Member States such as Hungary, where the tax authorities appear to be a hotbed of government corruption.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — The European Parliament has decided to set up a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures of a Similar Nature or Effect in order to examine the application by a Member State or the Commission of state aid law and Eu tax law in relation to advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect taken by Member States. I am in favour of setting up this Special Commission but I would like to stress that the importance of this analysis should not be carried out only and only when media cases arise, such as those that have recently arisen, but must instead be extended to a number of countries in the European Union in order to investigate illegal practices of tax evasion and fraud, as well as state support that undermines or undermines European free competition.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I abstained on the establishment of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures, since this is obviously not the creation of a commission of inquiry and, de facto, it will therefore not benefit from the necessary means of investigation. The establishment of such a commission may appear to some to be a first step forward for tax transparency in the European Union, but it is in fact a sham and an empty shell. In the wake of the "LuxLeaks" scandal and the measures allowing Luxembourg's arrangements for 340 multinationals to evade a large part of their taxes, particularly in France and Europe, I regret that nowhere here is there any explicit mention of Luxembourg. This says, in my opinion, already a long time on the effectiveness of this commission which is really nothing special!

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the establishment of a special commission on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect. The committee, which will take place following a series of investigations launched by the European Commission into the tax rulings of multinational companies based in Luxembourg, Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands, will have an initial mandate of 6 months and will be composed of 45 members. Its role will be to examine the application by a Member State or the Commission of state aid law and EU tax law with regard to tax rulings. It will make proposals to combat tax evasion and unfair tax optimisation.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for the creation of a special committee on tax decisions and similar measures or with similar effects which would verify compliance with the tax regime at European level by all Member States and ensure that a tax balance at European level is restored.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: scríofa. — Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar bunú sainchoiste chun fiosrúchán cruinn a dhéanamh ar líomhaintí d’imghabháil cánach agus de chalaois chánach atá déanta ag roinnt corparáidí ilnáisiúnta trasna an Aontais Eorpaigh, agus an bhaint a líomhnaítear a bhí ag roinnt ionadaithe polaitíochta leis. Is é mo thuairim go bhfuil géarghá ann go dtarlóidh fiosrúchán mar seo. Nílim sásta leis an dóigh nár cheap an Pharlaimint go raibh sé tábhachtach go leor brú ar aghaidh leis an gcoiste fiosrúcháin a bhí molta. Dá mba rud é go mbeadh coiste fiosrúcháin bunaithe bheadh na cumhachtaí dlíthiúla acu a chinntiú go mbeadh cinneadh a tháinig mar thoradh den fhiosrúchán oibiachtúil, cothrom agus gan chlaonadh. Tá sé fós le bheith cinntithe go sonrach an mbeidh na cumhachtaí cearta ann chun fiosrú a dhéanamh ar na bealaí éalaithe dlíthiúla a bhí i bhfeidhm ag corparáidí ilnáisiúnta ar fud an Aontais Eorpaigh le cabhair ó ionadaithe polaitíochta sinsearacha. I gconclúid, mar gheall ar na hagúis go léir atá mínithe agam, chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar bhunú an tsainchoiste seo agus beidh mo pháirtí agus mo ghrúpa ag déanamh monatóireachta ar an scéal seo.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The "Special Committee on Tax Agreements and Measures of a Similar Kind or With Similar Consequences" will deal with binding tax information and prohibited state aid over the next six months and will finally present a report. I voted in favour of setting up this special committee to ensure investigations into tax dumping by multinationals.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal for a special committee because I believe that all Member States must follow honest tax behaviour, exclude unfair tax revenues and ensure a level playing field.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. "Despite my disappointment that this is only a special commission and not a commission of inquiry, the mere creation of a commission is a good thing. Of course, Luxembourg is not even named, even though everyone knows full well that this measure follows the scandal created by the revelations of tax practices in that country. There can be little optimism about the great wave of the defined mission and the lack of resources of a special commission in relation to a commission of inquiry. It is to be hoped that this will only be a first step. So I'm voting for it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I naturally voted in favour of setting up the Special Committee on Fiscal Agreements, because I believe that a fair European fiscal policy depends very much on the success of the Union itself, as well as the revival of the real economy and employment. Evading and using tax havens are probably the crimes that do the most harm to a society that wants to call itself just and egalitarian, endangering the foundations on which society itself is based. Our group has said this several times, particularly since the Luxleaks scandal: the fight against tax evasion and tax havens will be a priority in this parliamentary term. The creation of this committee is proof of this.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. — I fully support the establishment of a special committee on tax rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect. Recent examples of "Luxleaks" or HSBC Bank show that a few in the current system successfully find ways for various tax, financial and monetary malfeasances that benefit only them and the consequences are borne by all citizens. An even more alarming fact is that various malfeasance occurs with the approval of the executive branch. As the only European body elected by citizens, the European Parliament has a specific task to respond to such cases in a timely manner, to encourage the adoption of a more adequate regulatory framework and to protect the citizens it represents.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a decision taking into account the Commission's decision to investigate the practice of tax rulings in accordance with EU State aid rules in all Member States. To that end, the Special Committee should be granted the power to analyse and test practices on tax judgments issued in the Member States from 1 January 2013. On 1 January 1991, the Commission's powers to analyse and assess the commission's practices to carry out constant monitoring of all aid schemes existing in the Member States and to propose appropriate measures necessary for the gradual development or functioning of the internal market, the power to analyse and test whether Member States comply with the obligations to establish detailed rules of application on the obligation to cooperate and provide all necessary documents. Furthermore, it should be given the power to analyse and examine compliance with the obligations under the Council Directive on mutual assistance of the competent authorities of the Member States in the field of direct taxation. It is also important to analyse and assess member states' conduct in accordance with the principle of loyal cooperation.  The powers of the Special Committee should also relate to the analysis and assessment of third country aspects in aggressive tax planning by undertakings established or established in the Member States, as well as the exchange of information with third countries in this regard.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — I support the resolution on the creation of a special committee for decisions on the tax regime and other measures similar in nature or effect. However, I must express my view that it needs to be based, in particular, on the principle that tax competition between States is beneficial. Tax harmonisation, on the other hand, would not help European economies, in my opinion. On the other hand, I, of course, support efforts to expose tax evasion and injustice.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Some Member States use tax rulings extensively to provide tax advantages to foreign companies. This practice disintegrates the European Union and instigates unfair competition within it. I am therefore in favour of the establishment of a special committee, chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure, in order to shed light on a perverse practice of democratic societies.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The Commission decided to investigate, in all Member States, the compatibility of the practice of tax rulings in advance with union rules on State aid. Union tax legislation obliges all Member States to communicate to other Member States, by spontaneous exchange, all information on advance tax rulings, in particular if they can lead to a loss of tax revenue in another Member State or if fictitious transfers of profits within business groups may lead to a reduction in fees or taxes. This resolution proposes the establishment of a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures of a Similar Nature or Effect in order to examine the application by a Member State or the Commission of State aid law and Eu tax law in relation to advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect taken by Member States. The Special Commission should assess, inter alia, whether State aid is compatible with the internal market and whether it is not applied abusively, and more overall, whether the obligations arising from Union tax legislation are fulfilled by issuing the final recommendations it deems necessary on this matter. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, created following the LuxLeaks case and which, within a maximum period of one year, must submit its proposals to build a true tax union and end tax havens, tax evasion, privileges and fraudulent tax competition in the EU. The commitment of the Spanish Socialists is to end banking secrecy, get companies to pay the taxes where they generate their profits and create a common corporation tax for the EU.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the proposal which aims to set up a committee dedicated to investigating, from a general point of view, the different types of problems related to European taxation. We understand, however, that the creation of this committee comes after an investigation has become impossible that questions the tax regimes with which members who are now personalities of the European institutions have been able to facilitate tax engineering manoeuvres to different companies or private entities of various kinds.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Following the Luxleaks case, the European Parliament today voted in favour of the creation of a special parliamentary committee to examine tax rulings and other measures of similar nature or effects of the Member States of the Union and to propose recommendations for the future. This special commission will be composed of 45 members and will be established for an initial period of six months. I have always considered that Parliament has a duty to take up this issue and that the committee must provide the best answers to it, but it is also imperative that this political will be shared by the States, because any progress on taxation is conditional on their unanimous approval. There are still many steps to achieve fair and equitable taxation within the Union. Investigating possible violations is part of the process and that is why I wanted to support them, but what is more important is to get a comprehensive picture of these tax arrangements, in order to be able to draw up the laws that prevent them and, thus, to preserve the public finances of the whole of the European Union. This is a key issue. It is about Europe's credibility and responsibility.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the establishment of this Special Committee, because I believe that all the practices of the Member States concerning the application of tax legislation and EU State aid legislation in relation to tax rulings and other measures of the same nature or effect should be comprehensively investigated if such practices constitute an act by the Member State itself or of the European Commission. I hope that this Commission will be able to produce comprehensive, swift and relevant work.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported the creation of the special parliamentary committee on tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or effect. This special commission is set up for a period of six months and will examine the revelations concerning member states' tax rulings; it will then make concrete proposals to put an end to the abuses.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of setting up the Special Committee because, among its tasks, it also has the task of shedding light on the Luxleaks case on the tax preferences granted by the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg to certain multinationals and large companies.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the proposal which aims to set up a committee dedicated to investigating, from a general point of view, the different types of problems related to European taxation. We understand, however, that the proposal for the establishment of this committee comes after an investigation has become impossible that questions the tax regimes with which members who are now personalities of the European institutions have been able to facilitate tax engineering manoeuvres to different companies or private entities of various kinds.

name: Anne SANDER
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the creation of a special parliamentary committee whose mission will be to examine the tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect of the Member States of the Union. Tax rulings are pre-tax arrangements between a past state and a company to pay less tax. This special commission is set up following a series of investigations launched by the European Commission against certain countries such as Luxembourg, but also Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands.  This is a very serious issue and has implications for our democracies. Google, for example, paid only 7 million euros in taxes in France, for a turnover of 1.6 billion euros in 2013. How do you explain that? How can we justify the overtaxed wages and incomes of the middle class and that large foreign companies pay very little tax? Proposals are needed to minimise this injustice and European tax dumping.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament approved the establishment of a special committee on the LuxLeaks case. We abstained in this vote because we consider that this is not a sufficient measure. Our group calls for a commission of inquiry into the case, which has been curbed again by the grand coalition (popular, socialist and liberal).

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure that the tax dumping of multinationals is investigated. However, I report the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, not to allow the establishment of an investigative committee to be voted on, when the mandate that would have allowed it is the basis of the special committee. Only one committee of inquiry would have allowed access to classified documentation from the Member States, which would have made it possible to find out the role of some European political figures, such as Commission President Juncker, in relation to tax evasion and avoidance costing European citizens one billion euros per year. The formation of a committee of inquiry was legally justified because the European Commission had not complied with its own directives, which require Member States to transparency in their tax rulings.  The investigation of tax rulings cannot be limited to State aid either, since they are compatible with competition policy if they do not discriminate between companies.  I therefore undertake to consider how to legally require the establishment of an investigative commission.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of setting up a special committee to evaluate the impact of unfair tax practices across Europe. Recent scandals such as LuxLeaks have given serious need for this committee. Through this new committee’s activities, the representatives of European citizens will be able to look into all cases of tax avoidance and tax evasion in Europe.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported the establishment of a Special Committee on Tax Rules, although the Greens/ESS Group proposed the establishment of a European Parliament Committee of Inquiry to examine all possible cases of breaches of European tax laws and practices. We received strong support, more than the required 25 per cent of MEPs and MEPs, i.e. an extraordinary 192 signatures. The Research Committee is the strongest instrument in the hands of the European Parliament and would represent the power of EU citizens and citizens through the supervisory function of MEPs and MEPs. It would only provide comprehensive access to the official documentation of the Member States, the Commission and the Council of the European Union. With this act, the Grand Coalition devalued the strength and credibility of the European Parliament as the only directly democratically elected institution. The 'Luxleaks' affair is the best evidence of the unprecedented proportions of the failure of member states and the Commission to comply with and implement the provisions of the fundamental treaties of the European Union. Already in 2012, the Commission recognised the threats of aggressive tax planning by certain multinationals to divert their tax liabilities to Member States with softer tax regimes with the purpose of tax avoidance, thereby boosting their own private profits. Member States shall exchange information on possible tax losses in other Member States, as well as on suspicions of aggressive tax planning by private companies.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — By deciding on the establishment of a special committee of the European Parliament to deal with the implementation of EU State aid and tax legislation on tax decisions and other measures with a similar nature or effect, Parliament has provided a partial insight into the issue of tax avoidance. I myself supported the creation of this committee, but I still have some concerns. This decision is a good step forward that was necessary, but it is far from enough. It seems to me that the creation of this committee is a bad compromise between the sincere desire to investigate the background of tax affairs in a high-quality and transparent manner and the attempt not to investigate at all. There is a possibility that the committee will only develop into a form that is without competence and merely superficial. The Decision of the Parliament Presidency not to place on this vote the point on the establishment of the Commission of Inquiry proposed by the Greens is contrary to democratic standards. The LuxLeaks affair erupted violently, and citizens expected to get concrete answers and explanations. That is why we in the Green Party have gathered enough signatures to set up a commission of inquiry, which would have powers and is Parliament's most powerful tool in cases where the conduct at issue is properly investigated.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The purpose of establishing a special tax rules committee is to fight for tax fairness and tax transparency in Europe. Tax filing evasion is still a problem in some Member States and this committee aims to achieve transparency of tax opinions, come up with far-sighted proposals to strengthen tax equitation and fight tax avoidance more strongly in the European Union. Those are my reasons for supporting this decision.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support this proposal to establish a special committee on tax rules and other measures of a similar nature or effect, as I consider its existence necessary to achieve equality of treatment. Transparent treatment when taxing multinational companies is of utmost importance and I am of the opinion that there must be no situations in which certain types of benefits and benefits are given. Equal treatment of all, both domestic and foreign companies, is one of the foundations on which the entire European system is based, the violation of which must not go unnoticed. In my view, tax policy must not leave room for state will, but must be improved and upgraded at European level, and the positive news is that Alain Lamassoure, as the long-time chairman of the European Parliament's budget committee and a respected member of the EPP Club, will best represent the interests of both the EPP and other clubs because he is a politician with charisma and an expert.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I agree with the establishment of this committee as it can bring more information on the so-called 'Lux Leaks' case of European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. Similarly, this committee can contribute to detecting similar practices much earlier in the future. EU countries should not set special tax rates for selected businesses, but all businesses should have the same, transparent conditions that apply to all.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The establishment of a committee to examine cases where EU countries use loopholes in their legislation and regulations to benefit, abusively, from tax rulings, is necessary but should be limited to investigating these cases without extending its competence to the other tax mechanisms of the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — Hugues Bayet was appointed shadow rapporteur on the first report. He will focus on two key priorities for the PS: the fight against tax evasion and evasion and the introduction of a capital tax. The Socialists did not wait for Luxleaks to break out to demand fairer taxation. It is high time to put in place tools to combat tax evasion, otherwise Luxleaks will soon become Belgoleaks, Frenchleaks and finally EUleaks.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the creation of a special committee on tax rulings. After the revelation of Luxembourg tax practices, this vote is an important step to study further the tax practices of all the Member States, (not just Luxembourg) , and to make concrete proposals to put an end to abuses.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this committee, of which I am to be a member. Although it is a dire decision to establish this special commission rather than a commission of inquiry, at this point, we believe it is necessary to use the available tools. We will use this commission to shed light on the massive tax scam, organised by governments like Juncker's in Luxembourg.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - On 12 February, the European Parliament voted to set up a special parliamentary committee, the TAXE Committee. This committee, set up thanks to the M5S in Europe, against tax havens and tax avoidance by multinationals will assess the system of tax arrangements between EU Member States and large multinationals.  The special committee is composed of Members from all the political groups. For the M5S, I, together with my colleague Marco Zanni, will have the honour of protecting the interests of citizens from the power of the multinational lobby. However, the choice of this tool is a long way from what the M5S had initially asked for, as this committee will not have any real investigative powers. Following the tax scandal in Luxembourg, we tabled a motion of censure, which was unfortunately rejected by the Strasbourg Chamber last November. We have therefore called, together with 191 other Members of the European Parliament, for a parliamentary committee of inquiry to be set up to investigate and assess any infringements made by Luxembourg or other Member States in the field of tax arrangements. Unfortunately, the Legal Service of the European Parliament and the large political groups (PPE and S&D) have decided that our request was unfounded, without going into the specific substance of the matter. The choice of special committee is therefore the minimum solution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a special committee to ensure that the tax dumping of multinationals is investigated. However, I report the decision of the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, not to allow the establishment of an investigative committee to be voted on, when the mandate that would have allowed it is the basis of the special committee. Only one committee of inquiry would have allowed access to classified documentation from the Member States, which would have made it possible to find out the role of some European political figures, such as Commission President Juncker, in relation to tax evasion and avoidance costing European citizens one billion euros per year. The formation of a committee of inquiry was legally justified because the European Commission had not complied with its own directives, which require Member States to transparency in their tax rulings.  The investigation of tax rulings cannot be limited to State aid either, since they are compatible with competition policy if they do not discriminate between companies.  I therefore undertake to consider how to legally require the establishment of an investigative commission.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of setting up a special committee on tax rulings because this will allow the creation of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect to examine practice in the application of EU state aid and taxation law in relation to tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect issued by Member States.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The Luxleaks scandal has shaken the European Union and scandalised public opinion, calling into question the legitimacy of the European Commission and its political capacity to promote more tax justice. As more information was released, it was soon understood that this issue covers the vast majority of the countries of the European Union, committing the two large political families of this Parliament, popular and socialist, to their national governments where they actively participated in this promiscuous relationship between political power and large multinational companies. Hence the retreat of the people and the Socialists, who did everything they could to prevent the creation of this committee of inquiry. That is why they made it impossible to set up a committee of inquiry, replacing it with a special committee with far fewer powers.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. — I support Parliament's decision to set up a special committee to investigate Mr Juncker's involvement in the LuxLeaks affair. Unfortunately, the committee's mandate has been watered down. Instead of a committee of inquiry, we get a special committee. And instead of the Juncker system, it is looking at tax justice and tax transparency in the EU.  The winners are the Greens, who are once again allowed to address taxation at EU level and continue their dream of extending EU competences. The black and red social democrats are the helpers. They are only too happy to become henchmen of the Greens, because only in this way can they prevent the Juncker, who has just been elected by them, from being damaged shortly after taking office. The truth is lost, because there is no real interest in how Mr Juncker is involved in the affair. It is therefore worth recalling what is at stake: a person who has facilitated tax evasion in the office cannot be President of the Commission.  With regard to the change in the subject of the investigation, I must also point out that tax competition has an important function. It leads to lower taxes and helps the state not to get too fat. The EU rightly lacks competence in tax law.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of setting up this special committee to assess member states' tax arrangements, in order to shed some light on realities in many EU countries which are likely to be harmful to their European partners themselves. However, we cannot hide, not admitting that in reality the choice of this instrument is far removed from our demands, which emerged overwhelmingly following the Luxembourg tax scandal (LuxLeaks), which directly involved Commission President Juncker, and for which we had prepared a special censure, which unfortunately was rejected by the Strasbourg Chamber in November. We have therefore called, together with a total of 191 Members, for a parliamentary committee of inquiry to be set up to assess effectively any violations committed by Luxembourg or other European countries. The Legal Service of the European Parliament, with the support of the large groups (The People's Party and The Socialists), has decided that our request was unfounded, but did not go into the specific substance of the matter. Today's choice is therefore the minimum solution, which can please (or displease) everyone. In any case, we must use all the instruments at our disposal, and so I have decided to take part in this committee, trying to make an active contribution.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of setting up a special parliamentary committee to assess the system of tax agreements between EU Member States and large multinationals. When it comes to fraud, evasion and tax havens, we must not compromise. As a member of the 5-Star Movement, I had already signed a request to set up a committee of inquiry following the LuxLeaks scandal over the alleged tax favours granted by Luxembourg to 340 banks and multinationals over the last twenty years, which had personally involved the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, against whom we had also prepared a special motion of censure. Following the refusal of the large political groups in this Parliament to support our first proposal, the decision to set up this committee therefore appears to be a watered-down solution. However, I believe it is essential to use all possible, albeit insufficient, instruments at our disposal to counter these despicable policies.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I want to explain my vote on the resolution on the Islamic State. The vote was not electronic, which is why I want EU citizens and my constituents in the Czech Republic to know that I supported the resolution against the Islamic State. I consider the Islamic State to be an extremely dangerous unit, it is not possible to say either an organisation or a state that is currently carrying out acts against humanity. It is a unit against which it is necessary to support the allies who are fighting against it, and it is necessary for these allies to work more closely together in the future and to consider whether the offensive against the Islamic State should take even more forms. I believe that if we are not active in this matter, the danger of the Islamic State may increase and grow into other Islamic countries, as we see in North Africa, for example.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I also wanted to express that I voted against the Islamic State and I believe that there may not have been one member in this House who would not support this motion for a resolution, which has been voted on here. As part of my oral explanation, I would like to appeal in particular to the EU states and European allies to take joint unified military action against the Islamic State, preferably with a Security Council mandate. And I am glad that I have had the opportunity here to reiterate this call against the Member States, because we can kind of make sure of each other's non-support for the Islamic State, of condemning its practices, but until european states and their allies around the world find enough determination to intervene militarily, I am convinced that the Islamic State will not be defeated.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I too voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. I have to say that all the points are correct. However, I was particularly pleased with paragraph 9 of the motion for a resolution, because it also looks at the causes a little bit. It is once again a question of calling on the Iraqi Government to be truly representative, because all political groups, all ethnic groups in society, must be reflected in the administration and government in the Iraqi state. I was also pleased because, in my view, it was the beginning source that led some people to radicalism. That is why the motion for a resolution is balanced, and now, if you like, it is a question of implementing these points.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Mr President, it is a pity that we did not have a roll-call vote for the final vote here, so that it could be on the record that the vast majority of Members in this House condemn without reservation the activities of Islamic State. This is one of the most brutal movements, if we can call it that, that the world has ever seen. Certainly in the modern era, when so many countries have moved forward in trying to respect human rights, to see some of the activities of this Islamic State, in terms of beheadings, the treatment of women and their use as gifts for soldiers, forced marriages etc., it is so out of date that we have to condemn it without reservation – and, indeed, use all the methods we can to ensure that this type of activity is written out of history.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latent conflicts in Iraq and Syria, together with the violence that is putting the threat of ISIS in the region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the European Union. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The adopted resolution contains elements that are difficult to be against, such as the clear condemnation of human rights violations committed by ISIS/Daesh terrorists and their related groups in Syria and Iraq. In this area, concerns are expressed about the progressive deterioration of the humanitarian situation, especially that of domestic refugees. However, the roots of the problem are not included in the resolution. There is no reference to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which was key not only to the humanitarian crisis it triggered, but because it initiated a trend of annihilation of secular states in the Middle East that favored religious factions. Without addressing the roots of the problem, similar situations may be repeated elsewhere in the globe in the future, which is why I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The crisis in Iraq and Syria, exacerbated by the activities of ISIS, is leading to a dramatic deterioration in the humanitarian and human rights situation in these areas. Against this background, I welcome Parliament's resolution, which supports a global operation against ISIL/Da'ish and other extremist terrorists in the Middle East and North Africa. However, the protection of civilians should be of central importance here.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — Humanitarian assistance in Iraq and Syria can only be done properly in good cooperation with local authorities. This is what is practiced in Iraq, whether with the Baghdad government or with the autonomous Kurdistan Regional Government. I regret that the same is not true of the Syrian government. I regret that this resolution sends back to back the terrorist group "Islamic State" and the Syrian government, which is the first to fight it on the ground. Furthermore, I regret that only the "Islamic State" group is mentioned, while dozens of Islamist terrorist groups have the same acts on Syrian territory. For these reasons, I abstained on this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — As so often, this resolution contains plenty of text that I agree with. I utterly condemn the abuses of human rights which are going on at present in Iraq and Syria. The level of discrimination against various communities, including the Christian minority, is completely unacceptable. This resolution, however, is about more than simple condemnation of what is happening in those countries. It suggests an international foreign policy role which I simply do not believe that the EU should have. Consequently, I am abstaining on this motion.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because its rhetoric proposes some cornerstone guidelines for international action in the face of the ongoing crisis in Iraq and Syria. To begin with, the IS group, among others in this conflict, has caused incalculable human suffering through its criminal activities, thus we must act without any delay in order to provide relief and assistance to the victims affected by its actions. It is important to unequivocally condemn the actions of IS and other terrorist groups and appeal to the international community, Member States and other EU institutions to respond politically and support the humanitarian relief efforts for the peoples affected by the despicable acts of IS and other groups. Hence, I think it is crucial that this resolution also supports the global campaign against IS and welcomes the commitment of coalition partners in uniting to form a strategy to defeat IS and stop the crisis from further escalation. When diplomatic efforts are failing we need to start considering alternative strategies. In addition to this, I congratulate the resolution’s call to the international community to ensure that conditions necessary for achieving war justice are met by increasing efforts to document the atrocities of IS.

text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. "If the threat posed by the Islamic State group is to be eradicated, it is necessary to make a fair diagnosis of each other's responsibilities, so as not to make the same mistakes. Sending back-to-back the "Islamic State" group and the Syrian regime is truly irresponsible and unworthy of the abominable tragedies that are playing out today. In these circumstances, I could only abstain.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The chaotic situation in Syria and Iraq requires a collective and rapid response from the international community. The protection of civilians in general and children, women and minorities in particular, the millions of refugees living in unsustainable conditions throughout the region, respect for international humanitarian law and human rights, the cessation of massacres in general and the establishment, as soon as possible, of a climate conducive to peace are as many colossal challenges as the European Union , the United Nations and the international community must work together. Failure to respond to this situation or mishanding our response would have dramatic consequences on the ground. The Union and the Member States must live up to their values and provide a strong, unanimous and effective response.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstained on this motion for a resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, in particular in relation to the Islamic State group. It is undeniable that the war crimes of the Islamic State group, particularly against religious minorities, including Christians, must be condemned and that a strong response must be given in order to rescue the population and stem the spread of this terrorist group accused of war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity.  Nevertheless, I find it politically irresponsible to vote for this statement, which sends back to back the Islamic State group and the Syrian government.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I agree with the positions supported in this resolution, and I therefore supported it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latent conflicts in Iraq and Syria, together with the violence that is putting the threat of ISIS in the region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the European Union. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The EU must increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organizations.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) The conflict in Syria has dramatic numbers on the humanitarian front. More than 200,000 people were killed, more than ten million displaced, with about four million Syrians fleeing abroad. According to the Commission, some 276,000 refugees have tried to enter the EU. More than 200,000 Syrians have taken refuge in Iraq.  This situation dramatically crosses developments in Iraq and in the neighbouring areas of the offensive by the terrorist organisation Isil/Daesh. There are already more than two million displaced persons among the Iraqis. The situation of refugees in neighbouring countries is bordering on liveability. The situation, complicated by the rigidity of winter, is likely to worsen even further with the onset of heat, given the sanitary conditions and poor access to drinking water. I voted in favour of this resolution which, in condemning the horrific violations of the human rights of the Assad regime, Isil/Daesh and other jihadist groups, calls on the Eu ropean Union to adopt a comprehensive regional strategy to defeat Isil/Daesh and to contribute to joint efforts to mitigate the humanitarian crisis and the conflict in Syria and Iraq. We are also aware that the fundamentalist formations gaining ground in the Middle East and North Africa are intimately linked to the terrorist threat we face within the Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. —There is almost no form of human suffering and suffering that has not befallen the populations of Iraq and Syria in recent years. War, ethnic cleansing, disease, religious persecution, famine and a number of other accidents have collapsed on innocent people and unfortunately there is no indication that the suffering will soon end.  In addition to the news, Europe also encounters these accidents, or more precisely their consequences, face to face. Thousands of unfortunates fleeing Iraq and Syria have made desperation move ships towards our borders. Europe has a moral obligation to provide them with direct assistance in the form of food, medicine and other life's sub-businesses. But if we want to really help them we need to invest more resources to stop the wars raging in their countries.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. While I strongly condemn the deadly ideology and medieval practices of the Islamic State group in Iraq and the Levant, I can only regret the lack of detail on the instruments advocated against this threat.  In addition, the consequences of this new interference need to be carefully considered.  The text even evokes questions of sexual orientation, which seems far removed from the subject. I do not quite understand how the LGBT population would suffer more from the conflict than religious minorities, women or children. It is also questionable whether the Syrian regime and the Islamic State group should be on an equal footing. I condemn the abuses of the Islamic State group, but consider it irresponsible to put it on the same level as an internationally recognized government. So I abstained.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour since the situation in Iraq and Syria has now become critical and hundreds of civilians are suffering because of it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the Humanitarian Crisis in Iraq and Syria, particularly in the context of Islamic State (IS), because Islamic State poses a threat to the peoples of these countries and endangers the security of European states.   The IS crisis has caused an unprecedented situation, leaving behind millions of refugees and people in need of emergency assistance. By interpreting the law of the Shasion, acts of barbarism are committed daily against the members of religions other than the Muslim one.     When thousands of supporters of the fundamentalist movement in the Member States have voluntarily joined is forces, this leads to a phenomenon that is increasingly worrying about us. The tragedy in Paris revealed that the radicalisation of European Islamists could have originated in prisons in Europe, where they were serving their sentences for minor offences. I categorically condemn the atrocities committed by Islamic State and believe that we should act decisively against those who commit massacres against innocent citizens. I believe that a measure such as the revocation of citizenship would be a firm response against those who want to shake the values of contemporary civilization with unprecedented terrorist attacks.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. ISIS is made up of beasts and must be annihilated.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. - I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latent conflicts in Iraq and Syria, together with the violence that is putting the threat of ISIS in the region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the European Union. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria is unprecedented. The involvement of the Islamic State group is of course undeniable. Human rights are violated on a daily basis with terrible violence. Women and children are treated like slaves. The girls are forcibly married to fighters from the Islamic State group. All those who do not respect the commandments of the Islamic State group are killed or beaten. We cannot allow such atrocities to be done. We must continue to provide both military and humanitarian assistance to the region. We need a coordinated European response to this problem. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, particularly in the context of IS. The resolution also highlighted how the atrocities and violence perpetrated by the so-called Islamic State, which has launched a campaign of systematic ethnic cleansing in northern Syria and Iraq, have plunged the people of northern Syria and Iraq into terror, forcing thousands of people to flee.  Given the complexity of the problem, it is therefore becoming increasingly important that the European Union's strategy should include an integrated approach capable of combining military, political, humanitarian and development aspects. The European Union is therefore obliged to provide humanitarian assistance and to make its contribution in the fight against extremism in the region. At the same time, it is crucial that the EU supports its neighbours, in particular Jordan and Lebanon, so that they can cope with the influx of refugees and the threat of the Islamic State.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — It is estimated that there are more than three million displaced persons in Syria alone and that about three billion dollars would be needed to respond adequately to the humanitarian crisis. The response to the ISIS threat must be addressed by giving priority to resolving the humanitarian crisis and the measures to be implemented to limit its long-term negative effects.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. — The humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria is a real tragedy for the populations concerned: persecuted Christians, mass displacement of populations who are now forced to live far from home in appalling conditions of unsanitary conditions. We cannot stand in the way of this tragedy. The resolution also had the merit of underlining the responsibility of countries such as Qatar and Saudi Arabia in financing the Islamic State group. However, I had to abstain on this resolution, which refers back to back the crimes of the "Islamic State" group with the , admittedly imperfect - regime of Bashar al-Assad. The persecution guided by the fanaticism of the "Islamic State" group cannot be compared with the actions of the Syrian government. It is, from a geopolitical point of view, to take the risk of losing a valuable ally in the fight against terrorism.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because both situations have caused a humanitarian disaster of enormous proportions. I have also considered the additional problem that many refugees and internally displaced persons are not registered, which prevents them from accessing the necessary humanitarian aid and basic protection measures. I strongly condemn the horrific, systematic and widespread violations of human rights and the abuses committed by all parties, and in particular all forms of violence against people on the basis of their religious and ethnic affiliation and violence against women.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — The EU must act in unison and resolutely against terror and develop a stronger capacity on internal security. We must reach out to the people of Iraq and Syria and provide whatever help and assistance we are able to.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I can only express my concern at this wave of rampant violence which has led to an unprecedented humanitarian disaster in recent years, where the violation of human rights is the order of the day, especially to the detriment of women and children. Children who, according to a report by the UN Committee of 4 February, are kidnapped as sex slaves, enlisted as soldiers, killed, crucified and even buried alive. These atrocities have reached their climax. We need a response from the international community to military action. It is essential to keep military and humanitarian actions separate, which serve to alleviate the suffering of civilians encircled by the conflict, people who must be protected and to whom medical and psychological assistance must be provided. I also hope that appropriate legal action will be taken as soon as possible against all citizens of the Member States who decide to join these terrorist groups, because the advance of terrorism also affects the European Union.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which condemns the human rights abuses and violations committed by IS in Iraq and Syria against civilians and hostages because of their ethnic or political background, religion, belief or gender. The resolution also stresses that IS not only poses a threat to the people of Iraq and Syria but also to the security of European countries, and calls on the international community to provide more humanitarian aid and assistance to the people affected by the crisis.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because we must strongly condemn the violent conduct of civilians and, in particular, of minors who are buried alive, crucified and sold as slaves on the sex market. I express my growing concern at the deteriorating humanitarian and human rights situation in Syria and Iraq and the violations of international humanitarian law by IS. In addition to the condemnations and the hope that IS will stop these practices, a concrete and real way of intervening would be to welcome these children into our countries. We must not wait for them to arrive in the hold of a ship or under a lorry, but to organize a way to welcome them. We are at a crossroads where we can continue to arm and support the people with humanitarian aid or try to find a solution on the ground. For example, an attempt could be made to establish a 'buffer-neutral' zone for refugees. All this with the hope that peace may one day shine in that territory too.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The adopted resolution contains elements that are difficult to be against, such as the clear condemnation of human rights violations committed by ISIS/Daesh terrorists and their related groups in Syria and Iraq. In this area, concerns are expressed about the progressive deterioration of the humanitarian situation, especially that of domestic refugees. However, the roots of the problem are not included in the resolution. There is no reference to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which was key not only to the humanitarian crisis it triggered, but because it initiated a trend of annihilation of secular states in the Middle East that favored religious factions. Without addressing the roots of the problem, similar situations may be repeated elsewhere in the globe in the future, which is why I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — The ongoing violence in Syria has led to an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe in recent years, with more than 200,000 people killed, most of them civilians. More than 12.2 million Syrians and more than 5.2 million people are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance in Iraq. There are 3.6 million people living and in need of help in areas controlled by Islamic State.  Islamic State poses a threat to the Iraqi and Syrian people and an integrated approach to the military, political, humanitarian and development dimension is needed to deal with this threat. The EU is the first donor to the victims of the crisis in Syria, with more than EUR 3.2 billion already allocated. The EU will unlock an additional one billion euros over the next two years to deal with the crises in Syria and Iraq, as well as to counter the threat posed by Islamic State. These funds must enable the financing of a global strategy consisting of political, social and humanitarian measures targeting Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey.  At the same time, the allocated funds must contribute to the fight against terrorism, in particular strengthening the actions of the Member States and the EU with a view to restricting the influx of foreign combatants and helping countries in the region in the fight against violent extremism.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — Today, we are facing the biggest humanitarian crisis of our era with the long-lasting conflict in Syria. Since the beginning of the conflict in Syria, almost half of the Syrians have been forced to leave their homes and flee for their lives in search of safety. And the situation is deteriorating every day. They are forced to live in extremely poor conditions. Hundreds of thousands of Iraqis share the same fate. For many, it is not the first time. I strongly support this parliamentary report addressing the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria with priority and urgency, and find it highly important to achieve the de-escalation of violence as a basis for a broader political process.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — It is regrettable that there are so many situations of human rights violations and that the lives of educated, professionally active women and, in particular, women who have run for public office, are at risk only because they want to be involved professionally, and that the majority of refugee and displaced children do not have access to education. I join my colleagues who strongly condemn acts of torture and express my deep estrepaying sympathy for the victims of atrocities committed in those regions.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament strongly condemns by this resolution the systematic, brutal and widespread violations of human rights committed by both the regime of Bashar al-Assad in Syria and by the terrorists of Daesh and other jihadist groups in Iraq and Syria. In view of the deteriorating humanitarian and human rights situation in the region, it is crucial that the European Union adopts and implements a coherent comprehensive regional strategy to stop Daesh, coordinate efforts to alleviate the humanitarian crisis and end the conflict in Syria and Iraq. Since there is an interdependence between conflict, humanitarian suffering and radicalisation, the elimination of the terrorist threat must be a priority and for these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the face of the horror of the violence perpetrated by the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria, Parliament had a duty to condemn this barbarity in the strongest terms. In particular, it was essential to recall the European Union's strong support in the face of a catastrophic humanitarian situation. I welcome the vote by a very large majority of this resolution. The increase in the departures of radicalised European citizens who will join the ranks of the Islamic State group poses a serious danger to Europe. I am therefore very much in favour of the development of a common strategy in Europe for the surveillance and control of jihadists and radicalised citizens.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — The armed conflicts in Syria and Iraq are a considerable challenge for Europe and for the world, in that they touch deep within our conception of man and its supreme value. It is essential to fight militarily against the group "Islamic State" in order to reduce terror. All EU states must now be stakeholders in this initiative, and show their willingness to build a genuine common defence policy.  But we need to do more, also on the humanitarian front.  Humanitarian corridors must be established to ensure that food arrives, to help Syria's neighbouring countries, especially Lebanon, which has been destabilized by a 25% increase in its population.  We also need to act economically. It is absolutely necessary to cut off the financial resources of the Islamic State group, to put in place an embargo on the oil it exploits.  We must act, of course, politically. Prioritize our enemies, especially in Syria. And bring together all the countries of the region, from Saudi Arabia to Iran, through Turkey, around the table.

name: Karima DELLI
text: In writing. — The human and humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria must force all European states and the world to respond. Too many human lives have been sacrificed for nothing; it is our duty as elected representatives to encourage Europe to react. Its action is still too slow and too minimal for us to be satisfied with.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution condemning the violence perpetrated by the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria and calling for more support from the Commission and the international community to help the victims. This humanitarian crisis is one of the most serious in contemporary history. Nearly 20 million people in the region are in urgent need of assistance.  I also had the opportunity to contribute to the drafting of this text and to add some considerations relating to atrocities committed against children, which was outlined in a recent report by the UN Committee on the Rights of Children.  These children are enlisted and forced to become child soldiers. They are also used as informants, human shields and even as suicide bombers. This is particularly the case for children with mental disabilities. Children belonging to Christian and Yazidi minorities are systematically murdered or become sex slaves sold in the markets with price tags. The 18 experts of the Committee on the Rights of the Child also report cases of mass execution of boys, but also of children beheaded, crucified or buried alive.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We are voting against because there is no global campaign; there are simply some countries that are currently fighting against the Islamic Caliphate, although most of these countries are the same ones that indirectly or directly in some cases raised and equipped the Caliphate. In any case, therefore, we consider their attitude to be hypocritical and that they simply aim to serve their own interests again.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. — I supported this resolution condemning the shocking human rights violations in Iraq and Syria. The current crisis in Syria, as a result of violence by the Assad regime and terrorist groups, has triggered a humanitarian catastrophe that has reached an unprecedented scale. The humanitarian situation in Iraq, caused by the current conflict and the violence and repression of the terrorist organization ISIL/Daesh, translates into some 5.2 million people in urgent need of humanitarian aid and more than 2.1 million Iraqis who are internally displaced. The deterioration of the humanitarian situation is worrying. Given the tremendous complexity and scale of this problem, the EU needs to take a comprehensive strategy to combat ISIL/Daesh and contribute to joining global efforts to alleviate the humanitarian crisis and end the conflict in Syria and Iraq and its international ramifications.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The current crisis of violence in Syria has left more than 200,000 dead, mostly civilians, has caused more than 7.6 million displaced people and 12.2 million refugees. According to humanitarian organizations on the ground, more than 5.2 million people need help and there are many refugees and displaced people who are not on the register. The terrorist organisation behind these attacks, ISIL/Daesh, has summarily executed citizens and launched systematic campaigns of ethnic cleansing in northern Iraq and Syria with a particular focus on women and girls. I therefore condone the shocking, systematic and widespread abuses and violations of human rights in both countries, expressing my concern at the deteriorating humanitarian and human rights situation in these two countries.
