The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — We are concerned about the serious political and social situation currently in Syria and Iraq. For our part, we also condemn all the freedoms and fundamental rights of these peoples and the criminal practices of torture and indiscriminate murder and persecution of minorities carried out by fascist and far-right ideology groups such as IS or al-Qaeda, as well as the crimes resulting from the aggression that the US and its eu and its allies in the region carry out. This situation is inseparable from new and old processes of aggression and invasion of Iraq and the interference and destabilisation of Syria, as well as the occupation and aggression of Israel, processes that rely on the complicity and support of the majority of Parliament, in the face of international law and the UN Charter. This resolution is part of the campaign of lies and hypocrisy of those who supported the promotion, financing and armament of groups that continue to provoke barbarism and destruction, extending it to several countries in the region. At the heart of this problem is the deepening crisis of capitalism and the race for geostrategic dominance and energy resources in which this region is rich.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The human rights situation in Syria and Iraq has deteriorated significantly in recent months and violations of international humanitarian law are being violated. The people of Iraq and Syria are a daily wartime conflict, as well as a threat from ISIL. It is therefore essential that a comprehensive regional strategy for the Middle East is adopted as a matter of speed. The surrounding countries must stop the oil trade, which generates considerable financial revenues for ISIL. A large number of Citizens of the Member States have joined ISIL fighters and pose a significant danger to the European Union. Jihadists therefore need to be subjected to greater control over their movements by the European security services and agencies. The international community must step up its efforts to alleviate the suffering of millions of Syrians and Iraqis who lack basic food and medicine and are trampled on by their human rights.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the resolution condemning the crimes committed by IS in Iraq and Syria.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria because of the islamic state's violence, because there is no global campaign, there are simply some countries that are currently fighting against the Islamic Caliphate, although most of these countries are the same ones that indirectly or directly in some cases have raised and equipped the Caliphate. In any case, therefore, I consider their attitude to be hypocritical and that they are simply intended to serve their own interests again.  There are more serious problems in the area that should worry us.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because the humanitarian situation in Iraq, Syria and neighbouring countries is devastating. The spread of the Daesh (IS) group has led to one of the gravest humanitarian crises in contemporary history which must be confronted with every possible means. I support the creation of a broader coalition against the Daesh terrorist group, to include any nation that is willing to defend the rights of peoples to be free from fear and to live in dignity. I agree with the position that only a genuine and inclusive process of national reconciliation between different ethnic and religious groups in Syria and Iraq can be a solution to defeat the threat of Daesh.  I believe that, in order to reach this objective, the coalition must include the Sunni population and gain their support. We must not underestimate the vital threat Daesh poses to the populations of Iraq and Syria. The international community, altogether with the Iraqi security forces, the Iraqi Kurdish fighters (the Peshmergas) and the Syrian democratic forces must fight and defeat Daesh, in order to put an end to the humanitarian crisis, avoids any further loss of lives and reinstate the peace in the region.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — Violence in Syria, as a result of the Assad regime and ISIS terrorist violence, has led to an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe, with more than 200,000 killed, most of them civilians, more than 7.6 million internally displaced people, as well as more than 3.8 million Syrians who have fled their country. Similarly, the humanitarian and security situation continues to deteriorate in Iraq as a result of the actions of the terrorist group ISIS, which has undertaken systematic campaigns of ethnic cleansing, war crimes and serious violations of international humanitarian law in the territories under its control. Europe is aware of the serious threat to the entire isIS region, so we must adopt a comprehensive regional strategy to defeat it, ending the sources of funding for terrorism, arms supply and the transnational flow of foreign fighters. It is essential to protect civilians from this senseless barbarism that is causing so much suffering. Europe cannot afford to look the other way, we must put all means at our disposal to achieve the ultimate defeat of terrorism.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. The EU must increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organizations.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - The war inflameing Syria and Iraq is likely to have a devastating impact on the human rights situation in the two countries, not only in this phase of conflict but also in the long term in these now battered lands. With this joint resolution, for which I am voting in favour, Parliament is sending a strong and urgent message to the Member States to make every effort, as far as possible in a difficult phase of conflict, to support the neighbouring countries that are now engaged in supporting the humanitarian emergency. The European Union, in agreement with the United Nations and other forces in the region, must now propose an ambitious strategy to facilitate as far as possible humanitarian support actions and the basis for future reconstruction.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. — Atrocities committed by Islamic State are unspeakable and we need to do all that is in our power to stop them. Tackling IS will require military action and draining their financial resources, but also supporting state building and inclusive policies in the region.  Last but not least we need to develop an understanding of how IS has been able to come into existence to make sure we can stop similar events from happening ever again. Here it is important to note that the Assad regime has played a crucial role in fostering the development of IS. The fact that he is now painting a picture of his regime as the only alternative to terrorism is belied by the fact that in 2014, just 6% of regime air strikes targeted IS. Meanwhile his regime has been indiscriminately bombing civilians, as shown by recent events in the city of Douma, where a barrel bomb campaign by the Syrian army killed at least 18 people and caused indescribable suffering among civilians.  If we want to bring an end to the humanitarian crisis in the region, we need to adopt a foreign policy that looks at the full picture. Unfortunately, we are not there yet today.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. — The humanitarian crisis is growing in Iraq and Syria as a result of the abuses committed by the Islamic State group. These abuses can only be stopped if they cooperate with local authorities. This is what is practiced in Iraq, with the central government as well as with the Kurdish regional government. It is time to do the same with Syria to help Damascus cope with the humanitarian disaster caused by terrorist groups. The European Union and the Member States must re-establish diplomatic contacts with Syria and reopen their embassies in Damascus, as the new Syrian government has just done. The normalization of diplomatic relations with Syria is an indispensable condition for ensuring humanitarian cooperation, but also in security, with the Syrian services, which will enable us to fight jihadist networks.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. The joint resolution to be adopted does not refer to the real causes that are the source of the current situation in Iraq and Syria. The joint resolution condemns acts of violence, as well as the violation of human rights and ethnic minorities; however, it accuses the Syrian regime of crimes committed in Syria, including the use of chemical weapons against civilians and arbitrary arrests, among other atrocities. It calls for action from the European institutions to increase the level of control and security within European borders to combat Islamist terrorism and strengthen the exchange of information between Member States. It does not, therefore, take into account that one of the causes of the conflict concerns interference by Western powers, especially U.S. intervention in Iraq. That is why we have decided to abstain.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. — I voted strongly for this resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, especially in the light of the Islamic State group. The resolution strongly condemns human rights violations and violations committed by the regime of Bashar al-Assad and terrorists of the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria. It then proposes several avenues and makes several urgent requests: that the European Union have a real comprehensive regional strategy, that the European Commission make a greater financial contribution to respond to this unprecedented crisis, that the international community become more involved. She also stresses, and this is a point that is particularly close to my heart, about the situation of children and girls who are victims of sexual violence every day. More than 200,000 people have been killed in Syria, more than 7.6 million people have been displaced in Syria, 5.2 million people in Iraq are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, etc. We need a rapid response to this humanitarian crisis, the violence and horrors, the barbarity that people on the ground face.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — The appalling human rights abuses and violations of international humanitarian law that have been committed by IS and associated terrorist groups are resulting in a growing humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq; these abuses and violations are war crimes and crimes against humanity. I condemn these acts in the strongest possible terms.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution. There is an urgent need for the international community to live up to its commitments by strengthening humanitarian assistance and assistance to the millions of people affected by the crisis in Iraq and Syria, especially in the harsh winter in the region. The European Union must develop a comprehensive regional strategy to block the Islamic State group, to help alleviate the humanitarian crisis and to end the conflict in both Syria and Iraq. This strategy includes supporting refugee-hosting countries, working with regional partners to combat terrorist financing, arms deliveries and the influx of foreign fighters, and combating extremist violence. Finally, I believe that accountability for serious crimes committed by all parties during the conflict, including crimes on religious or ethnic grounds, must be established for a lasting peace to be achieved.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latent conflicts in Iraq and Syria, together with the violence that is putting the threat of ISIS in the region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the European Union. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — In a world on fire, where conflicts are cross-border without a clear separation between good forces and evil forces, we must look for solutions.  Until now, military intervention in distant countries with cultures other than ours has exacerbated conflicts and left countries in chaos. Who are the coalition partners? Who exactly are our allies and enemies and which countries are doubly in it? How best to combat acts of terrorism? Is that with fighter jets or are there other means?  We will have to monitor the situation in Syria closely with the international legal community, but if we really want to show compassion for the victims of the civil war, we must above all provide aid to Syrian refugees. The sense of anger and the impotence that we all feel is understandable but does not justify ill-considered military action. Fear is a bad counselor, but feelings of anger and retribution are just as much.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. — International organisations estimate that more than 17.5 million Syrians and Iraqis are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, 10 million of whom are internally displaced due to armed confrontations and the danger of being trapped in areas brutally controlled by the Islamic State terrorist movement. The so-called "sharia courts", set up to impose punishments with amputation, stoning and crucifixion, as well as war crimes and campaigns of ethnic cleansing, complete the specter of unleashed barbarity in northern Iraq and Syria.  That is why I support the call for the EU to adopt and implement a regional strategy to annihilate the Islamic State group and to act more effectively to alleviate the humanitarian crisis, which is compounded by a difficult winter and the risk of epidemics, amid poor sanitary conditions. I find it revolting that the World Food Programme has had to temporarily suspend a food aid programme for 1.7 million Syrian refugees due to a crisis in international funding. Without a massive and urgent international effort, we will face a double catastrophe in the Middle East, humanitarian and security, which will directly affect the EU by increasing instability in the immediate vicinity, increasing illegal migration and exacerbating the terrorist threat on the territory of the Member States.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — The situation caused by the Islamic State is very serious. It is clear that we Europeans and the international community must do everything possible to allow refugees to return to their homeland as soon as possible. This requires a huge joint effort. Given the seriousness of the crisis, we must also see, unfortunately, that peace cannot be made in northern Iraq without a military solution. If Europe and international organisations cannot succeed in providing assistance, we face a very serious, even irreversible, humanitarian catastrophe in the region. I trust that we will have the strength to do so, together with the local communities: Muslims, Christians or Yazids. We must preserve a 2,000-year-old Christian culture in the Middle East, which is now in danger of being completely eradicated.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. The joint resolution to be adopted does not refer to the real causes that are the source of the current situation in Iraq and Syria. The joint resolution condemns acts of violence, as well as the violation of human rights and ethnic minorities; however, it accuses the Syrian regime of crimes committed in Syria, including the use of chemical weapons against civilians and arbitrary arrests, among other atrocities. It calls for action from the European institutions to increase the level of control and security within European borders to combat Islamist terrorism and strengthen the exchange of information between Member States. It does not, therefore, take into account that one of the causes of the conflict concerns interference by Western powers, especially U.S. intervention in Iraq. That is why we have decided to abstain.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the resolution and I think all Members of the Parliament should condemn the actions of the Islamic State. Any campaign to liberate the territories under ISIL control should adhere strictly to international humanitarian law and international human rights law, in order to avoid more loss of life and feeding the extremist agenda. I would like to point out that, taking into account the unprecedented scale of the crisis, millions of Syrians and Iraqis are in need of basic goods and services, and this must be a priority for the EU and the international community at large.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, especially in the context of IS. With the political and security catastrophe we have in this area, it is an extremely tragic humanitarian situation. Hundreds of thousands of people who have left their homes in the face of the horrors of war have the right to humanitarian aid and the care of the European Union until realistic political and security conditions are created for refugees to return to their homes.  I called on the Commission, member states and other countries relevant to resolving this conflict, not primarily the US, Russia and Turkey, to fully engage in resolving this unsustainable situation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. — Humanitarian assistance in Iraq and Syria can only be done properly in good cooperation with local authorities. This is what is practiced in Iraq, whether with the Baghdad government or with the autonomous Kurdistan Regional Government. I regret that the same is not true of the Syrian government. I regret that this resolution sends back to back the terrorist group "Islamic State" and the Syrian government, which is the first to fight it on the ground. Furthermore, I regret that only the "Islamic State" group is mentioned, while dozens of Islamist terrorist groups have the same acts on Syrian territory. For these reasons, I abstained on this text.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. — Systematic human rights violations and abuses against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups are causing a dramatic humanitarian crisis. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. More than 2.1 million people moved to Iraq in 2014 and UNCHR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the EU to move forward on a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. In addition, for consistency with its own values, the EU should develop a special reception plan for these refugees that includes the distribution of its beneficiaries among the 28 countries of the Union.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. — I am deeply concerned about the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria. Given the increasing power of ISIS in the region we are seeing ever more refugees fleeing the region in fear of their lives. We need to offer support to these people and to address the crisis with any available means we have at our disposal.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the humanitarian crises in Iraq and Syria caused by the atrocities perpetrated by the Islamic State group, as well as by all the jihadist groups active in those countries. The resolution calls for increased humanitarian aid to civilians, an international donor conference and the development of a comprehensive European strategy for the region, including to stop these terrorist groups.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, in particular in the IS context’ because we agree in principle.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — Since the beginning of the conflict in Syria, almost half of the Syrians have been forced to leave their homes and flee for their lives in search of safety. They are the victims of President Bashar al-Assad and now they are forced to live in extremely poor conditions. Hundreds of thousands of Iraqis share the same fate. Addressing the humanitarian crisis must be a priority and urgency, as the situation is deteriorating every day, and should be part of our strategic fight against ISIS. It is important to achieve a de-escalation of violence as a basis for a broader political process. It is, however, even more crucial that we sever the problem from the roots, increasing pressure on the Assad regime and assist Iraq in advancing the political process of inclusivity that is so critical to resolve the crisis.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — The conflict currently taking place in Iraq and Syria, which are occupied by the so-called Islamic State , is not the only one that has been eliminated. Islamic State (IS) is one of the most complex in the world today and is full of bad news. In IS territory, there is a very harsh interpretation of Sharia law, violence against civilians, the killing of hostages, torture and other crimes against human rights. The GUE/NGL faction proposed amendments to the resolution to help the European Parliament to perceive the problem in its entireas. For example, we wanted to include in the resolution the words of Kofi Annan, who called the US invasion of Iraq a mistake and one of the reasons for the current crisis. We also wanted to remind you that NATO is trying to assume competences that are solely for the UN General Assembly, respectively. the UN Security Council. I consider it important that the EU understands the complexity of the whole issue so that it can deal with the situation more effectively and, if possible peacefully, without further military intervention in an area already war-torn and unstable. However, the joint motion for a resolution did not contain these parameters, which is why I decided to abstain. I appreciate the humanitarian aid that the EU provides to Syrian refugees, but I am saddened that we are failing to prevent 2% of refugees entering EU countries via the Mediterranean from finding death in these waters.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — What is happening in Syria and Iraq is shocking the whole world. We strongly condemn the systematic and widespread human rights violations committed by both the Assad regime and Isis terrorism, forcing millions of people to leave their homes. An unprecedented humanitarian crisis, in need of more immediate and more aid. That is why we are calling for a new donors' conference to be convened so that the commitments made can be fulfilled as soon as possible. With this vote, we reaffirm the need for the European Union to have a comprehensive regional strategy to defeat Isis, to help mitigate the effects of this humanitarian crisis and to put an end to the conflict that is upsetting Iraq and Syria. A strategy that must also take into account the necessary aid to those countries that receive refugees from the conflict, without forgetting, however, that only by arriving at a political transition in Syria and a truly inclusive government in Iraq will the region be able to embark on the path of peace.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this report because it conveys a message of condemnation of the heinous forms of violence perpetrated by IS both in Iranian and Syrian territories. More than 7.6 million Syrians remained internally displaced and a further 3.8 million fled to neighbouring areas. I believe that the EU must, with all its might, combat the terrorist phenomenon through a shared commitment involving all the main players in the international community, in defence of democracy and human rights.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The unprecedented humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq, which has affected the lives of millions of people and is still unthrct, requires a unified and clear response from the international community. Terrorist groups in the Middle East region despise the fundamental values of the EU and the international community as a whole, and the serious crimes against humanity committed or committed by terrorists pose a major challenge to the entire international legal system.  It is very important to stress that the various violations of humanitarian law that are currently being committed, both in the European Union's immediate neighbourhood and in the Middle East region or beyond, must be stopped as soon as possible and those responsible must be brought to justice. We cannot allow the fundamental principles of international law to be broken without any concrete consequences. I therefore support this European Parliament resolution, while condemning the brutal human rights violations committed by the Assad regime and the terrorists of the so-called Islamic State, and calling on the international community to make every effort to de-escalate the situation in Syria and Iraq.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. — I supported the joint resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria because it gives an uncompromising assessment of the abuses of the Islamic State group against the populations under its control and calls for determined action against this entity. I welcome the fact that this resolution calls for a comprehensive strategy against the Islamic State group, including the sources of its funding, including those derived from oil smuggling, something I had requested as early as September 2014. I also support the request for assistance and protection of civilians in humanitarian and international law, as proposed in this text. Unfortunately, the resolution ignores one of the causes of the current catastrophic situation: the invasion of Iraq in 2003. Nevertheless, this call for determined action against the "Islamic State" group must be supported. That is why I voted in favour of this text. Especially since it also addresses the issue of the plight of refugees from this region, calling for additional efforts for rescues at sea and for their reception.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. — National Front MPs abstained on the resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria because it puts the terrorists of the Islamic State group and the Syrian government, as critical as it may be, on the same level. Apparently, the established political groups in this Parliament, as well as the US Government, the Commission and the Council, have learned no lessons from their interference in several Arab countries. In wanting to support the so-called Arab Spring, they have actually supported, or even (at least indirectly) armed terrorist groups such as the "Islamic State" group. There is no self-criticism in the resolution put to the vote. Yet the consequences of the political choices of the United States and the European Union on Iraq and Syria are catastrophic. The list of atrocious and inhumane crimes committed by the jihadists is innumerable: mass executions, beheadings, stonings, crucifixions, acts of ethnic and religious cleansing.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " The hot conflicts in Iraq and Syria, along with the violence in the ISIS region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the EU. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The alud of refugees in the region, which began years ago, with the Arab Spring, has received an insufficient response from the EU, both for the economic resources provided and for the number of refugees welcomed in Europe. The large number of refugees is complicating the maintenance of refugee camps in neighbouring Syria and Iraq. In addition, tensions are emerging between refugees and local communities over the lack of resources and the collapse of the public institutions of host countries.

text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters.
