In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The adopted resolution contains elements that are difficult to be against, such as the clear condemnation of human rights violations committed by ISIS/Daesh terrorists and their related groups in Syria and Iraq. In this area, concerns are expressed about the progressive deterioration of the humanitarian situation, especially that of domestic refugees. However, the roots of the problem are not included in the resolution. There is no reference to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which was key not only to the humanitarian crisis it triggered, but because it initiated a trend of annihilation of secular states in the Middle East that favored religious factions. Without addressing the roots of the problem, similar situations may be repeated elsewhere in the globe in the future, which is why I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — On the security front, the situation in Iraq and Syria is deteriorating by the day. Residents of these two states face mass killings, torture and kidnappings because of their political and religious beliefs.  The victims are mostly civilians, women and children.  Stronger reactions from the European Union and international organisations are necessary and I have supported this resolution, which calls for urgent action to help prevent terror, protect human rights, protect citizens from torture and other cruel and inhumane acts. It is of utmost importance that the international community provides additional humanitarian assistance and financial support to countries affected by IS terror and to take steps to prevent its activities from continuing.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. What is happening now in Iraq and Syria is simply atrocities. Turning the heads of innocent people and proclaiming it as the single most correct way of life in the world is unacceptable. It seemed to me that the resolution contained an unfortunate wording on sexual minorities, but overall I supported this resolution. But what is happening in Iraq and Syria after the actual overthrow of previous regimes is, by its very nature, a major mistake of the European Union, and we are already facing the consequences. All this could have been predicted 5-10 years ago.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. I welcome the european Union's new strategy called 'Elements for an EU regional strategy for Syria, Iraq and the threat posed by DAESH'. The €1 billion financial package for 'restoring peace and security in a region devastated by violence and terrorist actions' is an important, necessary tool in combating terrorism and supporting peace. I support the global campaign against ISIL/DAESH and congratulate the strong commitment of the partners in this coalition to concrete actions within a common and coordinated long-term strategy. This strategy should provide for humanitarian and development assistance mechanisms for countries in the region, as well as programmes to combat extremism and de-structuring terrorist financing schemes. In order to combat terrorism within the EU effectively, it is essential that we make every effort to eliminate the escalating extremist terrorist threat in the Middle East and North Africa and fuel the phenomenon of radicalisation in the EU. I welcome the call of the UN Human Rights Council, addressed to the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, for the urgent deployment of a mission to Iraq to investigate abuses committed by ISIL/DAESH and its associated terrorist groups in connection with the human rights violations laid down by international law rules.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. - The humanitarian situation in Syria and Iraq is not hopeless but urgent. The EU’s new strategy ‘Elements for an EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the Daesh threat’ and its financial assistance package of 1 billion euros, 40% of which will be channelled in the form of life-saving humanitarian assistance within Syria and Iraq as well as neighbouring countries hosting Syrian refugees, are important steps for increasing the EU’s effectiveness and contribution. This new aid package is especially timely and important considering that vaccine-preventable infectious diseases are spreading across Syria and Iraq due to the collapse of the health system and lack of basic sanitation. In addition to the dangerous outbreak of polio, other communicable diseases like hepatitis A, the parasitic infection leishmaniasis, typhoid and measles have all been rising. Spread of these diseases poses a threat to the neighbouring countries such as Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon, which provide refuge to thousands of displaced people. It is the EU’s responsibility to extend its help to its partners in tackling this humanitarian emergency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Syria, particularly in relation to the Islamic State, because the European Parliament notes clearly and unequivocally, on the one hand, that many refugees and internally displaced persons have not been registered and, on the other hand, that un logged populations are excluded from much-needed humanitarian aid.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the situation in Iraq and Syria because, first of all, it sends out a message of strong condemnation of the unacceptable acts of violence perpetrated by IS in the area which includes the two countries and under its control. The ongoing conflicts in Iraq and the violent crisis in Syria have caused an unprecedented catastrophe in history. More than 7.6 million Displaced Syrians, while a further 3.8 million have fled to neighbouring countries. I believe it is necessary for the European Union, an example of civilisation and social development, not to miss an opportunity to declare itself an enemy of anyone who carries out repressive activities against the weakest. The advance of the terrorist organisation, followed by the deflagration of a real crisis within these countries, must be countered, as indicated in the resolution, through a shared commitment involving all the main players in the international community. In this regard, I welcome the new strategy promoted by the EU in support of Syria and Iraq against the threat of IS and, in particular, the EUR 1 billion package intended to contribute to peace and security within the area.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This text on the humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria gives a relatively informed view of the dire situation of people affected by the conflict in the Syrian-Iraqi area. Twelve million Syrians (out of a population of 22 million) are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, and 4 million have left the country. The situation is also catastrophic for Iraqi refugees who have fled the advance of the Islamic State group. But, as usual, these goals, full of good feelings, go hand in hand with full support for the U.S.-led coalition in the region. The text remains silent on the causes of this situation and the responsibilities, first of all those of the United States, which, since its invasion in 2003, have stoked ethno-confessional divisions in Iraq, without which the "Islamic State" group would never have been able to meet its military successes. I abstain from opposing requests for humanitarian aid in the area, without approving the political inconsistency of this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria is of great concern to all and the EU must take serious action to resolve it as soon as possible. The Islamic State cannot continue to act with impunity, reapering the lives of innocent people in a barbaric way. The EU must join forces with its allies to combat this situation which is jeopardising stability and peace in that region and leading to thousands of refugees in a situation of real humanitarian crisis.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This resolution expresses the Parliament’s support for the global campaign against ISIL and its long-term strategy to subdue the threat posed by extremists. The resolution also draws attention to the need to expedite the processing of asylum applications of refugees fleeing the conflict zones. It is essential that Member States support the countries most affected by the mass arrival of irregular migrants and asylum seekers on their shores.  Therefore, I have voted in favour of this resolution as it pledges more support for the efforts to defeat ISIL and alleviate the suffering of those affected by the extremist militants. Member States should also do their utmost to prevent further unnecessary deaths in the Mediterranean and share the responsibility of hosting the refugees fleeing the conflict.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing — The ongoing humanitarian crisis in Syria has driven more than 7.6 million people to displace, with more than 12.2 million Syrians in need of immediate assistance. There are more than 5.2 million people in Iraq, with 2.1 million Iraqis driven from their homes. The international community must therefore start to act actively and, in the current difficult winter, in particular, strengthen immediate humanitarian aid and assistance to the millions of people affected. At the same time, however, the necessary steps must be taken to defeat the so-called Islamic State, which deliberately and systematically commits human rights violations, including killings and other types of cruel violence against people on the basis of their religious or ethnicity.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — The civil war in Syria is this March 5 years. A humanitarian disaster that has killed more than 200,000 people, mostly civilians, has created more than 12.2 million refugees and 7.6 million internally displaced people.  In Iraq, one of the countries bordering Syria, the conflict and violence perpetrated by Islamic State fighters is intensifying day by day, despite the actions of the international coalition, which is in the form of aerial bombardments. Two countries that, due to their political and socio-economic instability, become places conducive to the advances of Islamic State fighters. Currently, the Islamic State has under its control a part of the territories of the Syrian state and intends to expand its caliphate in iraqi territories. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that only through common and comprehensive action can we stop this movement which commits atrocious crimes. All parties to the war must be held accountable for the crimes committed. I believe that this is the only way to establish a sustainable peace in Iraq and Syria.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I abstained on this motion for a resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, in particular with regard to the Islamic State group. It is clear that the war crimes and barbaric acts perpetrated by the Islamic State group against religious minorities (including Christians) must be strongly condemned, and that a strong response must be given in order to rescue the population and to stop the rise of this terrorist group, which has committed war crimes and ethnic cleansing. However, it is particularly geopolitically irresponsible to vote for a resolution that sends back-to-back the Islamic State group and the Syrian regime.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which warns of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Syria and Iraq and strongly condemns the barbaric abuses committed by the Islamic State group in the name of Sharia, especially against ethnic and religious minorities. The text stresses that the European Union and its Member States have already spent almost EUR 3.5 billion on humanitarian aid in Syria and Iraq, but that we must go much further, focusing all our efforts to defeat the Islamic State group and strengthen our support for the peoples of Syria and Iraq.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — The humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria continues to deteriorate day by day, with hundreds of thousands of refugees and displaced persons in need of all kinds of assistance. With this resolution, we strongly condemn the atrocities, systematic abuses and human rights violations committed in the area, the killing of hostages and the harassment of women and children. While we welcome the rapid use of the European Civil Protection Mechanism, we believe that it is still insufficient to meet the needs of the civilian populations involved. We therefore call for greater involvement of Europe, with its more important economic participation in the United Nations humanitarian programmes, and for better involvement and cooperation with the work carried out by other international organisations engaged on the ground. Perhaps the opening of a European Union office in Erbil could help to improve the visibility and effectiveness of European action and thus also promote more effective coordination of humanitarian assistance.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted and signed this resolution which strongly condemns the atrocities that have occurred in The Territory of Syria and Iraq. Through this resolution, the European Parliament expresses itself very concerned about the situation and calls on all parties involved in the crisis in the region to respect international humanitarian law, to protect civilians, ensuring that they receive medical services and humanitarian assistance, but also that they can leave the territories affected by violence in maximum safety. The EP also welcomes the EU strategy entitled 'Elements for an EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq, as well as for the threat posed by Daesh' created to ensure 'the restoration of peace and security in a region that has been devastated by terrorism and violence for too long'.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — This report describes the devastating humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq, which is being exacerbated by the violence of the IS terrorist group. Despite the good approaches to the fight against terrorism, the report contains too many unclear phrases to vote in favour. Words alone do not help those affected, and clear measures and international cooperation are called for here.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — The Syrian civil war has already created the worst humanitarian catastrophe of the 21st century. Now it has also been compounded by the horrors of ISIL in Iraq and Syria. It is important that European countries stop directing their citizens to fight for ISIL. We help our partner countries do the same. Central Asian countries, for example, are in great trouble. Stronger cooperation needs to be done with the Arab states and Turkey, which, as an EU candidate country, need to be more involved in the EU's coherent foreign policy, both in the fight against ISIL and in helping refugees. Refugees – helping them must also be a priority for EU humanitarian aid. If necessary, development aid funds must be redirected to humanitarian aid in order to alleviate the suffering of people. Stronger international restrictions must be imposed on both arms supply and transfers of funds reaching ISIL.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - The violence perpetrated by the terrorist organisation ISIL/Daesh has led to an unsustainable situation for the population in areas under terrorist control. The humanitarian catastrophe generated is unprecedented in history. In the absence of a cohesive response from the international community, ISIS has managed to capture ever larger areas of Iraqi and Syrian territory. The threat came to the West through the actions of the so-called "foreign fighters". The humanitarian crisis linked to the difficulty of creating humanitarian corridors to provide aid to people in difficulty, combined with the harsh winter, requires an immediate response on several fronts. ISIS is taking over power and has set up sharia courts in the territory under its control which, with the support of a special criminal code, impose punishments such as amputation, stoning and crucifixion against people accused of violating extremist interpretations of Islamic sharia law. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on this subject because I believe that it is only through coordinated humanitarian intervention at global level and a careful exchange of information between states that the spread of this threat, which affects the entire international community, can be limited.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: In writing. The resolution voted today by the European Parliament calls on the Union and its Member States to present a comprehensive solution to the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria. Taking into account the fact that the inadequate response of the international community to the Syrian crisis has fostered the emergence of the Islamic State group, it thus calls on us to assume our responsibilities. Following on from the European Union's new regional strategy for Syria and Iraq, as well as the threat posed by the Islamic State group, Parliament recalls the various elements that our response must include, including: the protection of civilians, assistance to refugee states, the fight against the financing of terrorism, political integration in Iraq and the processing of asylum applications. We want to stress the european Union's need for coherence and strategy in the region in the long term. This will be the subject of my report on the prospects for stability and security challenges in the region, which will remind us that the security, political, economic and social crisis it is going through can only be addressed by coordinating security, political, economic and social actions.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. — I support the resolution and I support the global campaign against IS. It is of utmost importance to forge the necessary commitment among a coalition of partners to work together under a common, multilateral and long-term strategy to defeat IS terror and on the other hand to enable more than 12 million people to return to normal life. The crisis needs fast resolution, as the situation risks turning into a major regional and international conflict. All Islamic states should be united on the matter, finding the right solutions to contain the extermination and the economic appetite of a marginal group that misuses religious and ideological purposes to work for its own interest.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — Due to the lack of robust proactive practices, first in the wars in Iraq and Syria and then accompanied by the absolute failure of international institutions to stabilise those countries in order to successfully defend themselves against the violence carried out by the Islamic State, Iraq and Syria have been brought to alarming levels of humanitarian crisis which is a threat to the health, security and well-being of members of both peoples. By 2014, more than 140,000 people had been killed in Syria, while 6,500,000 had been displaced within the state and 2,500,000 in neighbouring states. The situation in Iraq is not at all better and accordingly the UN has declared the highest level of urgency for the crisis in that country.  Almost 40% of the total refugee population is made up of Christians who are abused, persecuted and killed mercilessly in Iraq and Syria. The life of all refugees has been brought to the brink of existence – without adequate housing, clothing and food conditions, they hope and await our help. It is not enough to send only humanitarian aid, but it is necessary to achieve the highest level of cooperation in order to establish stability in Iraq and Syria and to provide all the necessary assistance and assistance to the people affected by this terrible humanitarian crisis.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — There is no point in being outraged at the abuses committed by the so-called Islamic State if the Syrian regime continues to be ostracized. This is not to say that Bashar al-Assad is blameless, of course, but defeating this particularly violent terrorist organization should be a top priority. Rather than putting the so-called Islamic State and the Syrian state on the same level, it would be better to go after the true allies of Islamic fundamentalism, starting with Qatar and Saudi Arabia. I therefore prefer to abstain on this resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) We can no longer even see the immensity of the tragedy that Syria (and Iraq) is experiencing, addicted to constant images of war coming from too many countries all over the world. The humanitarian crisis that has been unleashed as a result of the war and the expansion of IS in Syria and Iraq must find a strong response from the international community, first and foremost with a long-term strategy. Solving this crisis should be part of our strategy to defeat IS: the two go hand in hand. The huge number of people who have taken refuge in neighbouring states is putting a strain on these countries, which are already burdened with internal tensions, and if the number does not decrease in the short term this situation could further exacerbate the crisis in the Middle East region. The aid that the EU is providing and can continue to provide, also thanks to the opening of its office in Kurdistan, as announced by high representative Federica Mogherini, remains crucial. On the other hand, however, we cannot ignore the intervention of the United Nations in order to be able to refer to the International Criminal Court persons who have committed atrocious crimes against humanity in these territories. This too will be essential to ensure lasting peace in the region.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. — The scenes of brutal violence we witness every day should be a sign of urgent action by the European Union to help the victims of this unprecedented terror. This violence has taken particular hold in Iraq and Syria, where thousands of people are brought to the brink of survival and existence every day. The European Union must show full solidarity with the people who are afflicted and try to help them through urgent crisis measures. All the more so as thousands of young ISIL fighters come from the EU. In addition to urgent measures of financial and food and medicine assistance, a comprehensive development strategy is needed for the Middle East and North Africa. A military victory over dictators and terrorists alone is not enough, as it is easier to remove the top of the regime than the political, economic and social circumstances in which they were held.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The European Commission announced last week that it would allocate an additional €1 billion to address the crisis in Syria and Iraq and to counter the threat posed by the so-called Islamic State (IS). I welcome the Commission's approach to financing a "global strategy" aimed at restoring peace and security in the region, consisting of a package of political and different concrete measures for Syria and Iraq that also include assistance to Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, the countries that have taken in the largest number of refugees (Turkey 1 650 000, Lebanon 1 200 000, Jordan 600 000).  The European Commission's strategy presented is based on diplomatic action by the European Union, the development of anti-radicalisation programmes, the prevention of terrorist financing channels, combating the phenomenon of foreign fighters, and effective border control. The EU is the first donor with more than €3.2 billion, and 40% of new financial assistance is earmarked for humanitarian care for displaced persons. Due to the alarming announcement by the UN World Food Programme in December 2014 to suspend aid deliveries to Syrian refugees due to lack of funds, the EU is hereby preventing a humanitarian catastrophe and a security-political problem.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria and express my growing concern at the worsening situation in the two countries which has led to the repeated violation of international humanitarian law, as we have seen in the context of the ISIL/Daesh insurgency. I believe that we are now aware of the threat posed by ISIL/Daesh and the danger it causes throughout the region. The European Union must put in place a clear and effective strategy to defeat the ISIL/Daesh threat, resolve the humanitarian crisis and contribute to an end to the conflict in Iraq and Syria. At the same time; the European Union must find a viable and lasting solution to deal with the emergence of the increasing number of crossings into the Mediterranean of migrants from war-affected areas. It is necessary and a priority to prepare a European strategy of solidarity and support for the Member States most affected by the landings of migrants.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The situation in the Middle East has continued to worsen and the international community is easily disarmed in the face of such abuses. With this resolution, the European Parliament draws attention to the plight of refugees from Iraq and Syria. Their living conditions require special attention, and that is why I am in favour of this resolution. The action of the European Union and the countries bordering the conflict zone will only be more effective by setting priorities for action.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The current crisis of violence in Syria has triggered a humanitarian catastrophe that has reached an unprecedented scale in history, with more than 200,000 dead, mostly civilians, more than 7.6 million internally displaced persons and more than 12.2 million refugees. On the other hand, the humanitarian situation in Iraq continues to worsen, with more than 5.2 million people in urgent need of humanitarian aid and more than 2.1 million internally displaced people. Overall, the humanitarian situation has deteriorated considerably, and abuses and violations of the most basic fundamental rights have been systematic and that the parties to the conflict have used human suffering as a weapon of war and have illicitly diverted aid products, thus violating the Geneva Conventions. Unfortunately, the international community is not meeting the needs of Syrians and Iraqis. This resolution reiterates that the priority of the EU and the international community must be to alleviate the suffering of millions of Syrians and Iraqis who lack basic goods and services. It also calls for greater coordination at international level to help people in need as effectively as possible. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria after the intolerable actions of the regime of Bashar al-Assad and the terrorist group "Islamic State". I strongly condemn any violation of human rights and any violation of international humanitarian law, let alone when they are so violent.  The figures are alarming: in Syria, more than 200,000 civilians have been killed and more than 7.6 million people have been displaced. As for Iraq, more than 5.2 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance and protection.  We need to act more urgently in the face of the humanitarian crisis, but also put in place a comprehensive regional strategy with all regional actors against the Islamic State group. As we know, the political situation in this geographical area is strategic for the global fight against terrorism and for the protection of all populations, whether they are in the Middle East or In Europe.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn the systematic human rights violations and abuses committed against the people of the region by the Syrian regime, ISIS and other jihadist groups. The EU needs to move forward with a jihadist counter-terrorism security strategy that fights its financing, arms supply and the flow of transnational foreign fighters. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latent conflicts in Iraq and Syria, together with the violence that is putting the threat of ISIS in the region, are aggravating a humanitarian crisis that requires greater commitment on the part of the European Union. In numbers, more than 7.6 million Syrians have moved within the country and another 3.8 million have crossed borders into neighbouring countries, especially Turkey. In 2014, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in Iraq and UNHCR estimates that nearly 330,000 refugees spend the winter in inadequate shelters. The EU should increase its contributions to humanitarian programmes within the framework of the United Nations and improve its cooperation with international organisations.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. The joint resolution to be adopted does not refer to the real causes that are the source of the current situation in Iraq and Syria. The joint resolution condemns acts of violence, as well as the violation of human rights and ethnic minorities; however, it accuses the Syrian regime of crimes committed in Syria, including the use of chemical weapons against civilians and arbitrary arrests, among other atrocities. It calls for action from the European institutions to increase the level of control and security within European borders to combat Islamist terrorism and strengthen the exchange of information between Member States. It does not, therefore, take into account that one of the causes of the conflict concerns interference by Western powers, especially U.S. intervention in Iraq. That is why we have decided to abstain.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Due to the violence in Syria, more than 12.2 million Syrians are now desperately seeking help. In Iraq, more than 5.2 million citizens are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance and more than 2.1 million people have been internally displaced. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the international community to honour its commitments by strengthening humanitarian aid and assistance to the millions of people affected by the crisis in Iraq and Syria. The voted text also strongly condemns the systematic, brutal and widespread violations of human rights as well as the abuses committed by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the terrorists of the Islamic State group and other jihadist groups in Iraq and Syria, including the massacre of hostages. The European Union must develop a comprehensive regional strategy to block the Islamic State group, to help alleviate the humanitarian crisis, and to end the conflict in both Syria and Iraq. This strategy includes supporting refugee-hosting countries, working with regional partners to combat terrorist financing, arms deliveries and the influx of foreign fighters, and combat extremist violence.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, of which I am one of the proponents, because we are facing a truly unprecedented catastrophe, which has killed more than 200 000,000 people, mostly civilians, displaced more than 7 million and generated more than 12 million refugees, citizens absolutely in need of assistance on Syrian territory. This wave of violence has had repercussions in other countries, which have attracted thousands of refugees, such as Lebanon, Turkey, Jordan and Egypt. The same situation occurs in Iraq, with more than 5 million people in need of urgent humanitarian aid, with thousands of Syrian refugees added. The report stresses the need for the EU to adopt a regional strategy to combat terrorist organisations present in these territories, joining forces to mitigate the humanitarian crisis by providing assistance in civil, financial and security matters, trying to end the conflict in both countries.  We are facing an unsustainable situation which has destroyed thousands of human lives and must be fought vehemently not only by the European Union, but also by the entire international community, always with respect for human rights and for the protection and dignity of the human person.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The humanitarian situation in Syria and Iraq in areas controlled by the Islamic State group is alarming and I remain deeply concerned about this situation.  The actions of Bashar al-Assad's regime and terrorist groups have caused a real humanitarian catastrophe. In Syria, more than 200,000 people have been killed, more than 7.6 million people have been displaced in the country, and Iraq is home to more than 233,000 Syrian refugees.  I voted in favour of this resolution so that the European Union (EU), Member States, regional partners and the international community should continue their work. The EU has just released an additional EUR 1 billion for 2015 and 2016 to help the region and help build a lasting peace. It is also important that the EU implement as soon as possible the comprehensive strategy it has just published to combat the crises in Syria and Iraq and the threat posed by the Islamic State group.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (§ 5/1) I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution, as it supports the global campaign against ISIL/Daesh and welcomes the commitment of coalition partners to cooperate within a common, comprehensive and long-term strategy to defeat ISIL/Daesh; On paragraph 17, I have chosen to vote against it, as it urges the EU and its Member States to make full use of the EU guidelines on the promotion and protection of the exercise of all human rights by lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people in relation to Iraq and Syria.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. The joint resolution to be adopted does not refer to the real causes that are the source of the current situation in Iraq and Syria. The joint resolution condemns acts of violence, as well as the violation of human rights and ethnic minorities; however, it accuses the Syrian regime of crimes committed in Syria, including the use of chemical weapons against civilians and arbitrary arrests, among other atrocities. It calls for action from the European institutions to increase the level of control and security within European borders to combat Islamist terrorism and strengthen the exchange of information between Member States. It does not, therefore, take into account that one of the causes of the conflict concerns interference by Western powers, especially U.S. intervention in Iraq. That is why we have decided to abstain.

name: Anne SANDER
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns the systematic, brutal and widespread violations of human rights and the abuses committed by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, by ISIL and Islamic State terrorists and other jihadist groups in Iraq and Syria. The situation is catastrophic: in Syria, 7.6 million people are displaced and 12.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. In Iraq, 2.1 million people are internally displaced and 5.2 million are also in urgent need of assistance.  The European Union must increase its aid and assistance to the people affected by these tragedies and finally develop a comprehensive regional strategy to influence the end of conflicts, by combating the financing of terrorism, arms deliveries and the influx of foreign fighters, and by using all the political, economic and diplomatic means at its disposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The adopted resolution contains elements that are difficult to be against, such as the clear condemnation of human rights violations committed by ISIS/Daesh terrorists and their related groups in Syria and Iraq. In this area, concerns are expressed about the progressive deterioration of the humanitarian situation, especially that of domestic refugees. However, the roots of the problem are not included in the resolution. There is no reference to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which was key not only to the humanitarian crisis it triggered, but because it initiated a trend of annihilation of secular states in the Middle East that favored religious factions. Without addressing the roots of the problem, similar situations may be repeated elsewhere in the globe in the future, which is why I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I condemn in the strongest possible terms the systematic human rights violations, abuses and violations of international humanitarian law resulting from the acts committed by IS and associated terrorist groups which amount to war crimes and crimes against humanity.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. — The atrocities of IS are well known and need to be stopped. As there are many, many refugees who are in great need, I welcomed this resolution which calls for an end to the violence, restoration of peace and help for the victims.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I am concerned about the humanitarian catastrophe in Syria and Iraq resulting from the actions of the Assad regime and terrorists, and I consider the assistance of the international community and the Member States of the European Union necessary.  The systematic conduct of violence based on religion and ethnicity in northern Iraq and Syria indicates the prevalence of human rights violations and disregard for the dignity of human life. Currently, over 12 million Syrians are in urgent need of assistance, while more than 7.6 million people have been displaced. No better situation is not in Iraq, there are 6 million people living in IS/Da'esh-controlled areas, of which up to 2.2 million people are hard to come by. Therefore, I support international humanitarian agencies operating in Iraq and Syria in providing as many medical and counselling services, psychological treatment and adequate assistance as possible.  With 276,000 refugees attempting to enter the EU illegally so far, mostly life-threatening by travelling in the Mediterranean Sea, more effective rescue and resuse actions are needed. The European Union must help the Member States under the greatest pressure of asylum seekers to arrive.  In order to achieve lasting peace, I supported this resolution aimed at mitigating the crisis and applying adequate international legislation to bring all acts and crimes to justice.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. —I support this resolution as ISIL's actions have violated all human and moral laws. A humanitarian crisis of terrible proportions is under way, and the world is failing to meet the needs of refugees and the countries that have sheltered them. All forces now need to be focused on aiding, supporting and providing humanitarian aid.  While there are some indications that ISIL has been weakened by the Jordanian plane attack in retaliation for the burning of pilots, there is still a long way to go before the expansion and financing of ISIL is halted, as well as the expansion of the caliphate. Also, in this sense, each country must start on its own, it is necessary to improve controls at the borders and in the interior of each state to prevent fighters from going to Iraq and Syria, because the fact is that the EU residents themselves go to fight on the side of ISIL.  This extremism is a great danger of our time and therefore the EU must do its utmost to contribute to the eventual fall of ISIL and the protection of vulnerable groups there.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support this proposal for a resolution because I think it is of utmost importance that the international community provides additional humanitarian assistance and financial support to countries affected by IS terror and that everything possible is done to prevent their plans as soon as possible. The situation there is getting worse by the day, with more than 200,000 people killed and mostly civilians, women and children. They are killed, tortured and kidnapped en masse because of their political beliefs and religious affiliations, women are captured and sold, and children are driven to suicide by bombings. This is a violation of all the basic human rights we are fighting for and the current situation should be tried as soon as possible so as not to spread IS to the territory of North Africa and Libya, where IS is trying to take advantage of the political vacuum situation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — There is no global campaign against the Islamic State. There are certain countries that are currently fighting against the Islamic Caliphate, most of which are the same ones that indirectly or even directly, in some cases, raised it and equipped it to serve its own interests.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. — The security threats posed by ISIS in the Middle East and beyond, including Europe, have been the topic of much discussion but the ongoing humanitarian crisis should not be lost within that debate. The daily atrocities committed by ISIS are now so widespread that the ability to document and catalogue each one is almost impossible. ISIS holds its territory under a reign of terror in which women are raped, children are used as soldiers, people from the LGBTI community are killed, adulterers are stoned and hostages are beheaded. This same ideology is being exported across the region and only recently we have seen the barbaric murder of Coptic Christians in Libya. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have left Syria and Iraq, heading largely for the immediate border areas including Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. In the Kurdistan Regional of Iraq there are an estimated 1.5 million refugees and internally displaced persons. Recent reports suggest that it will need to find around USD 1.4 billion to finance this in 2015 alone. EU Member States must do more to target development aid to help fund these costs, particularly to those governments, such as Jordan and the Kurdistan Regional Government, that are actively participating in the military fight against ISIS.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — We discussed the humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq, aggravated by the violence of the Islamic State group, with Commissioner Stylianides. I voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq. More than 7.6 million Syrians have been internally displaced and 3.8 million have fled to neighbouring countries. In Iraq, more than 2.1 million people were displaced in 2014 and, according to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, some 330,000 refugees will have to spend the winter in poor-quality shelters. The Kurdistan region of Iraq is home to more than 900,000 displaced people.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which strongly condemned the human rights abuses and violations committed by the terrorists of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and the Assad regime.  There is an urgent need to come up with a strategy to defeat IS and to put an end to the humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq. We must support stronger countries hosting refugees, but also work to cut terrorism financing, the supply of weapons and the flow of foreign fighters.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. - The terrible attacks by ISIL/Daesh are one of the most critical threats that we, as humanity, have to face in our days. The disastrous intervention in Iraq created the conditions for instability and radicalisation. The consequences of such a disastrous and illegal intervention together with the violence and repression inflicted by ISIL/Daesh are gruesome: more than 5.2 million people are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance and more than 2.1 million Iraqis are internally displaced. The situation in Syria, a humanitarian catastrophe with more than 200 000 people killed, was ignited by the plethora of dreadful abuses by the Assad regime, which themselves feed and fuel the conditions in which extremists can thrive and they have created a flood of refugees which it is almost impossible to cope with. I have voted in favour of this resolution because it calls for closer cooperation and engagement in the EU and at international level to help restore peace and stability in a most devastated region and to provide more humanitarian aid and assistance to the people affected by the crisis in Iraq and Syria.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — With this vote I strongly condemn the systematic and widespread human rights abuses and violations committed by the Assad regime and by the terrorists of IS in Iraq and Syria, including the killing of hostages as well as all violence against persons based on their religious and ethnic affiliation, and violence against women, children and LGBTIs, and deplore the establishment of unlawful, so-called ‘sharia courts’ in the territory under IS control. I express my deep sympathy to the victims of the atrocities committed by IS and call for the immediate release of all hostages. The ongoing war in Syria and the recent threat posed by IS, poses a serious threat to the people of Iraq and Syria, and the broader Middle East; the EU has to present a comprehensive regional strategy to defeat IS and to end the humanitarian crisis and the conflict in Syria and Iraq

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. "We vote abstention on this text. We condemn the Islamic State group, but it is unacceptable to put on the same level of responsibility the Syrian state and its President Bashar al-Assad and a terrorist, criminal organization, with opaque funding and support... The Syrian regime is facing an army for many foreign people who are trying to illegitimately overthrow the country's institutions and establish an intolerant and intolerable political-religious regime.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The adopted resolution contains elements that are difficult to be against, such as the clear condemnation of human rights violations committed by ISIS/Daesh terrorists and their related groups in Syria and Iraq. In this area, concerns are expressed about the progressive deterioration of the humanitarian situation, especially that of domestic refugees. However, the roots of the problem are not included in the resolution. There is no reference to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, which was key not only to the humanitarian crisis it triggered, but because it initiated a trend of annihilation of secular states in the Middle East that favored religious factions. Without addressing the roots of the problem, similar situations may be repeated elsewhere in the globe in the future, which is why I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — The ongoing barbaric violence that we are witnessing in the Middle East is appalling. The extreme violence undertaken by ISIS has led to a large number of civilian deaths and mass exodus of people from all walks of life. We believe that the need to continue humanitarian aid to the region is vital to ending the violence and bringing about a just ending to the terrible events unfolding in the Middle East. For this reason I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it condemns the atrocities committed by IS in Iraq and Syria, but above all because it calls on the European Commission and the International Community to assist the victims. An important liberal focus of this resolution is the fate of the child soldiers.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The case of Syria represents a paradigmatic example of the type of external intervention of so-called Western countries, i.e. the EU and the United States and its armed arm, NATO. An intervention that is oriented according to the economic and geostrategic interests of great capital and which completely disregards the political, social and humanitarian rights of peoples. In this way, large continental areas are disorganized by the force of bombs and the financing of extremist terrorist groups, transformed into defenders of democracy and Western values. Unfortunately, and as has happened in the past, the monster has turned against its creator and created a gigantic humanitarian crisis that has rightly shocked public opinion. This is a fire that must mobilise the entire international community and, in particular, the EU, which has strong responsibilities in this process. However, putting out this fire without understanding its origin and without drawing the proper lessons will be just another postponement until more crimes are committed by the West, with the same hypocrisy as ever.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. — I agree with the European Parliament resolution of 12 February 2015 on the humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq.  Christians on the ground in particular are forced to flee FROM ISIS as soon as possible, otherwise they will only be faced with the choice between conversion or beheading. However, as is typical of our EU, the resolution's section of demands does not mention Christians once, where, for example, lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans-suxuelle and intersex (LGBTI) people are repeatedly called for protection. In addition to the obvious demand for the Member States to prevent the departure of future IS fighters, the return of the perpetrators must of course also be noticed and stopped in good time. Otherwise, there is a risk of the formation of terrorist cells within Europe, which will once again increase and spread through propaganda and teaching. People in the affected areas continue to need help. In the form of food and shelter, but also in defence against ISIS. And as soon as possible!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I supported this joint resolution because the situation in Iraq and Syria has resulted in one of the worst humanitarian crises, resulting, among other things, in the massive influx of migrants into Europe. We, as the EU, must first and foremost ensure that international humanitarian law is respected, and we must not allow human rights to be violated even in such a situation. I believe that only an end to the conflict in these countries can resolve the situation, which unfortunately seems to be the case for the long haul at the moment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: writing — A UN report last week revealed the unprecedented cruelty of Islamic radicals from ISIS who do not hesitate in their fight to abuse children with intellectual disabilities as suicide bombers or human shields. The number of abducted children, mainly from Christian groups, but also among Shiites and Sunnis who are tortured, sold into slavery, sexually abused or directly murdered, is also increasing. I am glad that, thanks to my initiative, the resolution approved today contains a clear condemnation of these barbaric practices. It is important that all developed states are more committed to ending the suing of these barbaric radicals as quickly as possible, thus also halting the huge humanitarian crisis in the area.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — We are concerned about the serious political and social situation currently in the Syrian and Iraqi territories. For our part, we also condemn all the freedoms and fundamental rights of these peoples and the criminal practices of torture and indiscriminate murder and persecution of minorities carried out by fascist and far-right ideology groups such as IS or al-Qaeda, as well as the crimes resulting from the aggression that the US and its eu and its allies in the region are carrying out. This situation is inseparable from new and old processes of aggression and invasion of Iraq and the interference and destabilisation of Syria, as well as the occupation and aggression of Israel, processes that rely on the complicity and support of the majority of the EP against international law and the UN Charter. This resolution is part of the campaign of lies and hypocrisy of those who, like most of the EP, supported the promotion, financing and arming of groups that continue to provoke barbarism and destruction, extending it to several countries in the region. At the heart of this problem is the deepening crisis of capitalism and the race for geostrategic dominance and energy resources in which this region is rich.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – I declare the interruption of the session of the European Parliament. (The sitting was closed at 11.40)
